column3:
Minister of Agriculture criticizes "green radicals" and wants to reduce bureaucracy in the sector

For the Minister of Agriculture, this project will bring “competitiveness” to the region and will “help” territorial cohesion and its sustainability

The Minister of Agriculture today criticized the “green radicals” who demonstrate against the construction of dams and warned that it is necessary to simplify projects related to the sector and end the existing bureaucracy. “What we then have to do is another job, which is simplification, which is to get rid of bureaucracy, I know that in this country there are a lot of people who are paid to create problems, deep down, and not to solve them, but this is something that has to end”, said José Manuel Fernandes. The governor, who was speaking at the signing ceremony of the contract for the construction of the irrigation network for the Xévora hydro-agricultural development, in Campo Maior, in the Portalegre district, gave as an example the delay that often takes to obtain, for example, a environmental impact statement. “An environmental impact statement cannot take five years, it is a huge loss for that to happen. Fortunately, we have a Prime Minister who not only considers Agriculture as strategic and structuring but also has this objective of simplification, this objective of accelerating processes”, he highlighted. “Water is a priority for agriculture, it causes me some confusion that there are, for example, radicals as I call them, green radicals, who are against the construction of dams, against the storage of water, this was promoting the desert in a number of places, it was against the environment”, he added. Later, speaking to journalists, José Manuel Fernandes highlighted that agriculture “is not the enemy” of the environment and that dams help biodiversity and help the environment and the fight against climate change. “There are those who want to eliminate dams, which was a disaster, leading not only to the abandonment of the territory but also to an increase in drought and environmental problems”, he lamented. The Government will move forward with the construction of the Xévora Hydroagricultural Development irrigation network, starting from the Abrilongo Dam, in an investment that could exceed 25 million euros. The investment, financed by the Rural Development Program (PDR) 2020, will have to be completed physically and financially by the end of 2025, followed, by 2026, by another phase of the project that encompasses the construction of the irrigation pumping station and the reservoir. The project, at this stage, has an investment of more than R$17 million, will benefit an area of ​​1,560 hectares, with a pipe network length of 44 kilometers. For the Minister of Agriculture, this project will bring “competitiveness” to the region and will “help” territorial cohesion and its sustainability. During the ceremony, the president of the Xévora Beneficiaries Association, Luís Minas, explained that the association “has to be a partner” in this project, remembering that it was the beneficiaries who bore the costs of the environmental impact study project. Also present at the ceremony, the mayor of Campo Grande, Luis Rosinha, said that it is “a very important day” for the municipality, as it is a project “very desired” by the entire population.

column3:
King Charles installs solar panels at Windsor Castle

Britain’s King Charles III, a lifelong campaigner on environmental issues, has installed solar panels at Windsor Castle and plans to convert the British royal family’s Bentley cars to run on biofuel, palace officials said. Charles has installed solar panels on part of the Windsor Castle estate known as the Lord Chamberlain’s Upper Store, replacing the existing lead roof. More panels are planned to be added in the future, officials said. The royal family owns Bentley limousines, which will be converted to run on biofuel next year as an interim step before the fleet goes electric, officials said. The king has long been outspoken on environmental conservation, and in 2020 described global warming and climate change as the greatest threat humanity has ever faced. Palace officials made the announcement as they explained the details of the annual report on taxpayer-funded income and expenditure, known as the Sovereign Grant. The document showed that official spending for 2023-24 was £89.1 million (€106.4 million), up from the £86.3 million allocated, forcing the royal household to dip into reserves to fund the deficit, albeit less than last year. In total, travel costs amounted to £4.2 million, with the biggest overseas expense being the King and Queen's state visit to Kenya, which cost £167,000.

column3:
Two more dolphin carcasses found in Lake Tefé, Amazonas

The emergency monitoring and possible removal of dolphins from Lake Tefé, in Amazonas, found two carcasses of these animals, the Mamirauá Institute for Sustainable Development reported today (2). The mobilization, carried out over the weekend, occurred after the death of more than 100 aquatic mammals, such as the red dolphin and the tucuxi, which lived in the area. On Saturday (30), the Chico Mendes Institute for Biodiversity Conservation (ICMBio) sent teams of veterinarians and staff from the Aquatic Mammal Center (CMA) and the Environmental Emergency Division to determine the causes of the extreme mortality of these mammals. In addition to the drought, the hypothesis is that the heat is causing the deaths of fish and mammals in the region. The mobilization involves partner organizations, such as Mamirauá, with actions to monitor animals still alive, search for and collect carcasses, collect water samples for disease analysis and monitor the water temperature, which reached 40 degrees Celsius (ºC). "We continue the operation to monitor the lake temperature. On the 28th, the temperature reached 39.1°C, dropped to 37ºC on Friday and 32ºC on Saturday. However, yesterday, at 4 pm, it rose to 37.8°C and we are very alert. There is still no major progress in knowing the cause of deaths, but temperature remains the main candidate for the cause of mortality, Ayan Fleischmann, a member of the Mamirauá institute, told Agência Brasil. According to Fleischmann, there is still no update on the rescue of the animals still alive in the lake. On Friday (29), Mamirauá issued an alert to the population living near Lake Tefé to avoid contact with the lake's waters and also recreational use. In an interview with the Viva Maria program, on Rádio Nacional da Amazônia, the coordinator of the Mamirauá Amazon Aquatic Mammal Research Group, Miriam Marmontel, said, on Saturday (30), that these animals end up acting as sentinels of water quality and are the first to be affected by changes caused in the environment. "They gave us the warning and now we have to be aware of it. The tendency, if we don't change our habits, is that these events will continue to happen. Global warming and changing climate parameters are affecting an environment that we use a lot, especially in the Amazon. Water is essential for Amazonians and this water, which is currently not suitable for dolphins, is also not suitable for humans”, said the researcher.

column3:
COP-27: Brazil has chosen to “stop destroying the Amazon”, says Al Gore, former US vice president

Nobel Peace Prize winner, former US vice president and climate activist Albert Gore Junior, better known as Al Gore, said on Monday, the 7th, that a few days ago, Brazil “chose to stop destroying the Amazon”. In an impassioned speech at the summit of leaders of the Climate Conference (COP-27), he argued that global leaders have a “trust problem” when it comes to combating climate change and advocated investing in what he called a “sustainable revolution”. Al Gore did not mention Jair Bolsonaro or Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva by name during his speech. However, on October 30th, as soon as the victory of the PT candidate was confirmed, the activist congratulated the president-elect on his victory and said that “the world expects renewed leadership from Brazil in driving solutions to the climate crisis and in containing biodiversity loss”. “We are talking and starting to act, but we are not doing enough. It is a choice to continue this pattern of destructive behavior. I believe we have other options,” he said. He stressed that we are in the early stages of a “sustainable revolution,” which has the “magnitude of the Industrial Revolution” and the “speed of the digital revolution.” “If we invest in this and stop subsidizing the culture of death, we can save ourselves,” he argued. “Every dollar spent on renewable energy creates three times more jobs than dollars spent on fossil fuels. And this green revolution is massively deflationary, just as the world is trying to find new ways to fight inflation,” he argued.

column3:
Marina Silva receives award in Belo Horizonte and asks for Congressional support for the environment

Brazil's Minister of State for the Environment and Climate Change, Marina Silva, received the Hugo Werneck Award for environmentalist of the year at a ceremony held on Tuesday (2) at the Convention Center of the Belo Horizonte Shopkeepers' Club (CDL-BH). During the ceremony, the manager asked for the support of the National Congress with the agenda related to environmental preservation and revealed that the federal government hopes to double the resources available for the Climate Fund. “The government needs to overcome the difficulties with Congress, which understands that certain structures are a cost. I think it is not a cost, it is an investment. The climate authority will help with the challenge of climate extremes. Right here in Minas Gerais, we are living with torrential rains and rising temperatures,” said the minister. Marina Silva stated that the government of President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva (PT) will work “within budgetary possibilities” to build “new structures” related to environmental preservation. “Civil society and the scientific community are doing their part. Those who are not doing their part are governments and companies,” she claimed. Climate Fund

The minister also commented on the Climate Fund, a Brazilian government instrument created to finance projects, studies and ventures aimed at reducing greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and adapting to the effects of climate change. The initiative already has 10 billion reais in resources and, according to Marina, the government expects to expand to 20 billion reais. “The Climate Fund is for the entire country. It is 10 billion euros for projects in the area of ​​urban mobility, mainly electrification of urban fleets, reforestation and water resources, bioeconomy, infrastructures for sustainable development. We are investing in the new economy. Projects that aim to tackle climate change”, she stated. Municipalization of environmental preservation actions

Journalist and environmentalist Hiram Firmino, creator of the Hugo Werneck award, classifies the environmental issue as revolutionary and defends the participation of municipalities in the agenda. “The world has changed, because pain is educational. People are feeling climate change firsthand. We are talking about the municipalization of environmental management”, he claims. Hugo Werneck Award

The Hugo Werneck Award, created in 2010, is a national reference in the fight for environmental preservation. It recognizes and publicizes the best projects, cases and actions in favor of the environment and sustainability, with more than a thousand applications and 170 winners and honorees. The award has become a landmark in the Brazilian environmental calendar, raising awareness in society about the importance of protecting the planet and fighting climate change. Inspired by the legacy of Hugo Werneck (1919-2008), one of the pioneers of ecological awareness in Latin America, the award encourages society's participation in building a greener future.

column3:
The world's largest moving iceberg causes alarm in the international community. “Antarctica is waking up”

The world's largest iceberg is on the move for the first time in more than 30 years. The ice mass, called A23a, separated from the coast of Antarctica in the late 1980s, and was until now a fixed “ice island” in the Weddell Sea, a region disputed between the United Kingdom and Argentina – a reality that has been changing in the last year. With an impressive 4 thousand square kilometers in area (more than 40 times the size of the city of Lisbon) and 400 meters deep, the recent movement of A23a has left the scientific community on alert. “It had been stationary since 1986, but eventually it would shrink sufficiently in size that it would lose adhesion and start to move,” Andrew Fleming, a specialist at the British Antarctic Survey, told the BBC, adding that the first movements of the platform began to be seen “in 2020.” In recent months, the intensity of this movement has increased, due in part to a change in winds and sea currents. The A23a is now almost over the northern tip of the Antarctic Peninsula. From there, it will probably mark a route towards the South Atlantic – a route that is already known as “iceberg alley”. Originally part of the Filchner-Ronne Ice Barrier, the ice mass broke away from the coast in 1986. At the time, it had a Soviet research station on its surface, which led Moscow to send an expedition to retrieve the equipment and research. The drift of A23a takes place at a time when another round of international debates on the climate is planned - a fact that motivated a visit by the Secretary-General of the United Nations, António Guterres, to Antarctica, where the official once again warned of the drama of climate change. “What happens in Antarctica doesn’t stay in Antarctica. (…) We are seeing a completely devastating acceleration,” said Guterres, who described the upcoming COP28 meeting in Dubai as an opportunity to agree on a period for the energy transition and the abandonment of fossil fuels. “Antarctica is waking up, and the world has to wake up with it,” he added.

column3:
Russia restricts civilian access to villages in Ukraine-bombed border region

Access to 14 villages in the southern Russian Belgorod region bordering Ukraine will be closed to most civilians, Governor Vyacheslav Gladkov said Tuesday, citing the “extremely difficult” situation due to Ukrainian shelling. Announcing the new restrictions in a video posted on his Telegram channel, Gladkov said that starting next week, only adult men accompanying military or government officials will be allowed to enter the settlements. Men must travel in armored vehicles and wear bulletproof vests and helmets, he added. “I hope you will agree that it is unacceptable to allow women and children to enter the settlements that are shelled every day,” Gladkov said. “We have already lost too many civilians, we have too many wounded. And of course, our task is to maximize security measures.” The Belgorod region has come under frequent fire from Ukrainian shelling and drones. Air raid sirens sound almost daily in the regional capital of the same name, just 40km north of the border. Ukraine says Russian shelling of Ukrainian cities has been devastating and, after nearly two and a half years of war, Russian forces are now in control of about a fifth of Ukraine. Russian President Vladimir Putin said in May that Russian forces were working to create a buffer zone in northeastern Ukraine to protect Russia from attacks launched by Kiev’s forces across the border. Gladkov’s announcement is a sign that the security situation in the region may have become more dire, prompting authorities to do more to protect civilians. More than 200 civilians have been killed in the Belgorod region since the start of what Moscow calls its “special military operation” in Ukraine in February 2022, Gladkov told the state-run Tass news agency on Tuesday. More than 1,100 have been wounded.

column3:
Spain detains three people for cyberattacks against countries supporting Ukraine

Spanish police arrested three people on Saturday (20) accused of having participated in cyberattacks by a pro-Russian group against public institutions and strategic sectors of the country and other NATO members. The attacks were directed against countries that support Ukraine in its fight against the Russian invasion, which began in February 2024. Two of the suspects were detained in Huelva and Seville, in southern Spain, while the third was detained in the Balearic Islands, a statement from the Civil Guard said. They were detained for “crimes of computer damage for terrorist purposes”. The three people are believed to have participated in attacks organized by the Russian-linked hacker group “NoName057(16)”, according to the statement. “The main activity of this group is to carry out distributed denial of service (DDoS) attacks against websites of public and private organizations in the government sectors, critical infrastructures and essential services”, said the Civil Guard. The security agency detailed that the group's main activity consisted of organizing DDoS attacks with “software developed by the group itself (…), called DDoSia” and which can be “voluntarily used by individuals who support the purposes of this organization”. The Guardia Civil statement also indicated that the group’s aim was to respond to “hostile and openly anti-Russian actions by Western Russophobes.” In mid-June, Swiss government websites were subjected to a wave of DDoS attacks ahead of a peace summit in Ukraine, in an operation claimed by NoName057(16). The attack targeted the portals of the federal government and organizations participating in the peace summit, according to Bern.

column3:
Running Out of Time, Ukrainian Armed Forces Commander Announces Leadership Changes

The newly installed commander of Ukraine’s armed forces, Aleksandr Syrsky, said he plans to make further changes to the military leadership and general staff, bringing in more officers who have gained experience during the conflict. According to Bloomberg, Syrsky said that “our headquarters must know all the needs on the battlefield and understand the situation on each part of the front. And for this, the skills of the officers who are part of the military administration come to the fore.” The media reported that the commander did not say how many officers who served under his predecessor, General Valery Zaluzhny, would be replaced or provide any other details. Ukraine’s military has struggled to make gains in recent months, as Russia outnumbers Ukrainian forces six to one in artillery shells. Meanwhile, after a review of internal resources, the Ukrainian military plans to recruit “significantly” fewer people than the 500,000 initially discussed, Syrsky said, without providing a new figure. “We hope to have enough people to protect the homeland and we are talking not only about conscripts, but also about volunteers,” he said. After Ukraine's 2023 counteroffensive failed to break through entrenched Russian lines, Kiev is beginning to build its own fortifications, with some critics questioning why this was not started sooner, media reports. In the commander's interpretation, Russia "will continue its offensive along a broad front" and intends to reach the borders of the Donetsk and Luhansk regions "at any cost", as well as reach more territories in Zaporozhie, Syrsky said. "We are preparing solid lines of defense in almost all threatened directions," he added. Last month, the fall of Avdeevka and several nearby settlements fueled fears that Kiev's defenses may not be able to hold out, with Ukrainian officials worried that Russian advances could gain significant momentum by the summer, as reported .

column3:
Climate change: the issue that Trump and the Republicans are not happy about

Climate change seems to be of little concern to participants at the Republican convention in Milwaukee, which met to endorse Donald Trump as a candidate for the US elections in November. "I don't believe in any of this," says Jack Prendergast, a delegate from New York at the meeting, convinced that "volcanic eruptions" cause as much damage to the planet as "the actions of man." He is impatiently awaiting Donald Trump's return to the White House so that the United States "can become the world's leading producer of oil and gas." Skepticism

The former president, who is running to oust Joe Biden from the White House, has the motto "drill, baby, drill," which sums up his support for the exploration and use of fossil fuels. Trump, who regularly makes skeptical comments about the climate, denounced the Paris Agreement during his first term. This week, the Republicans endorsed his candidacy for a second term. To be his running mate in the election, Trump chose Senator J.D. Vance, also a climate skeptic. The Ohio senator, who will become vice president if Trump is elected, has in the past accused Democrats of stoking fears about the "environmental crisis" for electoral gain. The platform the two will advocate in the elections was adopted Monday by Republican delegates in Milwaukee. The 5,000-word document does not make the slightest mention of climate or renewable energy, despite the country suffering a heat wave. On the contrary, the text calls for an end to "green" measures, described as "socialist". Trump himself opposes wind energy, convinced that turbines "kill the birds." Long-term work

Environmentalists like the Sunrise Movement criticized the Republican platform, saying the party “has made clear that it is happy to make the climate crisis worse.” “We have to look at their words with some perspective,” smiles Stephen Perkins of the American Conservation Coalition, perhaps the only booth at the Milwaukee convention to discuss preserving the planet. “I think some of his comments are more intended to entertain than to express political positions,” the 29-year-old told AFP. His organization is present in that major Milwaukee sports hub to advocate for a “conservative approach to climate policy” that could allow Republicans to “win” the youth vote, he believes. “It’s a long-term task,” admits Perkins, referring to a ‘natural aversion’ to the issue, especially among older Republicans. Radical sect

According to a Yale poll released on Tuesday, 16, more than two-thirds of Americans believe in the existence of climate change. However, this does not necessarily translate into support for Democratic President Joe Biden, who has promoted several initiatives to combat global warming during his term. Perkins, on the other hand, believes Biden is at the mercy of a “radical sect” of progressives “who don’t pay attention to nuance.” His booth at the convention displays the word “destruction” next to images of left-wing environmental activists throwing soup at a work of art.

column3:
Kiev could lose all access to the Black Sea if it does not agree to negotiations with Russia, says Musk

American billionaire and businessman Elon Musk believes that if Ukraine does not agree to negotiate with Russia, the country could lose all access to the Black Sea. According to Musk, the longer the conflict lasts, "the more territory Russia will gain." "If the war lasts long enough, Odessa will fall. In my opinion, the main question is whether Ukraine will lose all access to the Black Sea or not. I would advise resolving the conflict through negotiations before that happens," Musk said on the social network X.

According to the businessman, "attacking a larger army with deep defense, minefields and strong artillery, when Ukraine had no superiority in either armor or air, was a tragedy in terms of loss of life." Moscow has repeatedly indicated that it is willing to negotiate, while Kiev has prohibited any dialogue to end the conflict. Meanwhile, the West, which supports the government of President Vladimir Zelensky, is pressuring the country not to enter into negotiations. Earlier, the Russian government stated that there are no prerequisites for a peaceful solution, with the achievement of the objectives of the special operation, which can currently only be achieved militarily. The situation in Ukraine can become peaceful only if the new realities and the de facto situation are taken into account, and all of Moscow's demands are well known. Russia launched military operations in Ukraine on February 24, 2022. President Vladimir Putin justified the move by saying that it was necessary to "protect people who have been subjected to abuse and genocide by the Kiev regime for eight years." According to Putin, this involves "demilitarizing and denazifying Ukraine" and bringing to justice all war criminals responsible for "bloody crimes against civilians."

column3:
In 2024, Ukraine will implement over 200 reforms in accordance with Western recommendations

Moscow, June 4. TASS. The Ukrainian government has approved a plan for 2024, which includes over 200 reforms and about 400 indicators of their implementation, which were developed in accordance with the recommendations of Western partners. This was reported at a cabinet meeting by Ukrainian Prime Minister Denis Shmygal. "We have officially approved the reform matrix and the procedure for monitoring compliance with the recommendations and conditions that our international partners provided us. Over 200 reforms are planned for 2024. About 400 indicators of their implementation have been formed," Shmygal said on the cabinet website. According to the Prime Minister, the framework is a “huge plan for change”, which includes reforms, as well as officially approved recommendations and documents of the European Commission, structural beacons of the IMF, a blueprint for the EU aid program Ukraine Facility and the conditions of the World Bank, with the help of which this framework was developed. He added that the reforms cover both the economic sector and institutional changes, including law enforcement reform and anti-corruption policies. Western allies, on whose aid Ukraine depends, are increasingly linking the continuation of this support, as well as the country's European integration process, to the fulfillment of a number of conditions, including changes in legislation. In the fall of 2023, a leaked letter from the US President's deputy aide for national security Michael Pyle to the Ukrainian leadership caused a great resonance in Ukraine. The document presented a list of priority reforms that Kiev must implement in order to receive aid from Washington. Verkhovna Rada deputy Yaroslav Zheleznyak called this approach "money for reforms", and the head of the parliamentary faction of the pro-presidential party Serving the People, David Arachamiya, acknowledged that bills will be a priority for the Rada, their approval will depend on the continuation of funding from Western donors.

column3:
10 days after protests against Lula with Ukrainian flags, André Ventura shares photo with Putin's ally

It still seems like yesterday that 3 Chega MPs carried posters with Ukrainian flags in protest against Lula da Silva, but in fact it was 10 days ago.

Perhaps to celebrate this initiative in defense of the Ukrainian people, André Ventura shared a photo today with the President of Hungary and one of Putin's main allies in Europe, as proven by his statements and positions, much more denouncing in defense of Russia against Ukraine than Lula da Silva.

In January 2023, Viktor Orbán stated that “Ukraine cannot win even with Western help”, in February the Hungarian Prime Minister accused the EU and NATO of being in favor of war in Ukraine and in March of this year his Government declared that it does not intend to comply with the ICC's arrest warrant against Putin if the Russian leader visits Hungary.

André Ventura shared a photo of Viktor Orbán wearing his jersey today and wrote:

This morning I met with Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán and we talked about the European elections, the future of the right and the European Union. We also talked about football but I can't reveal that conversation ????

column3:
Former Russian president says Ukraine joining NATO would mean ‘war’

Former Russian President Dmitry Medvedev said Ukraine joining NATO would be a declaration of war against Moscow and that only “prudence” on behalf of the alliance could prevent the planet from being torn apart.

North Atlantic Treaty Organization leaders pledged at their summit last week to support Ukraine on an “irreversible path to full Euro-Atlantic integration, including NATO membership,” but left open the question of when that membership might happen.

Medvedev, deputy chairman of Russia’s Security Council and a leading voice among Kremlin hawks, told the Argumenty I Fakty media outlet that Ukraine’s accession would go beyond a direct threat to Moscow’s security.

“This would essentially be a declaration of war – albeit a belated one,” he said in comments published on Wednesday.

“The actions that Russia’s opponents have been taking against us for years, expanding the alliance, are bringing NATO to a point of no return.”

In a standard Kremlin line since Moscow’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine in 2022, Medvedev said Russia was not threatening NATO but would respond to the alliance’s attempts to advance its interests.

“The more such attempts there are, the harsher our responses will become,” Medvedev said. “Whether this will tear the entire planet apart depends solely on the prudence of the (NATO) side.”

column3:
Moscow accuses Kyiv of wanting to open Black Sea to NATO

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky signed a decree on Wednesday on the new Maritime Security Strategy, which envisages "changes and innovations", especially in the Black Sea, and which is accompanied by a strategy with international partners. Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov, commenting on the Ukrainian initiative, warned that Moscow will take measures to ensure the country's security due to the "additional threats" posed by the presence of NATO ships in the area. "The concentrated presence of NATO ships - and we take into account Bulgaria and Romania, which are NATO littoral states - poses additional threats to Russia, especially in the current situation," he said. Peskov referred in particular to the "direct involvement of NATO countries in the conflict over Ukraine", according to the Spanish news agency EFE. "Of course, Russia will take all necessary measures to ensure its own security," he said. Peskov also recalled that "the presence of non-Black Sea states" in those waters "is regulated very strictly by the Montreux Convention". "Turkey is, in this case, the administrator and performs its functions very clearly", he added, quoted by the Spanish agency Europa Press. Dating back to 1936, the Montreux Convention gives Turkey control of the Bosphorus and Dardanelles straits that connect the Black and Mediterranean Seas. Merchant ships enjoy freedom of passage, but warships are subject to restrictions "which vary depending on whether or not these ships belong to the Black Sea states," according to the Turkish government. Crimea's representative in the Russian parliament, Mikhail Sheremet, also accused Zelensky on Monday of wanting to prolong the conflict with Russia, according to the Russian news agency TASS. Sheremet said that Kiev's new maritime security strategy aims to build up Ukrainian naval forces and ensure the presence of North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces in the Black Sea. According to the Crimean MP, if Ukraine's military pressure weakens, Zelensky will no longer be needed by the West and NATO countries will stop supporting him as Ukrainian leader. Russia annexed Ukraine's Crimean peninsula in 2014 and, since the February 2022 invasion, has added the Ukrainian regions of Donetsk, Lugansk, Kherson and Zaporizhia to the list.

column3:
Municipal election cannot ignore climate agenda

The effects of climate change have been part of Brazilians' daily lives for some time. In May, the country was moved by the plight of the people of Rio Grande do Sul in the face of the unprecedented devastation caused by inclement rains, which killed more than 180 residents, left cities submerged, destroyed infrastructure and imposed billions in losses. In recent months, amid severe droughts and scorching temperatures, fires have spread, destroying vegetation and causing disruption to the population. It would be expected that this reality would make climate change one of the main themes of municipal campaigns across the country. That's not what happens, however. As the series of GLOBO reports “Resilient Cities” shows, the mayoral candidates seem to ignore the concern, despite the adaptation and mitigation measures for the effects of global warming mainly concern the municipal sphere. Every candidate should address the issue in their government proposals and plans. But, with the exception of the South, where the scars of the rains are still present, the report reveals that most programs treat the issue vaguely, relegating long-term measures to the background. The most common promises concern Civil Defense actions (alert systems), drainage works, creation of parks or planting trees. Not that such initiatives are unimportant. But the climate emergency demands more. Candidates should clearly explain their policies to prevent the occupation of disaster-prone areas (such as hillsides and riverbanks) and strategies to rehouse vulnerable families. Even if unpopular, these are essential measures to minimize the effects of tragedies resulting from increasingly frequent extreme weather events. Responsible for regulating land use, municipalities bear a fundamental responsibility in preventing disasters. The tragedy in Rio Grande do Sul showed that the occupation of cities needs to be rethought. There is no way to prevent rivers from overflowing or hillsides from sliding under torrential rains, but it is possible to reduce the effects of tragedies by better planning occupation. Certain areas, due to obvious risks, cannot receive housing. But only 13% of Brazilian cities have a specific plan to reduce the risk of disasters, revealed a survey by the Iyaleta Research Association. Less than a third have a master plan for flood prevention. Alert systems are in place in only 8%. In a scenario of more intense extreme events, candidates should present proposals that include reforestation of hillsides, street trees, cooling of transport and schools, preparation of health networks, with particular attention to children and the elderly. It is no longer a matter of projecting into the future. In the middle of winter, Brazilian cities have recorded temperatures above 40 degrees. Campaigns cannot be so disconnected from reality. It is not unlikely that torrential rains, heat waves, prolonged droughts and devastating fires will occur in the coming weeks, months or years. Cities need to be prepared to respond. During the campaign, candidates may even avoid the issue. But, once elected, they will certainly be exposed to it. They cannot claim surprise.

column3:
Bushy mustaches versus activists, in the Age of Climate Trap

Eduardo Oliveira e Sousa, from Ribatejo, with the most lush and bushy mustache in this electoral campaign, caught the eye last week and it wasn't just because of his well-groomed hair above his lips. The head of the AD list for Santarém spoke of “false climate reasons” that hinder investments, an opinion that, unfortunately, many people currently do not tolerate. Or, if he tolerates it, he is afraid of proclaiming it in the middle of the election-hunting season, so as not to harass the most sensitive souls like the swarm of political commentators who got tired of mocking the agro-forestry businessman now running for deputy. The AD candidate, who until a year ago led the powerful Confederation of Farmers of Portugal (CAP) and CNEMA in Santarém, limited himself to sharing what was in his soul and which is his full conviction. His and many other people, by the way. And to his rescue, in a gesture of solidarity that suggests that the news about climate change is clearly exaggerated, was also Saint Peter. In the days following Oliveira e Sousa's astonishing declarations, the saint in charge of climate matters treated us to rain, wind, cold and snow in the highlands as if to demonstrate that tradition is still what it was and so is Winter. Which climate changes which hood! During Carnival it was even raining, remember? At that electoral rally in Ourém, Oliveira e Sousa emphasized, in fact, that extreme weather phenomena have always existed. And he also emphasized it very well! Those more delicate and picky spirits that had been caught up in an Ice Age when there were no Alentejo samarras, salamanders or hot water bags; or that they had faced a flood of biblical dimensions without life jackets, fins and rubber rafts and were going to see what was good for their coughs. Manel, I have a past as an activist that I was unaware of until relatively recently, which ends up reconciling me with my angry and climatically irresponsible youth. For years I had the idea, and the remorse, that I had committed a lot of mischief and jokes of dubious taste, for which I would have to answer on the day of the final judgement. But, in the meantime, I discovered that little or nothing separated me from those who are today called climate activists (and other causes) and who even enjoy a certain amount of sympathy and social reputation, particularly among young people. People today are following a line - cutting roads, vandalizing facilities, throwing eggs and paint at people - and all these practices, which some in other times would call vandalism, delinquency or riots, are today manifestations of activism because practiced by euphemistically called activists. In short, semantic freedoms that help me calm my conscience and better reflect on who to vote for...

column3:
The energy transition

Extreme meteorological phenomena are multiplying. There are huge forest fires, severe droughts, torrential rains, large floods, violent heat waves, etc. In Portugal, some unpleasant effects of climate change are already being felt, effects that are dramatic in other European countries, in the United States, in Canada, in China...

How is it possible to ignore such clear signs and consider that the energy transition must be interrupted, consuming more fossil fuels? It is a regrettable reaction that is taking place in several European countries. This is a way of denying what is obvious. Years ago it was still possible to consider the imperative of reducing CO2 emissions a fantasy. Now, denying what is visible requires greater effort, which, however, some make to avoid being disturbed. The energy transition has costs, which are more comfortable to ignore. Those who react like this probably think that the final tragedy will only happen when they are no longer here. This is how future generations are condemned. This is irresponsible selfishness. Unfortunately, political leaders are not always up to the crisis that is unfolding. They prefer not to bother people and thus avoid the drastic measures that are necessary. Therefore, hope lies in the ability of young generations to protest, in order to force politicians to assume their responsibilities, instead of calmly continuing to act as if the energy transition were not extremely urgent. Young people protest because their lives are at risk. They're right. Everyone, young and old, should be grateful to those who do not resign themselves to passively waiting for the worst to happen.

column3:
Heat kills too many Portuguese people. Housing code should change

More than 600 deaths per year: “The summer plan should have been created in January and does not exist, as does the contingency plan.” Portugal is one of the countries with the highest excess mortality due to heat. It exceeded 600 deaths per year between 1990 and 2019. Carlos Cortes, president of the Medical Association, thinks that prevention could be more effective: “The summer plan should have been created in January and it does not exist, as well as the contingency plan , which should have been known in April. They are essential to preventing deaths associated with excessive heat, and every year this is never done.” “There is a lack of prevention measures and information campaigns for the population. The feeling of thirst is lost with age and older people have to force themselves to drink in hotter weather.” To Diário de Notícias, the president warned that the General Directorate of Health (DGS) is responsible for creating prevention plans. Carlos Cortes warns that heat waves have increased year after year, “with an increasingly longer summer period”. “The most vulnerable groups, such as children, the elderly and people with chronic pathologies that can decompensate, must implement some measures and there is a lack of literacy in this context. The campaigns should have been more intensified”, he adds. Excessive heat has several disadvantages. One of them is the change in our ecosystem: “There are diseases that were typical of Africa and are beginning to be present in Southern Europe. The diseases we have are not the same because viruses and bacteria that have a warmer environment develop differently compared to how they do in a temperate climate.” Precisely in this context, doctor Luís Cadinha recalls that the mosquitoes that carry Zika or dengue no longer reach just “one end of the Algarve and have spread throughout the area and have already been detected in Lisbon”. “Although mosquitoes only transmit diseases when infected, we have a new population in Portugal. This change in temperature makes our country a more favorable habitat for mosquitoes”, warns the public health professional. There are also more ticks. “Ticks stay active for longer and it’s not just in the summer anymore – and these are carriers of diseases that affect us. They start earlier and stop being active later. Previously they were active between May and September and now they start in March and remain until November”. Luís Cadinha also warns about the greater frequency of heat waves. As a comparison: there were only “two or three” between 2000 and 2005, and only in 2023 there were three heat waves.

column3:
Portugal must demand the release of Captain Paul Watson, the protector of whales

Captain Paul Watson has tirelessly roamed the world's seas for decades to defend whales. The founder of Sea Shepherd does nothing but ensure compliance with the law, since whales are supposedly protected by international law. Whaling has been officially banned since the entry into force of a moratorium adopted by the International Whaling Commission (IWC) in 1986. The aim of this organization is to defend life at sea through a unique strategy of aggressive non-violence and intervention against illegal operations that exploit life at sea. To date, it has helped save more than 5,000 cetaceans! Currently, only three countries are determined not to comply with the moratorium: Iceland, Norway and Japan. Japan was already condemned by the International Court of Justice in 2014 for its whaling activities, which were later hidden by false claims of scientific research. The famous captain, who is the subject of an international arrest warrant issued by Tokyo for "conspiracy to commit a collision", was detained on July 21 by Danish authorities while making a discreet stopover from his boat in Greenland. Since then, international public opinion has mobilized to demand the release of Paul Watson, notably through a petition launched by journalist Hugo Clément, which has more than 700,000 signatures. French President Emmanuel Macron has already intervened with Danish authorities to try to prevent his extradition to Japan. Whaling, as well as the persecution of activists who protect it, is increasingly incomprehensible, since we are facing an activity that is not only illegal, but goes far beyond the protection of a species. Today we know that whales play a fundamental role in mitigating climate change. Scientists recently discovered that whales can capture significant amounts of carbon from the atmosphere. Estimates indicate that a whale's ability to capture carbon from the atmosphere is equal to that of thousands of trees. In 2019, the International Monetary Fund itself published a study in which the value of the services provided by a whale (which includes the capture of carbon dioxide) “is more than 2 million dollars and easily more than a trillion dollars for the current large whale population.”

Whales are an essential part of a solution to the climate crisis. Carbon dioxide capture is about 30 to 40 times more efficient in the marine environment, in which whales play a key role. Therefore, the undersigned urge the Portuguese Government to join the other governments that have already embraced this cause, exercising all necessary steps with the Government of Denmark so that it does not extradite Captain Paul Watson and also appealing to the authorities Japanese companies to comply with international law.

column3:
Amazon will have slow recovery due to climate phenomena

The general coordinator of Earth Sciences at the National Institute for Space Research (INPE), Gilvan Sampaio, says that the southwest of the Amazon will receive rain again from November, but the precipitation will be below average and the recovery will possibly be slow. “The rainfall deficit was very large, it will still have effects in November and will gradually recover”, he said. Due to the influence of El Niño, according to him, rainfall will be greater than average in the South and, combined with the temperature anomaly in the North Atlantic, precipitation volumes will be lower than average in the Northern region of Brazil in the coming months. He says that, for Rondônia, the prospect is of maintaining below-average rainfall. “It is in this area that the Madeira River basin is located, which has an important contribution to the Amazon River”, he explained. Madeira is the main tributary of the Amazon. Natural flows in Porto Velho (RO) have values ​​51% below the average in October. Researcher sees relationship between drought in Rio Negro and global warming

The data is on the maps in the joint bulletin of INPE, the National Institute of Meteorology (INMET) and Funceme. Last Friday (27), the general director of INPE, Clézio De Nardin, explained the situation to senators in a session dedicated to debating the effects on climate phenomena such as El Niño. “There is a very serious drought in the west of the Amazon and it will extend to the east. Today in Manaus and going to Pará. It’s serious,” he warned. He explained that the data indicates that the Northeast will suffer from drought from February, March and April. “Get ready! The Northeast will suffer from rainfall well below average. This already motivates bodies to take appropriate prevention actions, especially social ones”, he warned. Data from INPE indicate the greatest increase in temperature ever recorded in the North Atlantic, which inhibits the growth of transpiration in the Amazon. “The temperature growth cycle of the North Atlantic takes the currents and when it reaches the top of the Amazon it forces the air current downwards, preventing the formation of clouds, preventing rain and this causes droughts”, he explained. Added to this are El Niño currents. With part of the Pacific warmed, the ocean winds that move in an East-West direction over the Andes Mountains form a kind of barrier over Brazilian territory, causing cold fronts to circulate more slowly over the South region. “The cold currents enter the southern region very slowly, causing extreme rainfall that is well below average in the rest of the country,” he said. The director highlighted the investment of around R$32.7 million from the Ministry of Science, Technology and Innovation (MCTI) in the Renewal of INPE's Supercomputing Infrastructure. The resources from the National Fund for Scientific and Technological Development (FNDCT) will be used to acquire the new supercomputer, install a photovoltaic plant to meet the machine's energy demand, and develop Monan – the Model for Forecasting Oceans, Continental Surfaces and Atmosphere. The unique data modeling system receives information from satellites, radar data and other measurement systems to forecast weather, ocean behavior, winds, among others.

column3:
Russia may deploy missiles if US deploys long-range missiles in Germany

"I do not exclude any options," said Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Sergei Ryabkov when asked about the possibility of deploying nuclear missiles if the United States confirms its decision, adding that such actions would imply "the definitive end of arms control agreements in that area." "In this situation, taking into account the combined capabilities of NATO member countries, we must evaluate our responses, without any internal limitations in terms of what, where and when [missiles] should or should not be deployed. This means that the options should be as broad as possible," the official said, as quoted by the Russian news agency Interfax. In this sense, the deputy minister said that Russia's position "does not pose a threat to anyone, it is simply seeking the most effective way, also in terms of costs, to respond to changing challenges." Riabkov also assured that Russian authorities will guarantee the security of the Russian enclave of Kaliningrad (a Russian enclave in the Baltic bordering Lithuania and Poland, two countries of the European Union and NATO), which "has long attracted the attention of adversaries". "If the representatives of the German government consider it justified to initiate measures for escalation under the pretext of the situation in the region, we will respond with compensatory measures in the form that we consider most acceptable," he stressed. "We will not stop at anything in solving the problems for our security along the entire perimeter of Russia's borders," he stressed. Last week, Ryabkov had said that "the nature of Russia's reaction" - if the US decides to take such a measure, which would involve the first American shipment of such weapons to Germany since the end of the Cold War - "will be decided calmly and professionally." The announcement by the United States and Germany indicates, as recalled today by the Spanish agency Europa Press, that the installation of long-range missiles aims to demonstrate Washington's "commitment" to NATO and a contribution to "integrated European deterrence", specifying that "these long-range conventional units will include (missiles) SM-6, Tomahawk and latest-generation hypersonic weapons, with a significantly greater range than current land-based materials in Europe". In parallel, the United States and four European countries - the Netherlands, Germany, Italy and Romania - announced on Wednesday the sending of anti-aircraft defense systems to Ukraine following the latest wave of Russian attacks that left 40 dead and 170 injured, as part of the military invasion ordered in February 2022 by President Vladimir Putin.

column3:
“Zombie” viruses are waking up 50,000 years later thanks to thawing Siberian permafrost

Danger is “increasingly evident”: While we are paying attention to climate threats from the south, such as tropical diseases, threats from the north, from melting ice, may be emerging simultaneously. Global health authorities, including the World Health Organization (WHO), are sounding the alarm about a potential new health crisis: the awakening of ancient “zombie viruses” from permafrost — the permanently frozen layer of subsoil. Some of these pathogens are 50,000 years old and were unearthed from layers of Siberian permafrost, according to research shared this Monday in a Bloomberg report. Concerns have intensified at a post-Covid-19 stage, given the absence of immunity and treatments available for these viruses. The main culprit for the awakening of these giant zombies is, once again, global warming, which is, as you read this article, thawing this permanent layer. As the Arctic could be ice-free by the summers of the 2030s, the release of ancient pathogens presents a new front of risk. Alongside greenhouse gases such as methane, pathogens lying dormant in permafrost represent an underestimated danger. Last year, according to the Financial Express, the team led by Aix-Marseille University professor Jean-Michel Claverie, who studies these zombies, published research that revealed that multiple ancient viruses extracted from Siberian permafrost remained infectious. Danger is “increasingly evident”

Pathogen resuscitation is not just theoretical. An anthrax outbreak in Siberia in 2016, triggered by a heat wave, resulted in numerous infections and led to the deaths of thousands of reindeer and a child. A separate study this year also managed to revive a 46,000-year-old roundworm, adding another layer of concern. According to Claverie, the danger is “increasingly evident”: while we normally consider climate threats emanating from the south, such as tropical diseases, threats may also be emerging from the north, in melting ice. The WHO has been monitoring unknown infectious diseases against which humans do not even have immunity or medicinal therapies to treat. The organization has included a generic “Disease X” on its list of priority pathogens requiring urgent investigation. Although the investigation is becoming increasingly complicated due to geopolitical tensions and fears of triggering new pandemics, it remains essential.

column3:
André Ventura confirmed the presence of two of Putin's “friends” who only visit Portugal after electoral defeats

André Ventura confirmed the presence of Jair Bolsonaro and Matteo Salvini, the two “friends” of Vladimir Putin only visit Portugal after electoral defeats, at a far-right summit scheduled for May 13th and 14th. Bolsonaro, who never visited Portugal as president of Brazil, has at least 8 legal actions pending against him. In July 2022, already 5 months into Russia's invasion of Ukraine, then-president Jair Bolsonaro reaffirmed that Brazil would not adhere to sanctions against Russia and that his relationship with the Russian leader was “exceptional… Mine relationship with the Russian government is not good, it is exceptional.” Matteo Salvini, leader of the Northern League, a party that lost more than half of its voters in the last elections in September 2022, risks 15 years in prison where he is accused of “kidnapping” 147 immigrants rescued on board a ship operated by the Spanish NGO Open Arms, who he denied disembarkation as part of his closed ports policy. The deputy prime minister of Italy, who again defended the end of sanctions on Russia in September 2022, has never hidden his admiration for Vladimir Putin, to the point of considering him in 2019 as the “best statesman currently on the planet” and having He wore a t-shirt with the face of the Russian President printed on it. Jair Bolsonaro, former President of Brazil, is facing several judicial investigations:

The case of the jewelry offered by Saudi Arabia. Bolsonaro is said to have brought two packages of jewelry that were not declared to the Tax Authorities. Crimes of genocide against the Yanomami indigenous community. Disobedience, breach of judicial secrecy, and environmental crimes related to the life, health and safety of several indigenous communities. Incitement to violence in the attacks in Brasília. The Public Prosecutor's Office considers that Jair Bolsonaro shared videos on social media in which he questions the regularity of the Presidential elections, which constitutes public incitement to commit a crime. Accusations of electoral fraud. Even before the elections, Bolsonaro was already the target of an investigation due to the successive attacks made on the Brazilian electoral system. Fraud regarding the administration of the vaccine against Covid-19. Bolsonaro's medical records indicate that the former President had taken a dose of the Janssen vaccine on July 19, 2021. Misuse for having used government bodies and resources to benefit his children, who are also the target of judicial investigations. Spying on citizens through the Brazilian Intelligence Agency (Abin). Suspicions that FirstMile was used to monitor opponents of the Bolsonaro government. Appropriation of weapons received on official trip, accused of embezzlement.

column3:
Red alert due to intense heat wave in eastern and southern Europe

Like Romania, all of eastern Europe is under an intense heatwave, the third of the season. "It's exactly what scientists predicted. This is part of human-caused climate change, and it will only get worse in the future if we don't act," Professor Ilan Kelman, from University College London, told AFP. Hungary's Debrecen airport, the country's second largest, had to be temporarily closed because the heat damaged the runways. In neighboring Romania, electricity cuts are multiplying in hospitals due to peaks in air conditioning consumption. A 45-year-old man died due to the heat in the city of Botosani (north) and in several parts of the country temperatures broke records overnight, with thermometers above 27ºC. "It is very concerning that temperatures do not drop. If organizations do not have time to cool down overnight, the number of deaths could increase," warned Kelman. Fires have devastated thousands of hectares in North Macedonia, Albania and Bulgaria. According to Hannah Cloke, a climatologist at the University of Reading, "European city dwellers will have to adapt not only their infrastructure but also their habits to deal with more intense heatwaves in the future," adding that "it could be almost impossible to leave the house on certain days." Prohibited working outdoors in several locations

Heat waves are increasingly likely and severe as a consequence of climate change, according to experts. In Europe, temperatures are increasingly hot, rising twice as fast as the global average. Some regions of Greece have already recorded temperatures above 40ºC for more than 10 days. The heat is so intense that the Acropolis of Athens, the most visited site in the country, had to close its doors for several days during the hottest hours of the day. The economy also had to adapt to high temperatures. In Sicily, since Wednesday, it is prohibited to work in agriculture and construction between 12:30 pm and 4 pm on days when the risk of working outdoors is "high". The measure remains in force until August 31st. A total of 14 Italian cities, including Rome and Florence, are on "red alert" due to heat and humidity. Due to the temperatures, several regions in Italy have suffered an invasion of locusts, according to the agricultural union Coldiretti.

column3: Ukrainian presidential election cancelled: what's next? Ukrainian President Vladimir Zelensky's decision not to hold a presidential election in his country, despite his term ending in two months, is unlikely to have a significant impact on his relations with the West, political analyst Bogdan Bezpalko tells Sputnik. Initially scheduled to take place this Sunday (31), the elections in Ukraine were cancelled under the pretext of martial law declared by President Zelensky. While the authorities in Kiev insisted that this decision was related to the Ukrainian conflict that began in February 2022, there are suspicions that the decision was motivated by Zelensky's ratings in opinion polls. "He does not want to hold elections because he is afraid of losing them and someone else taking his place. Ukraine is not in a state of war, mobilization has not been officially declared, there are no other attributes associated with a country that is officially in a state of war. Martial law, of course, may allow him to extend his term, but not indefinitely," political analyst Bogdan Bezpalko told Sputnik. Russia's permanent representative to the United Nations (UN), Vasily Nebenzya, has already suggested that Zelensky will technically cease to be a legitimate president once his term ends on May 21. However, Bezpalko noted that Zelensky's presidential term could be extended until August, without mentioning that the regime in Kiev could try to stage some provocation to "change the judicial status of the conflict" and thus further escalate the situation. The analyst added that Zelensky's decision is unlikely to have repercussions in the West, as the current regime in Kiev serves the interests of allied countries. However, if for some reason the West decides to remove Zelensky, it would immediately be declared that he does not hold the position legitimately, Bezpalko suggested. While Western powers may make "some timid statements" about Zelensky's decision not to hold elections, they are unlikely to be followed by any sanctions or a decrease in the flow of Western assistance to Kiev, he added. "He may end up facing some difficulties in his contacts with the West, but he will continue to receive help — limited, significantly diminished perhaps, but he will continue to receive help," Bezpalko noted. According to the expert, the question of Zelensky's legitimacy is a secondary concern, as the replacement would probably not change Ukraine's position towards Russia or the conflict as a whole. The reason for this, he said, is the fact that it is not just Ukraine or Zelensky itself that are involved in the conflict with Russia, but essentially the entire West. Bezpalko further noted that Zelensky has established an authoritarian regime in Ukraine by trying to deny his political opponents access to the mass media and any material resources. Furthermore, the president is considered responsible for dragging Ukraine into a conflict that has become an absolute disaster in the country and Zelensky would suffer a major defeat in a free and fair election, Bezpalko concluded.

column3:
Ukraine detains 30 officials suspected of allegedly embezzling nearly €3 million in military funds

The Prosecutor General’s Office of Ukraine announced on Friday the detention of 30 people during a large-scale operation across the country on suspicion of a conspiracy to embezzle military equipment worth nearly €3 million. The suspects were detained on suspicion of being “organizers and participants in criminal schemes involving the embezzlement of budget funds intended to meet the needs of the Armed Forces of Ukraine,” it said in a statement on the social network ‘Telegram’. In a statement, the Prosecutor General’s Office stressed that “a large-scale special operation was carried out to uncover the organizers and participants of criminal schemes involving the embezzlement of budget funds allocated to meet the needs of the Ukrainian Armed Forces,” it wrote, noting that “employees of housing maintenance units were found involved in the embezzlement of funds in almost all oblasts of Ukraine, in cooperation with representatives of commercial entities.” The detainees are 15 alleged members of criminal organizations and another 15 local public officials, including, for example, three officials from the city of Kharkiv, or seven from the Lviv, Chernigov or Yitomir regions. Specifically, they are accused of “inflating the prices” of firewood, electricity or natural gas, and infrastructure for military use, as well as “illegally acquiring assets in the form of commercial properties and land.” This is the latest example of the anti-corruption drive promoted by the country’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, following calls from the international community to facilitate its accession process to the European Union and NATO. These issues are a source of concern for Ukraine’s allies, led by the United States, which has provided tens of billions of euros in financial and military assistance since Russia’s invasion in February 2022.

column3:
US taps Turkey for explosives to help Ukraine, US media say

The United States is in talks to increase purchases of explosives from Turkey to speed up production of artillery shells. According to media reports, Ankara is on track to become the largest seller of artillery munitions to Washington this year. Turkish supplies of trinitrotoluene, known as TNT, and nitroguanidine, which is used as a propellant, would be crucial in the production of NATO-standard 155mm munitions, according to officials familiar with the discussions who spoke to Bloomberg. The surge in demand has delayed global orders and put pressure on defense supply chains, especially for components such as TNT, the officials said on condition of anonymity. The Pentagon said in late February that it had contracted General Dynamics Ordnance and Tactical Systems to build three metal parts lines for 155mm projectiles in Texas, including Turkish subcontractors. The plant, in Mesquite, Texas, is expected to start operating in June, the company said. The Turkish defense contractor Repkon’s production lines are expected to produce about 30% of all 155mm artillery shells made in the United States by 2025, the people said. In a statement about the investment in Texas and Turkish industry, the Pentagon said working with allies “is critical to building a global defense industrial base,” media reports said. In addition, the Defense Department has purchased 116,000 rounds of combat-ready munitions from Turkey’s Arca Defense for delivery this year, with more expected to be delivered as soon as 2025, officials added. The U.S. and European efforts are part of a race to catch up with Moscow, which has the upper hand on the battlefield and has forced Ukrainian troops to abandon strategic locations after surges. Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan plans to visit the White House on May 9 for the first time since President Joe Biden took office, as the two men thaw military ties. The agreement with Ankara also reveals a delicate balance between the NATO allies, whose relations have been strained by the Russian operation in Ukraine and Turkey's months-long blockade of Sweden's accession to the Atlantic Alliance.

column3:
Climate activists sentenced to between four and five years in prison in England

Five protesters linked to the climate group Just Stop Oil were found guilty of conspiracy to commit public disorder, The Guardian said. The activists were sentenced to record sentences for non-violent protests, because of their role in the movement that blocked London's M25 motorway for four consecutive days in November 2022. Roger Hallam, 58 and co-founder of the climate group, was sentenced to five years of prison. The other four involved were sentenced to four years. The five accused reportedly met on Zoom, on November 2, 2022, in a meeting where they discussed protest planning. At the same meeting, they allegedly tried to recruit people to block the highway. A journalist from The Sun reportedly joined the call and sent the recordings to police. During the trial that culminated in the record-breaking sentences, 11 protesters were arrested for contempt outside the courtroom. Christopher Hehir, the judge, considered that "the disturbance was intricately planned" and there was "irrefutable evidence" of the existence of a conspiracy, as cited by Sky News. Furthermore, Hehir added that the protesters "appointed themselves as the sole judges of what should be done in relation to climate change" and that they went "from concerned to fanatical" some time ago. Climáximo, a group of Portuguese climate activists, showed solidarity with Just Stop Oil. In a statement, the group declared that the convicted protesters were “political prisoners of a war that fossil companies declared on society” and compared this situation to the suspended sentence of a year and a half for the group's eight protesters, tried for blocking Avenida Duarte Pacheco , in Lisbon, on December 14, 2023. Amnesty International also spoke out against the penalty. “These long sentences for people seeking only climate justice should raise alarm about the recurring crackdown on peaceful protests in this country. This violates all of our human rights,” said Tom Southerden, legal and human rights advisor at Amnesty UK, as quoted by The Independent. Prosecutors alleged that the protests, during which 45 people climbed onto the motorway gantries, had an economic cost of at least 765,000 pounds, around 907,000 euros. Furthermore, the demonstration would have cost the Metropolitan Police the equivalent of 1.3 million euros. The protests also caused around 50,000 hours of delays and affected 700,000 vehicles, leaving the M25 compromised for more than 120 hours. A police officer also suffered bruises after being knocked down by a motorcycle in traffic caused by the protest.

Lisbon Court removed coercive measures against the historic leader of Neo-Nazi Skinheads to go and fight in Ukraine

It is true, when it was already thought that justice could not surprise, it does surprise, and it is estimated that there are victims of racism and xenophobia who wish that Mário Machado, historic leader of neo-Nazi skinheads and supporter of Chega de André Ventura, would not remain words, and manage to join the Ukrainian troops as quickly as possible, preferably on the front line. Mário Machado shared the Court's request and decision to withdraw the coercive measure for the fortnightly presentation of the crime of possession of a prohibited weapon and wrote: 

Breaking news!! Castro the following”..The serious international crisis triggered by Russia's invasion of Ukraine has mobilized the efforts of thousands of people, mainly in the humanitarian field. The defendant is not indifferent to this movement. Thus, it mobilized a group of people of various nationalities that propose to go to Ukraine to provide humanitarian aid and, if necessary, fight alongside the Ukrainian troops. ”

Since the judge made the order: “.. Considering the humanitarian situation lived in Ukraine and the purposes invoked by the defendant for his claim, the defendant may fail to comply with this measure of coercion while absent abroad.”

column3:
Russia ready to negotiate with Zelensky but questions legitimacy

"This is a difficult issue. From a legal point of view, it is a problem, but from a practical point of view, we are open to achieving our goals through negotiations. Therefore, several variants are possible," the presidential spokesman said. Zelensky's legitimacy as president of Ukraine has been a question raised by Russia, which argues that the Ukrainian leader's term ended on May 20. The Russian spokesman said that in addition to "problems with Zelensky's legitimacy", there is also "the problem of the ban on establishing any contacts or negotiations with the Russian side, as this ban remains in force". "Therefore, there is still a lot to clarify and we need to hear some explanations," Peskov said. Following Zelensky's recent statements about his readiness to negotiate a peaceful solution to the war in Ukraine, the Russian presidential spokesman stressed that "Russia is generally open to the negotiation process, but it is necessary to understand to what extent the Ukrainian side is prepared". "For now, as you can see, we have heard very different statements, so far things are not very clear," he added. On Wednesday, Peskov recalled that Russian President Vladimir Putin had stated that “Zelensky lost his legitimacy” after the end of his term, which “is a factor that could significantly hinder the peace process.” The spokesman also stressed that Russia will ensure the defence of its interests and security in any case, whether through negotiations or weapons. “The special military operation was launched as a last resort to achieve our goals,” Peskov said, stressing that “any war ends with peace negotiations.” In recent days, Zelensky has stressed the need for negotiations to end the war as soon as possible. The Ukrainian president has recently held contacts with political representatives in favour of an immediate ceasefire, such as Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán, US Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump and Vatican Secretary of State Pietro Parolin. Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba traveled to China this week to discuss potential peace talks between Ukraine and Russia. Ukraine has been relying on financial and arms aid from Western allies since Russia invaded the country on February 24, 2022. Kiev's allies have also imposed sanctions on key sectors of the Russian economy to try to reduce Moscow's ability to finance the war effort in Ukraine.

column3:
Bonn Conference: two handfuls of nothing

Compared to COP28, the negotiations took place in a more structured manner, without the confusion of the Green Zone, the hundreds of pavilions and side events, and with much less civil society participation – which, a priori, could indicate a greater appetite for streamlining and rapid negotiations. But that was not what happened. Around 6,000 participants from almost 200 countries met to address issues such as National Mitigation Plans (NDCs) and Adaptation Plans (NAPs), the Loss and Damage Fund, accelerating climate action through a just transition, Article 6 of the Paris Agreement (Carbon Markets) and the Transparency Framework. Climate finance, in particular the New Quantified Target for Climate Finance (NCQG), will be decided almost entirely at COP29 in Azerbaijan, becoming the “elephant in the room”. Despite expectations based on the outcome of the COP28 Global Stocktake on climate finance, SB60 represented a snail’s pace in climate negotiations and a serious omission in the face of the informal commitment to abandon fossil fuels. We returned home with two hands full of nothing and two hands full of everything for Azerbaijan. The major agreements of SB60 concerned the length of the texts submitted for negotiation, and the structural divide between the views of developed and developing countries. The current model of climate negotiations, known as the “Global Negotiating Process”, has proven to be ineffective, bureaucratic and dominated by the Global North. Every year, negotiators meet to discuss and make decisions on the best way to combat climate change. The working instruments for the negotiations are the negotiating texts, based on written proposals submitted by governments. At the end of a negotiation, the President bangs the gavel to declare that a decision or a new treaty has been adopted. The COP is the supreme decision-making body of the climate change process and we are heading towards the 29th. This inefficiency becomes even more worrying given the consecutive increase, year after year, in greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. It is urgent to rethink the traditional negotiation model and make it more efficient, accessible and transparent to civil society, ensuring a fair and equitable process that legally incorporates the needs of frontline countries. Ultimately: turning it into a true Climate Action Body, otherwise it will become the “dinosaur” in the room. Nothing less than this will be enough to limit the average temperature of the planet to 1.5ºC.

column3:
Artists gave up on “saving” the Amazon

This week the Amazon recorded the worst fire season in 17 years. The smoke corridor that has spread has already affected 10 Brazilian states. Despite the news about the fires not only in the Amazon Forest but also in the Pantanal being highlighted in the media, the concern of those who call themselves environmental defenders has not been nearly the same as that of the previous government. In 2021, when everything was the fault of the incumbent president, Greenpeace Brasil brought together more than 30 artists to release the song “Canção para a Amazônia”, signed by Carlos Rennó and Nando Reis. Several artists who participated in the action also campaigned for Lula in 2022, of course. However, they all remain silent about the increase in fires in Brazil. 3 years ago, Nando Reis himself, when commenting on the project, stated that “The situation in the Amazon is dramatic, serious and represents the climate catastrophe we are experiencing. And, to make matters worse, we have a president who has no commitment to combating deforestation.” Could it be that Nando's concern is no longer the same in 2024, considering that he is not making the same demand now? It is also worth highlighting the speech by the Spokesperson for the Greenpeace Amazon Campaign, Carolina Marçal, who in September 2021 stated that “the Bolsonaro misgovernment implements a destructive anti-environmental agenda. We will continue to resist and fight for the Amazon. Art is a powerful form of activism, struggle and resistance, and it is an honor for us to participate in a project like this”, said the expert. Where has all this resistance gone now that Lula is president? During the last electoral campaign, one of the main issues raised by the left was environmental issues and the protection of indigenous people, but as with many other things, it was yet another failure. The number of Yanomami deaths in 2023 was higher than that of 2022. Earlier this month, the newspaper “Estadão” announced that the Lula government would erase data on indigenous deaths. Nothing that seems to worry progressive singers either. Minister Marina Silva, now forced to appear more often due to the fire crisis, has already blamed climate change, human actions, and El Niño. He even blamed the previous administration for the record deforestation during the PT government, but before supporting and joining the PT there weren't so many people to blame. The target was just one. As always, according to the left, nothing bad that happens when they are in power is their fault, always someone else's. In 2020, Lula questioned where the armed forces were to try to combat the fires in the Pantanal and the Amazon, and stated that the then Minister of the Environment was a characterless citizen with no respect for nature. I am still waiting for the moment when you criticize yourself and your current minister for what is happening. With deforestation or fires, dead jaguars or charred alligators, indigenous people being killed or committing suicide, the artists, who loved to appear so much in previous years, did not have the courage to take a stand now, confirming that the concern was not with nature but with the pet politician. They quickly gave up on “saving” the Amazon.
