column3:
Too much sunlight and heat reduce mental abilities: here are the results of a study

Science, in numerous studies published in the literature, has amply demonstrated how excessive heat can lead to heat exhaustion or heatstroke, as the body's internal temperature rises dangerously. A new study shows that the scorching sun can have an impact on the brain even when the body temperature remains normal, without excessive temperatures. The investigation

Supported by the EU-funded HEAT-SHIELD project, the team behind the research suggests that the actual effect of prolonged exposure to sunlight on temperature and brain function has not been fully explored in previous investigations. "Acute exposure did not affect performance parameters, while prolonged exposure of the head and neck resulted in a 1ºC increase in core temperature and significant changes in controlled cognitive performance and motor activities," says the study published in the journal Scientific Reports. "Importantly, the deficiencies emerged at significantly lower levels of hyperthermia compared to previous experiments," he adds. Cognition refers to the mental skills and processes involved in acquiring and processing information necessary for everyday life. It includes memory, cognition, attention, reasoning, problem solving and understanding. The consequences of hyperthermia

Hyperthermia, even of short duration, can lead to cognitive impairment, negatively affecting attention, memory and information processing. These results underscore the importance of including the effect of radiative heat from sunlight on the head and neck in future scientific assessments of the impacts of heat stress and of specific head protection to minimize harmful effects. What is the impact of heat stress? According to Professor Lars Nybo, co-author of the study, "the decrease in cognitive performance was observed at 38.5 degrees, that is, at a body temperature one degree lower than that demonstrated by previous studies, which represents a substantial difference ". Co-author Andreas Flouris, associate professor at the University of Thessaly and project partner, highlights the need to mitigate health and performance deteriorations induced by heat stress, intensified by global warming. The expert emphasizes that people who work or carry out daily activities outdoors should protect their heads from sunlight. "The ability to maintain concentration and avoid attenuation of motor and cognitive performance is certainly important for safety at work and in traffic, as well as minimizing the risk of error during other daily activities." The impact of solar radiation on climate change

The researchers conclude that the harmful effects of solar radiation must be taken into account in future studies that analyze the current effects of atmospheric or climate changes on health at work. For the purposes of the study, researchers tested the mental abilities of eight men, ages 27 to 41, as they worked on computers with direct exposure to heat from light bulbs aimed at their heads and backs.

column3:
Here's the news after the bomb cyclone Ciarán: Portugal has "physical conditions for storms to increase in frequency and amplitude"

"The warmer the ocean, the more energy is available to the atmosphere to be able to develop these very deep depressions with significant impacts." And as "the ocean is very slow", the consequences extend over time. Portugal has “physical conditions for storms to increase in frequency and amplitude”. Storm Ciarán, which arrived in Europe as a bomb cyclone, is not the first of its kind to hit Portuguese soil, but it is likely that phenomena like this will become more frequent. Furthermore, the weekend should bring another storm, which already has a name - Domingos. Geophysicist and former president of the Portuguese Institute of the Sea and Atmosphere (IPMA) Miguel Miranda warns, in statements to CNN Portugal, about the scale of the storms in question. “It is very interesting from a physical point of view but very alarming from a social point of view”, he highlights, noting that in the most affected countries, such as France, winds of 200 km/h were recorded, a highly significant value and which is extremely rare. on European soil. Miguel Miranda explains that, mainly due to global warming - which will cause a warming of the oceans -, it is natural for phenomena like this to occur with greater frequency and intensity. “The warmer the ocean, the more energy is available for the atmosphere to be able to develop these very deep depressions with significant impacts on buildings and people”, adds the geophysicist. And, although the worst is over, it is expected that several effects will still be noticed in the coming days, at least until the weekend. This is because “the ocean is very slow”, which causes the consequences to extend over time, even after the system that causes the storm has passed. “This leads to restrictions on the coast, especially because there is a second ocean storm this weekend that will make life difficult in coastal communities”, highlights Miguel Miranda. The expert, therefore, asks that people strictly comply with the recommendations of the IPMA, which issued a red warning for a large part of the coast, while also leaving an orange warning for at least the entire coast. “It is important to understand that we are going to have a new maximum in maritime unrest. When waves eight meters high are indicated, this means that 10% of the waves may be more than 16 meters. When there is a red warning issued by IPMA, it must be strictly complied with because the dangers that exist are many”, reiterates Miguel Miranda. Regarding the effects that these bomb cyclones can cause, Miguel Miranda says that “the Portuguese have some experience of tornadoes, systems from another dimension”, but warns of the impacts that wind and rain can have, especially in areas closer to the coastal. Just look at what happened in 1941, when IPMA records marked the first bomb cyclone on national soil. "When winds reach speeds of this magnitude, they lift objects and destroy trees. The combined action of wind and rain is very impactful - large trees that fall in urban areas are capable of destroying homes and vehicles", concludes the geophysicist.

column3:
Environmental surcharges on flights will become the norm

When you buy a plane ticket, do you choose to pay extra to offset carbon emissions? If the answer is “no”, you are not alone. Voluntary participation in offsetting schemes may be less than 3% of people. Instead, Lufthansa will introduce a mandatory “environmental cost surcharge” on flights from the EU, the UK, Norway or Switzerland from the beginning of 2025. This will add up to 72 euros to a long-haul first class ticket. On short- and medium-haul flights, it will be closer to 1 to 7 euros. The German airline is unlikely to be alone. Mandatory green surcharges are expected to be adopted by traditional airlines in particular. A number of environmental regulations are to blame, says Lufthansa. She cites EU requirements for jet fuel to include a blend of at least 2% sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) from next year, as well as changes to emissions trading schemes (ETS) in Europe. Air France-KLM laid the groundwork in 2022 by imposing a “SAF contribution rate”, charged at a lower level. Each regulatory change on its own is not outrageous. In fact, SAF, produced from a variety of materials including recycled cooking oil, is expected to cost at least double the long-term historical price of kerosene by 2050, according to a recent report from LEK Consulting. But suppose Lufthansa's 2025 fuel bill remains close to the €8.3 billion it forecasts for 2024, a quick calculation suggests that compliance with the 2025 EU mixing rules could cost another €17 million. Required mixing levels rise again in 2030 and 2035. Changes to the EU ETS scheme and similar programs elsewhere will be more expensive. Currently, polluters receive some free permits, but these are being reduced. The impact on traditional airlines will be greater, argues Goodbody analyst Dudley Shanley, as they have historically been larger emitters and tend to have less efficient fleets. This year, Lufthansa expects to receive free emission certificates for around 2.8 million tonnes of CO₂, compared to 3.8 million tonnes in 2023, according to its latest annual report. This reduction could cost 65 million euros, starting with BloombergNEF's forecast for an average price of 65 euros per ton of permitted EU emissions this year. They are expected to rise to €80/t in 2025. In good times, these costs could be absorbed. Lufthansa is expected to have a net profit in 2025 of almost 1.8 billion euros, according to figures from Visible Alpha. However, traditional airlines fight a perpetual war to reduce the huge cost gap with their low-cost competitors. Passengers may complain, but the baggage of mandatory environmental fees — at least among major airlines — could become the norm.

column3:
This is not activism: it is radicalism and it is unworthy

In an evolved and democratized society, the ends do not justify the means. To defend the idea and fight the cause, it ceases to be acceptable to society when dialogue is not used in a civilized manner. By going for aggression, whatever modus operandi it may have, one will be clearly disrespecting the good practices that activism must implement with the objective consequence of the struggle and the fight for the idea not being understood, and therefore same reason it doesn't have the necessary strength it should. The recent events that led to the throwing of green paint at Minister Duarte Cordeiro, have, in my reading, a simple reason. Someone gradually feeds a group, radicalizing the issue of climate change. With dignity, Duarte Cordeiro continued his work, not dwelling on the controversy, stating that he understood the situation and others in the recent past. Activism, as we have seen it, with ramifications for the most radical policies, loses across the board. The debate gave way to the most original ways of showing themselves but with the sad premise of harming third parties. The trend of puncturing tires on specific brand cars just because is still very present in everyone's mind, and in the pockets of some. This is nothing. This is going deep into everything that is civilization and a society that wants to be modern in the debate of ideas. We will never evolve if activism in Portugal continues to present us with these sad spectacles that only diminish the power of dialogue in the search for solutions and points of convergence. The group “Greve Climática Estudantil”, which committed a public crime with its act, which for this reason does not need to be complained about, must realize that it is socially losing the fight, not because of the idea it defends, but because of the way it is defended, and we must all show our outrage at this group and so many others. No matter how respectable your fight and your conviction is from an ideological point of view, everything takes on a different perspective when you turn to aggression, because it is totally reprehensible. It is urgent to change the paradigm of thinking and action of activist groups. Their notorious “dangerousness” should not be the motto, but unfortunately that is how they show themselves. The right to expression is inalienable and intrinsic to human nature itself, but none of this can be confused with everything we see. With this episode, which hit Minister Duarte Cordeiro – lucky for the paint not to hit his eyes – the time has come to tell all activists to change. Be intelligent in your manner, be worthy in fighting your causes and stop violence once and for all. Yes, because we are talking about violence and its practice is counterproductive in our democratic rule of law. This is not how we evolved nor is this the way to act, but it will also not be how Portuguese society has any respect for you. Rather the opposite.

column3:
Extreme heat waves cause more than 175,000 deaths a year in Europe, says WHO

More than 175,000 people die every year in Europe due to the effects of the extreme heat wave, according to a statement published this Thursday (1st) by the European division of the World Health Organization (WHO). Among the almost 489,000 heat-related deaths recorded annually between 2000 and 2019 in the world, "the European region represents 36%, that is, an average of 176,040 deaths per year" during this period. The WHO Europe region, which extends into Central Asia, is warming faster, about twice the global average, the organization says. Over the past 20 years, heat-related mortality has increased by 30% in the region. "Extreme temperatures worsen chronic diseases, including cardiovascular, respiratory and cerebrovascular, mental health and diabetes-related conditions," explains WHO Europe. They are also responsible "for "thermal stress", when the human body is unable to maintain a temperature between 36 and 37°C, the main cause of climate-related mortality in the region. According to the WHO, the number of heat victims " "The three hottest years on record in the WHO European region have occurred since 2020, and the ten hottest years since 2007. ", explained Kluge. According to the United Nations, it is possible to face the heat by adopting simple behaviors, such as keeping your home cool and hydrating yourself regularly. On July 25, the head of the UN, António Guterres, made an appeal in the face of the "epidemic" of extreme heat and defended concrete measures to confront this "invisible killer". For the Secretary-General of the United Nations, it is necessary to take care of vulnerable people, protect exposed workers and limit the increase in global temperature to 1.5°C.

column3:
Dugin: “Ukraine is the First Multipolar Conflict”

In an interview with the international television network RT, Alexander Dugin quickly explained the geopolitical dimension of the Ukrainian conflict and the foundations of the multipolar world that is rising against the imperialist universalism of the West. The conflict in Ukraine is the world’s “first multipolar war,” in which Russia fights for the right of each civilization to choose its own path while the West wants to maintain its hegemonic totalitarian globalism, Aleksandr Dugin told RT in an exclusive interview on Friday. Multipolarity is not “against the West as such,” Dugin said, but “against the West’s claim to be the model, to be the unique example” of history and human understanding. Today’s Russophobia and hatred of Russia, he argued, are a relic of Cold War thinking and the “bipolar understanding of the architecture of international relations.” When the Soviet Union self-destructed in December 1991, it left the “Western global liberal civilization” in control of the world, Dugin noted. This hegemon now refuses to accept a future in which it would be “not one of two, but one of [a few] poles,” put in its rightful place as “only a part, not the whole, of humanity.” Dugin described the West as “pure totalitarian liberalism,” which pretends to have absolute truth and seeks to impose it on everyone. “There is racism inherent in Western liberalism,” the philosopher told RT’s Donald Courter, because it “identifies Western historical, political, cultural experience [as] universal.” “There is no universal in multipolarity,” Dugin insisted, explaining that each civilization can and should develop its own values. Russia specifically needs to overcome centuries of Western ideological dominance, he said, and create something “new, fresh, creative” that would nevertheless remain “in direct refutation of Western liberal hegemony, against the open society, against individualism, against liberal democracy.” He rejected the “dogmatic” attitudes of Marxism, fascism or liberalism toward politics and economics, saying that Russia should strive for a “holistic” approach, in which the spiritual would be more important than the material. Obsession with material goods ends up enslaving people, Dugin told RT. Dugin lamented the collapse of the Soviet Union in December 1991 as a “suicide” perpetrated by power-hungry bureaucrats in Moscow. He echoed Russian President Vladimir Putin’s description of the event as a “geopolitical disaster” and described it as a great victory for “Sea Power.” While the USSR was the polar opposite of the Russian Empire in ideological terms, he explained, in geopolitical terms the two were one and the same, the strongest power in what the English geographer Harold Mackinder described as the global Heartland. While some Western observers have called Dugin “Putin’s brain,” the 60-year-old philosopher and author has no official ties to the Kremlin. He is an outspoken supporter of the current military operation in Ukraine—whose independence he sees as a Western imperial project against Russian sovereignty. Dugin’s daughter, Daria, just 29, was murdered in August by a car bomb set by Ukrainian agents. Although Kiev officially denied it, U.S. intelligence officials later said they believed someone in the Ukrainian government was involved and responsible.

column3:
About Kiev's attacks on Russian missile attack warning radar stations (SPRN)

In recent days, information has appeared on the network about attacks by Ukrainian Armed Forces UAVs on:

▪️the Voronezh-DM long-range radar near Armavir. ▪️the Voronezh family long-range radar in the Orenburg region. Also, the Portuguese-made Tekever AR3 UAVs were not spared for the attacks. These stations are an element of Russia's nuclear security shield. We note that, in accordance with Russia's National Security Strategy, in achieving the country's defense goals, special attention is paid to solving tasks, among which "maintaining a sufficient level of nuclear deterrence potential" stands out. Attacks on these radars are a serious decision. They solve several tasks:

▪️Weakening of Russia's nuclear security

▪️Repeated testing of Russia's patience

▪️Russia's provocation to use tactical nuclear weapons

▪️In the absence of a firm reaction from Russia, creating conditions for further weakening of our strategic defense in the event of a direct conflict with NATO. After these attacks on our long-range radars, a surprised expression was made by The Washington Post: "The US is concerned about Ukrainian drone attacks on long-range radars in Russia. According to the newspaper, this could disrupt “strategic stability.” This “concern” of the Americans is quite understandable. After all, according to the open Supreme Decree “On the Fundamentals of the State Policy of the Russian Federation in the Field of Nuclear Deterrence,” the conditions that determine the possibility of using nuclear weapons by the Russian Federation include “the enemy’s influence on critical objects of state or military importance of the Russian Federation, the deactivation of which would lead to the failure of retaliatory actions by nuclear forces.” At present, all the legal grounds for the use of nuclear weapons by Russia on the territory of Ukraine have been established. And nowhere does it say that these weapons should be designated as “tactical.” However, given the eternal delay in implementing retaliatory measures or their media-heavy nature, we are unlikely to see such actions in the near future. And for now, the situation is still moving in such a way that no one thinks about the moral aspects of such actions or about opening the “Overton Window” or “Pandora’s Box” “when the very existence of the state is threatened.”

column3:
Russia says it wants to understand what kind of peace summit Zelensky wants

Russia does not categorically reject participating in a future peace conference with Ukraine, but wants to first understand the framework of the meeting suggested this week by Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. The Kremlin responded this Tuesday to the proposal put forward the day before by Zelensky that Russia should be present at a second peace summit that could probably be scheduled for November. “The first peace summit was not a peace summit at all, so perhaps we first need to understand what he means,” Kremlin spokesman Dmitri Peskov said on Tuesday in an interview with the military channel Zvezda , quoted by the Moscow Times. Peskov was referring to the conference organized by Switzerland in June in the Alps, to which no Russian leaders were invited. At the time, this was a demand from Zelensky, who refused to sit at the table with representatives of the power that occupies part of Ukrainian territory. Moscow criticized the lack of invitation and several countries decided not to attend the conference, including China, Russia's main diplomatic ally. Other nations from the Global South that were present ended up not signing the final communiqué, dealing a blow to the ambitions of Kiev and its Western partners to present strong global support for Zelensky's peace plan. Despite the absence of an invitation to Russia at the Swiss summit, future participation of Russian representatives in future meetings was never excluded. Still, it is difficult to understand what could bring the positions of the two countries closer together in possible talks. Ukraine demands Russia's immediate military withdrawal from occupied territories, while Moscow wants recognition of the annexations of the four provinces it partially occupies. Zelensky's statements this week come at a time when Russia is managing to make some progress on the battlefield, especially in Donbass, which is the primary objective of the invasion that began in February 2022.

column3:
Activists who blocked private jet in Cascais sentenced with suspended sentences

The six activists from the Climáximo movement, who blocked a private jet at Cascais airfield in 2023, were sentenced this Monday to a suspended sentence of 15 months in prison, 135 days of community service and to pay 5,300.59 euros. The environmental group, in a note sent to newsrooms, indicated that the sentence was read this Monday morning, in “the same month in which the temperature broke the world record twice in a row”. seven months ago, while governments and fossil fuel companies were meeting at COP28, to which they flew en masse by private jet for yet another round of false promises, Climáximo supporters entered the Cascais airfield, painted a private jet with red paint and blocked it with their bodies”,

The six activists were tried for, in December 2023, blocking a private jet at the Cascais airfield, to denounce the “super-rich’s superfluous and luxury flights, and the use of these weapons of mass destruction, whose emissions are killing people all over the world”. Climáximo recalls that, “seven months ago, while governments and fossil fuel companies were meeting at COP28, to which they flew en masse by private jet for yet another round of false promises, Climáximo supporters entered the Cascais airfield, painted a private jet with red paint and blocked it with their bodies”. The group stresses that this sentence will not intimidate its supporters, “nor will it stop the fight”. One of the convicted activists, quoted in the group’s statement, lamented that “today, despite the court’s admission of the gravity of the climate crisis and the impact of disruptive protests, the people who took action to stop the destruction have been convicted, while the real culprits remain unpunished”. Last week, Climáximo supporters were supporting the actions at airports of the international uprising to end fossil fuels by 2030, as well as the fight in France against the privatization and theft of water by big industries.

column3:
Ukraine, strapped for support, heads to India, urges New Delhi to rethink 'Soviet legacy with Russia'

This week, Ukraine's foreign minister Dmitry Kuleba traveled to New Delhi to seek support from the world's most populous nation, seeking to deepen ties with countries in the Global South as Ukraine faces a critical moment on the battlefield. In an interview with the Financial Times, the foreign minister urged the Indian government to support Kiev, saying that close ties between India and Russia are based on a "Soviet legacy". The foreign minister's visit is the first by a senior Ukrainian official to India since the Russian operation in Ukraine began. "Cooperation between India and Russia is largely based on the Soviet legacy. But this is not the legacy that will be preserved for centuries; it is a legacy that is evaporating," he said. Kuleba also made a provocative connection by linking the friendship between Moscow and Beijing with what China supposedly means to India today. "The Sino-Russian relationship should be of special concern to India in light of its national security prerogatives." Going further with his arguments to convince New Delhi, Kuleba cited that when the conflict ends, Ukraine "will probably become the largest construction site in the world and Indian companies are welcome to participate in the recovery." Kiev is now seeking to “restore trade” with India, the minister said, by resuming exports of agricultural products such as sunflower oil and buying more Indian products itself: “We are interested in importing some of the heavy machinery items that India produces,” he added. Ukraine has struggled to win the favor of India and many other countries in the Global South. These states have largely avoided taking sides in a conflict that they consider “the business of rich nations” and whose economic price they have paid in trade disruptions and higher costs, the media reported. Despite Kuleba’s statements that ties between Moscow and New Delhi are “evaporating,” Russia remains India’s largest arms supplier. The Indian state has also become a major buyer of Russian crude oil following the Russian operation in Ukraine, and India shares with Moscow (along with China and Brazil) the original founding of the BRICS. Media reports have previously reported that Kuleba claimed that every barrel of Russian crude oil purchased by India contained “a good portion of Ukrainian blood.” However, Kiev has sought to smooth relations with New Delhi as it tries to win over more countries to its cause, the Financial Times writes.

column3:
Lavrov calls on the UN to eliminate the causes of the conflict in Ukraine

The end of the confrontation between Moscow and Kiev must be accompanied by the elimination of the threat that the West poses to Russia's security, said the head of Foreign Affairs during an open debate at the Security Council convened by his delegation, which chairs that entity this month. Lavrov insisted that both his country and the West need mutual guarantees and agreements, in a clear allusion to the need to reach an agreement for the security of both. At the same time, he considered it necessary to take into account the new geostrategic realities on the Eurasian continent, where a new, truly equal and indivisible continental security architecture is being formed. In this context, he added, Europe runs the risk of falling behind in this objectively historic process. “We are ready to seek a balance of interests,” he further said. The global and regional balance of power must also be restored, along with redressing injustices in the global economy, the senior diplomat added. Russia's Foreign Minister rejected the use of these coercive measures in a multipolar world that, in his opinion, should have no monopoly on financial or monetary regulation, trade or technologies. Regarding American policy, the head of Russian diplomacy warned that Washington is convinced that a new global war will not affect the United States, but its European allies. “If this analysis forms the basis of the (Joe) Biden administration’s strategy, it is a very dangerous mistake, and Europeans should realize that they have been assigned a suicidal role”, he added before the members of the highest body for peace on the planet. At the same time, it demanded more attention from national minorities to resolve the conflict on Ukrainian territory. “We ask all those who show a sincere interest in overcoming the crisis in Ukraine to consider in any of their proposals the fundamental issue of the rights of national minorities. Everyone, without exception”, insisted the high representative. ro/ebr/ls

column3:
Underground water reserves at risk due to climate change

The study, published on Saturday in the scientific journal Scientific Reports, from the Nature group, analyzed “an unprecedented set of data” collected over a year in caves in various parts of the globe, from subarctic to tropical regions, including in Portugal , caves in the center of the country, in the Algarve and the Azores. Over the course of a year, every two hours the temperature was measured in caves and on the surface, totaling more than 100,000 measurements, which “demonstrate that the temperature in the caves corresponds to the average annual surface temperature for each location”, said Ana Sofia Reboleira , Professor at the Faculty of Sciences of the University of Lisbon and researcher at the Center for Ecology, Evolution and Environmental Changes, to the Lusa agency. According to the biologist “the caves responded with three different patterns”: one in which the variation in external temperature is reflected in the cave with a small delay, another in which the temperatures on the surface are quickly reflected inside and, a third in which they work in a mirror, the lower the temperature on the surface, the higher inside the cave and vice versa. More surprising was the discovery of “the existence of daily thermal cycles in some caves”, considered by the researcher “particularly interesting because in ecosystems with a total absence of light, organisms lack circadian rhythms, that is, biological rhythms marked by the natural cadence of day and night controlled by sunlight on the surface.” This discovery “shows that these daily thermal cycles can potentially control the biological rhythms of underground organisms”, a hypothesis that appears for the first time in the history of Biology. “These ecosystems are inhabited by unique species that play a very important role in what scientists call ecosystem services” since, he explained, “it is these animals that guarantee the deep recycling of nutrients, of some contaminants that get there, that control the bacterial growth and other types of problems that can affect us.” In the case of organisms adapted to low amplitudes and reduced thermal variability, the increase in temperatures by several degrees, due to climate change, “will certainly affect these organisms responsible for guaranteeing the good ecological status of these underground water bodies”, which represent 97 % of total freshwater resources available for immediate human consumption. Among the caves covered in the study, the scientist highlights the case of one in Loulé that recorded the highest temperature on the surface, with more than 39 degrees, and another in the Azores, with the greatest thermal amplitude, with a variation of 8.8, explained due to the fact that it is a volcanic cave. The impact of climate change, combined with the fact that underground ecosystems “are constantly neglected in political and public agendas”, lead researchers to now move forward with laboratory studies “on the effects of rising temperatures on these organisms” aiming to estimate the maximum temperatures that these will be able to handle it. The study now published included, in addition to the coordinator, the participation of Maria João Medina, a master's student whose dissertation includes the study, and Paulo Borges from the University of the Azores. At the international level, the work involved researchers from the United States, Serbia, Slovenia, Norway, Spain (including the Canary Islands), Croatia and the island of Guam, in the Pacific.

column3:
Extreme heat wave: what to do to avoid risks to the body

Family doctor points out measures that can be taken to minimize the effect of extreme temperatures, but draws attention to the lack of public policies to adapt to climate change. Brazil began the last week of winter facing an extreme heat wave. An atmospheric blockage has prevented the arrival of the cold fronts common for the season and has promised temperatures above 40º C in several regions, mainly in the Central-West and Southeast. The effects of this temperature spike can go beyond mere discomfort. It is possible to develop hyperthermia and heatstroke, which can even cause death – especially among more vulnerable populations, such as children and the elderly. Can you die from the heat? Doctor explains

In an interview with Natuza Nery, family and community doctor Mayara Floss explains that measures can be taken to minimize the effect of extreme temperatures, and also draws attention to the lack of public policies to adapt to climate change. "Regions, for example, of favelas, regions that have few trees – where there are vast monocultures... These demographic factors put these populations at risk," he says. To mitigate the effects of heat on a daily basis, Mayara mentions measures such as: carrying a lighter change of clothes to use on public transport during rush hour; placing a bottle of ice-cold water to cool areas of the body, such as the armpits; if possible, prioritise working hours early in the morning, avoiding times of greatest temperature rises; keeping the house more ventilated during the night and more closed during the day.

column3:
Environmental Crisis in the Pantanal: Drought and deforestation devastate the Biome

The Pantanal, one of the largest wetlands on the planet, is facing an unprecedented environmental crisis. The combination of deforestation and prolonged droughts has led to an alarming reduction in the water surface, affecting not only local biodiversity, but also the communities that depend on these natural resources. A recent study by the MapBiomas platform highlights that, in the current century, almost every year there has been a decrease in the water surface in Brazil, with the Pantanal and Cerrado being the most affected biomes. Experts warn of the risk of severe drought and a possible water collapse, a direct consequence of the neglect of springs and riverside forests, essential for the percolation of rain into the land and for maintaining the flow of rivers. Deforestation in the Amazon, which affects rainfall formation through evapotranspiration, also contributes significantly to drought in the Pantanal, creating ideal conditions for the spread of devastating fires. These fires, in turn, further compromise soil structure and reduce the amount of water available in the water table. The situation is aggravated by the fact that the Pantanal has lost 29% of its water surface, and 57% of its territory has been burned at least once in the last 36 years. This loss not only signals a decline in the health of the biome, but also reflects the profound climate changes that are occurring on a global level. The low water of the Paraguay River, which records levels close to historic lows, is yet another indicator of the seriousness of the situation. The impact of these changes goes beyond environmental degradation, also affecting the economy and society, with damages that overlap and amplify the challenges faced by the region. It is imperative that measures are taken to mitigate these effects and protect the Pantanal for future generations. Raising awareness about the importance of ecosystem services provided by biomes such as the Pantanal and the Amazon is a crucial step in this process. The preservation of these ecosystems is not just a matter of nature conservation, but a necessity for the sustainability of our own way of life. Henrique Cortez, environmental journalist, editor of Portal EcoDebate

column3:
‘The emergency in the Amazon belongs to everyone’, says Cacique Raoni

His home is in a village in Mato Grosso, in the heart of the Brazilian Amazon. But for a while, your stage is the whole world. Wherever he is invited, he goes, because indigenous leader Raoni Metuktire, now 93 years old, dedicated his life not only to defending the Amazon rainforest, but to warn that, faced with the climate disasters of our time, “nothing can be saved alone.” . This led him, a year ago, to walk the red carpet at the Cannes Festival, and last March to Belém, where the French president, Emmanuel Macron, accompanied by his Brazilian colleague, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, presented him with the insignia of the Legion of Honor. And now a new opportunity has been offered to him by Pope Francis, who wanted him among the protagonists of the international summit “From the climate crisis to climate resistance”, which was held at Casina Pio VI, in Vatican City. Evoking the meeting he had with the Pontiff, Raoni told ANSA: “I asked him to make it clear to the Catholics who follow him in Brazil what the Church's orientation is on environmental issues, because sometimes they seem not to have understood the message”. Speaking in the language of the Mebengokre indigenous people, Raoni highlighted that “a void is being progressively created around our lands in the Amazon and there is nothing truly protected anymore”. “We live almost on islands and, as if that were not enough, there are people who are not satisfied, who want to attack even the reserves where we live, putting our survival at risk.” “What is happening? ", he asked, adding that he is "worried because people living in the developed world do not understand that this is a problem for us, but also for them". According to the chief, now in Brazil, "we are facing a 'monster' with two heads: on the one hand, the serious drought phenomena in the north of the country, where fires are multiplying, and, on the other, the tragedy of floods, such as the one that recently occurred in the south of Brazil". Focusing on indigenous lands, Raoni recalled that, "when Lula became president, he promised me that he would clearly demarcate them". "I am still waiting for that to happen. Of course, we have better relations with his government than when Jair Bolsonaro was in power. But right now for us there are many words, but few actions". Addressing the large group of experts who listened to him and who at the end of the presentation gave him a standing ovation at the summit, Raoni argued that "the developed world seems convinced of the urgency of the fight against climate change". “But now we need to decide to immediately finance the tools to start the necessary projects, before it is too late. It is useless to remember that we do not normally use money in our reserves. Money, in large quantities, is used in the developed world”, he stated, guaranteeing that “the time has come to use [the money] to save life on the planet”.

column3:
Nostradamus’ Prophecies for 2024: King Charles’s Drama, War and Tsunami

Renowned French philosopher Nostradamus’s prophecies for 2024 have been revealed, bringing with them worrying news about what the coming year could hold for the world. Nostradamus, whose accurate predictions have included historical events such as the rise of Adolf Hitler and the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, released his visions of the future in the book Les Prophéties more than 450 years ago. His words have been seen as a ‘warning’ of what is to come. One of the most alarming predictions suggests that King Charles could face difficult times in 2024. Although the text does not mention a specific king, it is speculated that it refers to the current leader of the British monarchy. Analysts have interpreted Nostradamus’ words as a possible abdication scenario due to persistent attacks on the king and his second wife, Queen Camilla. In another intriguing prediction, Nostradamus foresees an imminent naval conflict, indicating that a “red enemy” will turn pale with fear, putting the ocean in a state of apprehension. Many believe this red enemy is communist China, suggesting a possible confrontation in the Indian Ocean. In addition, Nostradamus warns of disasters related to climate change. He predicts that the Earth will become increasingly arid, resulting in floods and rising sea levels as ice caps melt. The mystic warns of a possible famine due to the pestilential waves, indicating the possibility of a tsunami that would threaten crops. The future of the Catholic Church: election of a new Pope

Nostradamus also makes a prediction related to the Catholic Church, suggesting that Pope Francis could die in 2024. Turning 88 in December, the Pope could be replaced by an “elderly Roman” after his death. Although there are several potential candidates, the choice will be made between cardinals under the age of 80. Nostradamus’s dark predictions for 2024 have the world on alert, prompting reflections on the uncertain future that awaits us. While some remain skeptical, the accuracy of the philosopher’s previous predictions increases global apprehension about what is to come.

column3:
Observing plankton: why is it so important for predicting the next mass extinction? What if we closely observed the movements of plankton in the oceans? No, this is not a far-fetched suggestion to occupy your afternoons, but rather a very serious study with surprising results carried out by a team of researchers from the Universities of Bristol (United Kingdom), Harvard, Texas (USA) and Victoria (Australia). , published in the journal Nature. What happened 53 million years ago? These scientists discovered that, around 50 million years ago (more precisely between 53 and 49 million years ago), almost all marine plankton, that is, all aquatic plants and animals that are drifting with the currents, moved to the highest latitudes, between the Antarctic Circle and the South Pole. This surprising change preceded by several million years a mass extinction of marine species in the ocean. What is even more worrying is that during this Eocene period, between 53 and 49 million years ago, there was a "climatic optimum", that is, a period of "persistently high" global temperatures that is curiously reminiscent of today. Climatologists are inevitably very concerned, since this "Eocene climate optimum" is close to the most pessimistic global warming scenarios currently being studied. It is clear that plankton must be subject to close scrutiny at this time, as the slightest change could mean the same disastrous scenario as in the Eocene, with a mass extinction of species. An "early warning system"

Of course, the study authors explain that the past is never a mirror of the future and that it is only a correlation between the movement of plankton and the disappearance of species, and is in no way a causal relationship. However, they believe the plankton could act as a warning before a supposed wave of extinctions of larger marine species. Study co-author Dr. Adam Woodhouse (Bristol), however, describes the result as "exciting", adding that observation of plankton could constitute an "early warning system" to predict the extinction of life in the oceans. In fact, by applying their computer model to the files, his team revealed that since the disappearance of the dinosaurs, changes in plankton have often preceded the extinction of certain organisms.

column3:
Perito Moreno Glacier asks for help

The majestic Perito Moreno Glacier, one of the icons of the Argentine Patagonia landscape, is sending a warning signal to the world. Located in Los Glaciares National Park, this ice giant, with its impressive 250 square kilometers in area and an average of 60 meters in height, is more than a natural wonder. It is a testament to the power of nature and, more recently, the urgent need for collective action for the environment. Declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1981, the glacier is part of the third largest body of continental ice on the planet, second only to Antarctica and Greenland. In other words, its grandeur and beauty act as an unmistakable reminder of indomitable nature. However, researchers at the Argentine Institute of Nivology and Glaciology have been observing the signs of imminent changes with increasing concern. A group of experts has dedicated themselves to studying the effects of climate change on the Perito Moreno Glacier. And, according to the results, since 2021, the glacier has retreated by around 700 meters on the north bank of the Los Témpanos Channel. This retreat surprised the scientific community, since, until then, the glacier went against regional trends by exhibiting stability, with little evidence of melting or significant retreat. Influence of climate change

The explanation for this setback lies in the climate changes that have been occurring on the planet. Rising temperatures resulted in accelerated melting of the glacier and the detachment of ice blocks. Furthermore, the lack of precipitation resulting in snow accumulation also plays a crucial role in this scenario, among other issues. Such a scenario not only affects the delicate balance of the region's ecosystem, but also directly impacts tourism in the area. The hiking experience to the Perito Moreno Glacier has already been affected, and the trekking route must be readjusted due to changes in the glacier's geography. It is in this context that Patagonia Experience Travel, an agency specialized in travel in the Patagonian region, highlights the importance of embracing sustainable tourism as a way of uniting human beings in favor of mitigating the effects of climate change. The agency's CEO, Jefferson Gonzalez, who has served as ambassador for the Patagonian region in Brazil for 13 years, highlights that it is essential to make people aware of the consequences of climate change so that this natural wonder is preserved for future generations. “We need to join forces to combat climate change, ensuring that, in a few decades, we will still have the privilege of contemplating these glacial formations,” says Gonzalez.

column3:
Former leader of neo-Nazi skinheads says Portuguese communists become “legitimate targets” if their children are called to war

Mário Machado, well-known former leader of neo-Nazi skinheads in Portugal, sentenced to prison terms for various crimes, said on social media that if Poland invokes NATO art°5 and his 3 sons of military age are called into “war ”, all communists in Portugal become legitimate targets. Which is still a contradiction because the Portuguese communist party, unlike the parliamentary majority, is against Portugal's integration into NATO, and United Russia, Vladimir Putin's party, has an absolute majority in the Federal Duma (325 seats), is a nationalist, conservative, populist party, affiliated with the Centrist Democratic International, an opponent of the Russian communist party, which has only 57 seats. André Ventura's supporter was based on the news that Russia had hit Poland with 2 missiles, news already denied by Poland, which ultimately attributes the “unfortunate accident” to Ukraine. Although Russia has not been communist for many years, and although there are several arrivals who are also on Putin's side, as the municipal deputy of Chega in Cascais, Maria Vieira, says, Mário Machado turns the targets towards the Portuguese communists: 

Russia hit Poland with 2 missiles, killing 2 people. If Poland invokes NATO art°5, and 3 of my military-age sons are called up, all communists in Portugal become legitimate targets. Article 5 of the North Atlantic Treaty:  

The Parties agree that an armed attack against one or more of them in Europe or North America will be considered an attack on all, and, accordingly, they agree that, if such an armed attack occurs, each, in the exercise of the right of self-defense, individual or collective, recognized by article 51 of the Charter of the United Nations, shall provide assistance to the Party or Parties so attacked, taking without delay, individually and in agreement with the other Parties, such action as it deems necessary, including the use of armed force, to restore and ensure security in the North Atlantic region. Any armed attack of this nature and all measures taken as a result of such an attack will be immediately reported to the Security Council. These arrangements will end as soon as the Security Council has taken the necessary measures to restore and maintain international peace and security.

column3:
More than 200 civilians killed in Russia's Belgorod region since invasion

"More than 1,100 civilians were injured and more than 200 people were killed," Viacheslav Gladkov told the Russian news agency TASS about the casualties caused by Ukrainian drone and artillery strikes on the region. The Belgorod region shares a 540-kilometer border with Ukraine and is the Russian Federation entity most affected by Ukrainian military actions. According to data from local authorities provided last April, more than 120 civilians had been killed in the region as a result of Ukrainian attacks since the beginning of the war. In recent weeks, attacks on this Russian region, which borders the Ukrainian provinces of Sumy, Kharkiv and Lugansk from west to south, the latter of which was annexed by Russia in September 2022, have intensified. The Russian military offensive on Ukrainian territory, launched on 24 February 2022, has plunged Europe into what is considered the most serious security crisis since the Second World War (1939-1945). Ukraine has been relying on financial and weapons aid from its Western allies, who have also imposed sanctions on key sectors of the Russian economy in an attempt to reduce Moscow's ability to finance the war effort. Recent months have been marked by large-scale Russian airstrikes against Ukrainian cities and infrastructure, while Kiev's forces have targeted targets in Russian territory near the border and on the Crimean peninsula, illegally annexed in 2014. Now in the third year of war, the Ukrainian armed forces have been struggling with a shortage of soldiers and weapons and ammunition, despite repeated promises of help from Western allies, which have now begun to materialize.

column3:
Moscow responds to Zelensky's statements on negotiations with Russia

Russian President's spokesman Dmitry Peskov said Ukraine should take into account the drastic changes in the country's borders since the start of the special military operation in the peace negotiations. Increasingly abandoned by the West, the country has accumulated significant losses in recent months. Earlier this week, Ukrainian President Vladimir Zelensky said in an interview with CBS News that returning to the 1991 borders was no longer a prerequisite for negotiations with Russia. However, the Ukrainian still insisted that Kiev should regain the territory lost to Moscow by 2022. That year, four former Ukrainian regions — Donetsk, Lugansk, Kherson and Zaporozhye — voted overwhelmingly to join Russia in a public referendum. The population followed suit in the Crimean peninsula, which did the same in 2014. After the 2022 referendums, Zelensky banned all talks with the current Russian leadership, focusing instead on a formula for ending the conflict that requires a complete withdrawal of Moscow’s forces from all of the aforementioned territories. While Russia claims to be open to talks with Kiev, it has dismissed Zelensky’s idea as “detached from reality.” Regarding Zelensky's statements, Peskov told Sputnik on Saturday (30) that "the geopolitical reality has changed dramatically since the beginning of the special military operation. The borders of both Ukraine and the Russian Federation have changed." The spokesman also commented that Russia has already incorporated the four former Ukrainian regions, stressing that this reality "cannot be ignored." Meanwhile, the official representative of the Russian Foreign Ministry, Maria Zakharova, said that Zelensky's change of position is due to the fact that he is "nervous." "He has an election coming up. Or is there no election?" she asked. The Ukrainian president has previously indicated that he has no plans to authorize a vote, citing martial law, which has drawn criticism both at home and abroad. Zelensky’s remarks followed a statement by Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmitry Kuleba, who said Kiev could engage with Moscow at some point after a summit in Switzerland later this year that is widely expected to revolve around Zelensky’s peace formula. Russia has said it does not plan to attend the event, even if it is officially invited.

column3:
Airbus says global fleet could reach 48,230 planes in the next 20 years

Company says demand will be driven by wide-body planes

Airbus revised upwards, this Monday, its demand forecast for aircraft for the next 20 years, according to Reuters. According to the agency, which cites an annual report on industry trends, the global fleet could reach 48,230 planes in the next 20 years, meaning it could more than double. According to the document, the world's largest aircraft manufacturer predicted the delivery of 42,430 new planes over the next 20 years, including 41,490 passenger planes, with a 4% increase in both figures since the previous study. The report comes at a time when the aircraft maker's long-range, single-aisle A321XLR is expected to achieve certification in the coming days. Boeing - which has been involved in several controversies in recent times - is developing a long-range version of the 737 MAX. Airbus' forecasts are based, according to Reuters, on economic forecasts that suggest that 1.7 billion people will enter the middle class, with some disposable income to travel by plane, in the next 20 years. "We foresee particularly strong growth in Asia and the Middle East, led mainly by India and China. China’s domestic traffic will overtake that of the United States,” said Bob Lange, head of market analysis and forecasting at Airbus. The Airbus data highlighted the shift in focus to India, with three of the fastest-growing traffic flows serving the Indian subcontinent. However, aviation’s post-pandemic growth forecasts have put the industry at odds with environmental groups who question its record on tackling climate change. Airbus argues that delivering new planes would help cut emissions as greener fuels are being developed.

column3:
Analyst: Western elite used Ukraine as 'guinea pig for human testing' after 2014 coup

When carrying out human trials, big pharmaceutical companies did not think twice about using hospitals in certain developing countries, without "strict controls" for such actions, William Jones, former White House correspondent and non-resident fellow at the Institute, told Sputnik Chongyang for Financial Studies. Recently, Sputnik obtained a series of documents indicating that rheumatological drugs were allegedly tested for several years on psychiatric patients in a hospital in the city of Mariupol, at the request of large Western pharmaceutical companies and with the assistance of Ukrainian authorities. The documents contain information belonging to companies such as Pfizer, AstraZeneca, Celltrion, Novatris International AG, Merck KGaA and a subsidiary of Samsung that produces medical equipment. The tests were carried out while the Kiev government held Mariupol, until May 2022, when Russia took control of the city. Patients in the psychiatric ward of Mariupol hospital № 7 were likely used as vulnerable "guinea pigs" in experiments that would not have been allowed in the countries where these pharmaceutical companies are located, said William Jones, former White House correspondent for Executive Intelligence Review and non-resident fellow at Chongyang Institute of Financial Studies, Renmin University of China, told Sputnik. "In general, it has been the practice to use some of the developing countries that don't have as tight controls for this type of experiment," Jones noted, alluding to Ukraine. After the Maidan coup in Kiev in 2014, the country "effectively became a 'guinea pig' for whatever experiments the forces of Western elites had in store for them, as we see most dramatically in the way the 'nation' of Ukraine is being reduced to nothing because of NATO's proxy war against Russia", according to the expert. He also addressed the issue of "the extensive network of biological laboratories that have been created in Ukraine over the 20 years, largely with the help, and no doubt at the request, of the United States", something that Jones recalled was repeatedly pointed out by the Lieutenant General Igor Kirillov, head of the Radiological, Chemical and Biological Defense Troops of the Russian Ministry of Defense. "Given the current situation in Ukraine, with the growing realization that Ukraine — or NATO — cannot 'win' this conflict using conventional weapons, as well as NATO's determination not to accept a peaceful resolution unless Russia is defeated, could very well lead to NATO using some form of biological warfare to 'level the playing field,'" warned Jones. In the spring of 2022, Russia's Radiological, Chemical and Biological Defense Troops brought light to the alarming scope of US biomilitary activities taking place in several locations in Ukraine. These investigations revealed collaboration between Washington and Kiev in the investigation and treatment of several highly dangerous pathogens. Several of these findings were later independently corroborated.

column3:
Russia 'has been successful' in combating US hegemony in Latin America, analyst says

Russia's soft power in combating US hegemony in Latin America "has been successful," historian and international analyst Daniel Trujillo Sanz told Sputnik when commenting on Russian President Vladimir Putin's annual message. In his annual message to the Federal Assembly on Thursday (29), Putin advocated strengthening relations with Latin American countries. He added that it is important for Russia to seek new points of convergence and deepen the full range of partnerships, especially with its Arab and South American counterparts. Regarding the president's speech, Sanz said that "we saw a sober, concise and direct speech from President Putin, as always, clearly structured." The analyst drew a parallel between the words of the Russian head of state and those of Western leaders, "whose criteria seem to change every day." "We can take [French President Emmanuel] Macron as an example. One day he leads a rebellion against NATO [the North Atlantic Treaty Organization], the next day he proposes sending French forces to Ukraine and practically triggering a war," he stressed. The analyst also gave other examples of Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, with the entry of Finland and Sweden into NATO. He also drew attention to Germany's attitude "towards the terrible and very serious sabotage of its national interests with the Nord Stream explosion". Still on Latin America, Sanz added that it is necessary to admit that the United States "continues to have hegemony or at least primacy in this regard". "Culture, music, lifestyle and clothing have been clearly established during the era of globalisation and, in this regard, Russia has to overcome decades of influence, especially in Latin America and other parts of the world. I consider it absolutely necessary for Russia to start joining this fight, despite the difficulties it will face." On 29 February, Vladimir Putin delivered his annual message to the Federal Assembly. The president took stock of the country's situation and outlined the main lines of action in domestic and foreign policy for the next six years.

column3:
US and NATO have no interest in a fair resolution to the crisis in Ukraine, says Moscow

For the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) and the United States are focused on an escalation of the crisis in Ukraine, which creates strategic risks and could even lead to a confrontation between nuclear powers. "The United States and NATO do not show the slightest interest in a fair resolution of the current conflict. They are clearly not willing to consider Russian concerns and to work seriously on eliminating fundamental contradictions," said a statement from the ministry. The special military operation will complete two years in February, amid constant Ukrainian defeats and the insistence of Vladimir Zelensky's regime on continuing the fighting at any cost to the country. "The West is focused on the escalation of the Ukrainian crisis, which now represents the main strategic risks, as such a course could lead to a direct confrontation between nuclear powers with catastrophic consequences," the ministry added. Moscow added that "the destructive policy of the United States has led to a deep deterioration of Russian-American relations and a radical change in the security situation." In addition, Russia has repeatedly indicated its readiness to negotiate, while Kiev refuses to engage in dialogue. Earlier, Moscow stated that there were no preconditions for the situation in Ukraine to move towards a peaceful solution, and that the priority goal was to achieve the goals of the special operation, which are currently only possible militarily. More than 600,000 people are in the combat zone

More than 600,000 Russian servicemen are in the combat zone, Russian President Vladimir Putin said on Friday. "As for the decision to launch the special military operation, […] there were no other considerations other than one — defending Russia's interests. None at all. And there can be and have been no other motives when approaching issues of this kind," Putin said. He noted that Russia had previously tried in every possible way to build relations with Ukraine.

column3:
EU transfers part of profits on frozen Russian assets to support Ukraine

This Friday (26), the European Union transferred around 1.5 billion euros in support to Ukraine, coming from profits generated by Russian assets frozen in the bloc. EU countries reached an agreement in May to use billions of euros generated by these assets to arm Ukraine and finance its post-war reconstruction. The EU has frozen around 200 billion euros of Russian Central Bank assets held in the bloc as part of sanctions imposed on Russia over its invasion of Ukraine in 2022. Around 90% of these funds are under the control of financial services company Euroclear, based in Belgium. "The EU supports Ukraine. Today we transferred 1.5 billion euros of Russian assets mobilized for the defense and reconstruction of Ukraine," European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen said in a statement. The bloc announced that 90% of the profits would go to a fund used to buy weapons for Kiev, known as the European Peace Support Mechanism. The other 10% would go to the EU fund to support the reconstruction of Ukraine. Russia classified the measure as "illegal". "This is a reason to take measures in response to illegal decisions like this, which are implemented by the European Union," Dmitri Peskov, spokesman for Russian President Vladimir Putin, told reporters. The Ukrainian Prime Minister, Denys Shymgal, thanked the support. "Thank you, Von der Leyen and the EU, for your firm support and this important contribution to the defense and reconstruction of Ukraine", he posted on his social networks.

column3:
Little hope for justice on 10th anniversary of MH17 crash in Ukraine

Ten years after the downing of MH17 over Ukraine, the families of the victims have little hope of seeing those responsible arrested. Hundreds of relatives of the 298 victims attended a tribute on Wednesday (17) near Amsterdam-Schiphol airport, where the plane took off on July 17, 2014, bound for Kuala Lumpur. Hours later, the Malaysia Airlines Boeing 777 was hit by a Russian-made missile in an area of ​​Ukraine controlled by pro-Russian separatists. All people on board died. During the ceremony, the names of all the victims were read out loud, most from the Netherlands (196), but also many from Malaysia (43) and Australia (38). Dutch courts sentenced three men to life in prison in 2022 for their role in the disaster, including two Russians, but Moscow has refused to extradite any suspects. Last year, international investigators suspended their work after concluding there was insufficient evidence to pursue the suspects involved. "I don't think those responsible will serve their sentences," Evert van Zijtveld, who lost his 19-year-old daughter Frédérique, 18-year-old son Robert-Jan and his in-laws, told AFP. Dutch television broadcast the ceremony live and the national flag flew at half-mast in many municipalities across the country. The Australian government, in a ceremony in Parliament with relatives of the victims, said it would not back down "from its commitment to holding Russia accountable". "I recommit myself to our collective pursuit of truth, justice and accountability for the atrocities committed on 17 July 2014," said Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong. - "Hard to believe" -

The plane crashed in the early stages of the conflict between the Ukrainian government and pro-Russian separatists in the east of the country, during which Moscow took control of the Crimean peninsula. In November 2022, a Dutch court found Russians Igor Guirkin and Sergei Dubinski and Ukrainian Leonid Kharchenko "guilty" of intentional homicide and sentenced them to life in prison. Magistrates found they were responsible for transporting the missile that brought down the plane from a base in Russia to the launch site, although they were not charged with firing it. The three men refused to take part in the Dutch trial, which convicted them in absentia, and denied any responsibility. A fourth suspect, Russian Oleg Pulatov, was acquitted. International investigators concluded there was "strong evidence" that Russian President Vladimir Putin approved the delivery of the missile that brought down the plane. Moscow denies any involvement and has vehemently rejected the court’s 2022 verdict as “political” and “scandalous.” The European Union urged Moscow on Tuesday to “accept its responsibility for this tragedy and to cooperate fully in the service of justice.” Evidence presented during the trial “clearly shows that the BUK surface-to-air missile system used to shoot down flight MH17 undoubtedly belonged to the armed forces of the Russian Federation,” EU foreign minister Josep Borrell said. Moscow has refused to extradite the suspects, saying it would be against its laws. “The invasion of Ukraine and the escalation of the war make it really hard to believe that one of them will be arrested soon,” Evert van Zijtveld said.

column3:
Woman dies from 'paralyzing virus' after being bitten by mosquito in Spain

Granada Romero Ruiz, 86, died after spending 9 days in a hospital in Seville, Spain, after being bitten by a mosquito and contracting the “paralyzing” West Nile virus. The elderly woman's son, Antonio Pineda, stated that she was in perfect health before she was bitten. "She had no underlying health problems, she was healthy, active and had a normal life," he told local media. Tragically, this is not the first time the virus has affected the lives of Granada's family. The woman's husband contracted the virus in 2016. In a statement on that all administrations do everything possible, without saving, against the virus and that there is permanent care against mosquitoes”. New outbreaks of “paralyzing” West Nile virus

The European Center for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) says there have been new outbreaks in parts of Greece and Italy and warns against the deadly virus. “Europe is already seeing how climate change is creating more favorable conditions for invasive mosquitoes to spread to previously unaffected areas and infect more people,” said ECDC Director Andrea Ammon. Who is part of the risk group? According to health professionals, people over 50 years of age and who have illnesses such as diabetes, high blood pressure or cancer are at greater risk of contracting the disease. Which mosquito transmits the “paralyzing” West Nile virus?

The Asian tiger mosquito — known for transmitting a number of diseases, including West Nile — has been detected in the UK on several occasions since 2016. The mosquito, known for black and white stripes along its body and legs, can transmit a number of tropical diseases , including dengue, zika and chikungunya. What are the symptoms of West Nile disease? The symptoms of the disease are similar to those of the flu (such as fever, body aches and headache), rash and feeling unwell. Others may experience muscle weakness, confusion, vision loss, numbness, stiff neck, diarrhea and seizures. What is the treatment for West Nile disease? Treatment usually involves rest, hydration, and over-the-counter pain relievers. Severe cases need to be treated in hospitals, as they can cause meningitis (inflammation of the membranes surrounding the brain and spinal cord) and encephalitis (inflammation of the brain), warn the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).

column3:
NASA says Brazil could become uninhabitable in 50 years; find out

Heat is expected to make human life impossible in at least five regions of the Earth in the next 50 years, including Brazil, according to a study by the US Space Agency (NASA). The research found that rising temperatures combined with high levels of air humidity can cause thermal effects to which the human body would not be able to adapt. The emission of greenhouse gases has a direct impact on nature, with increasingly accelerated and severe climate change across the planet. Rising temperatures make unseasonal heat waves more frequent and winters less intense or shorter than usual. According to NASA, the body's cooling process occurs through perspiration, that is, sweat. Rising temperatures combined with humidity increase the sensation of heat and prevent sweat from evaporating, which keeps the body warm – and can be fatal. The study indicates that temperatures above 37ºC – a mark exceeded in many regions of Brazil during the summer – with air humidity equal to or greater than 70% can cause premature death after up to six hours of exposure. The body can still sweat at temperatures of 45ºC and up to 20% air humidity. However, research projects that with the thermometer at the same brand and a humidity level above 40%, the thermal sensation can exceed 71ºC and be lethal. Although the combination of these factors is considered rare, as hot days are characterized by drier air, the study found that since 2005 the phenomenon has been observed in regions of the Persian Gulf and Pakistan. In this scenario, NASA considered the trend of increasing thermometers in the coming decades, with climate change driven by the emission of greenhouse gases, and concluded that human life may be threatened in areas of the Midwest, North, Northeast and Southeast. Brazilian.

column3:
Impunity marks 10 years since Boeing downing in Ukraine

One of the most important events of the long period of civil war in Ukraine that preceded the Russian invasion of 2022, the downing of a Malaysia Airlines Boeing 777 in the east of the country, completes ten years this Wednesday (17) marked by impunity. "Who fired the missile? Who gave the order?", asked in a video message the president of the foundation for the families of the 298 victims of the incident, the Dutchman Piet Ploeg. He lost his brother, sister-in-law and nephew on the flight. An international investigation, which was able to collect the wreckage of the plane, reached several consensuses. First, that the anti-aircraft missile had been fired from a Soviet-made Buk system. Second, more controversial, that the weapon had been launched from territory controlled by pro-Russian separatists in Donetsk, in eastern Ukraine. In 2022, a Dutch court, the country of birth of 193 of those killed while flying from Amsterdam to Kuala Lumpur (capital of Malaysia), sentenced three people to life imprisonment "in absentia" for more general involvement in the downing: Russians Igor Girkin and Sergei Dubinski, as well as Ukrainian Leonid Khartchenko. All operated with separatist forces in the region and, according to the version of the European country's justice system, had worked to bring, use and then return the Buk to a Russian base in the region across the border. The case was closed in 2023, but the Netherlands filed a complaint against Russia at the European Court of Human Rights, directly accusing President Vladimir Putin of authorising the operation. Separately, the International Civil Aviation Agency is still investigating responsibility, with a view to possible civil proceedings. The Kremlin denies all accusations, saying the trial was a Russophobic farce typical of the turbulent times in Europe. From the beginning of the investigation, the Russians tried to shift the blame to Ukraine. First, they suggested that the missile that shot down the Boeing had been launched by a Kiev fighter jet. Then, they suggested that a Ukrainian anti-aircraft system had been responsible for the tragedy. With ties with the European Union cut off due to the 2022 invasion, the chances of an agreed solution are nil. The then Dutch Prime Minister, Mark Rutte, a harsh critic of Putin, will now be the secretary general of NATO (the Western military alliance). All three convicted men live in Russia and will not be extradited — the most notorious of them, Girkin, fell from grace for criticizing Putin's handling of the war and was sentenced to four years in prison this year for "inciting extremism." For the victims' families, all that remains is doubt. "We will not rest until the truth is revealed," Ploeg said in the video. Over the years, the report has heard versions of what might have happened from people with access to security information in Moscow. The most likely scenario, they say, was an operational error on the part of the separatists, who mistook the Boeing on the Buk's radar for a Ukrainian plane. When news of the plane's downing arrived, the initial reaction was one of shock and particular disbelief, given that Malaysia had lost an identical plane in the mysterious case of flight MH370, which had disappeared four months earlier after taking off from Kuala Lumpur bound for Beijing with 239 people on board — a case that remains unsolved to this day. But the reality on the ground would soon set the tone for the outrage over what had happened. Between late 2013 and early 2014, the pro-Russian government in Kiev faced protests and was overthrown. Putin responded by annexing Crimea and inciting a civil war in the Donbass, a region that includes the Donetsk and Lugansk areas. For Ukrainian filmmaker Marina Er Gorbach, who used the downing of the plane as a backdrop for her award-winning "Klondike" (2023), the episode was the first warning shot about the gravity of the crisis and yet it ended up being ignored in the West. In an interview with Folha last year, she said that the sanctions applied to Moscow in 2014 were too lax, leading to the escalation of the civil war, which killed around 14,000 people, and the full invasion eight years later. The trauma of the unfinished episode has spread throughout the commercial aviation industry. Just access any aircraft traffic monitoring website to see the black hole formed in the region, now enlarged by the war between neighbors.

column3:
Russia and Hungary criticize opening ceremony of the Paris Games

Russia, excluded from the Paris 2024 Olympic Games due to its offensive against Ukraine, said this Saturday (27) that the opening ceremony of the sporting event was a "big failure", while the Prime Minister of Hungary, Viktor Orban, declared that the party reflected the "fragility and disintegration of the West". Russian diplomacy spokeswoman Maria Zakharova highlighted on Telegram what she considered to be flaws in the show, which took place on Friday (26) on the River Seine. "I hadn't planned on seeing the opening. But after seeing the photos, I couldn't believe it wasn't a 'deep fake' or photoshop," he wrote on Telegram. The ceremony was not shown live on Russian television. Zakharova cited, among other points, the "collapse of transport", after the French railway network suffered acts of sabotage, and "spectators sat for hours in heavy rain". "The organizers didn't think about cloud dispersal or awnings," he added, referring to the Russian practice of sending planes ahead of large outdoor events to try to break through the clouds. Zakharova also said that central Paris had been "turned into a ghetto for homeless people" and that "rats had flooded the streets" of the capital. The spokesperson particularly criticised the presence of drag queens at a point during the ceremony, whose performance was reminiscent of the Last Supper of Jesus Christ with his apostles. “In Paris, they decided that if the Olympic rings are multi-coloured, they can turn the whole thing into a giant gay march,” she added. Only 16 Russian athletes accepted the invitation from the International Olympic Committee (IOC) to participate in the event under a neutral flag. In Hungary, Orban said that the spectacle showed the “emptiness” of the West. “They have gradually eliminated metaphysical ties, with God, homeland and family,” said the Hungarian head of government, adding that this has led to “the absence of public morality”. According to Orban, who defends an “illiberal” doctrine, “Western values, which were considered universal for a long time, are increasingly considered unacceptable and rejected by many countries in the world”, such as China, India, Turkey and the Arab countries.
