column3:
Russian Senator: International Court's Verdict Is First Step Towards Truth About Situation in Ukraine

A lawsuit filed by Ukraine in January 2017 made several accusations against Russia, holding it responsible for the attacks in Donetsk and the downing of Boeing MH17. On Wednesday (31), the International Court of Justice (ICJ) found the country not guilty. Following the verdict of the international court linked to the United Nations (UN), Russian Senator from Sevastopol Ekaterina Altabayeva told Sputnik that the decision is only the first step towards the truth about the situation in Ukraine. In a historic decision, the court did not give in to Kiev's demands, which essentially asked for Russia to be recognized as an "aggressor state" and the Donetsk and Lugansk People's Republics (DPR and LPR) as "terrorist organizations". Most of Ukraine's claims against Russia in Crimea under the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination were also rejected, ICJ President Joan Donoghue announced. "In particular, this indicates that the time will come when the Ukrainian government will be assessed. This is the first step, and the assessment of the Ukrainian regime and the investigation of the crimes of certain politicians, members of terrorist organizations such as 'Azov' in Ukraine will take place; I am sure that this will happen in the foreseeable future. The senator also stressed that the court’s decisions “put Ukraine in its place.” “I believe this is an important signal to the international community; it says that it is necessary to objectively assess what is happening in Ukraine,” she added. Kiev’s accusations The case, initiated by Kiev in January 2017, addressed several issues, one of which was Russia’s responsibility for the downing of the Boeing MH17 plane. However, the court rejected this demand, finding Russia not guilty of the incident. In addition, the court did not support Ukraine’s arguments about Russia’s alleged involvement and the responsibility of the Donetsk militias in several attacks, including the shelling of the Bugas military checkpoint near Volnovakha; the military airfield in Kramatorsk; and the positions of the Ukrainian Armed Forces in Mariupol and Avdeevka, which occurred in the period from 2014 to 2017. Regarding the charges of financing terrorism, the court indicated that Russia fulfilled its obligations to cooperate, including identifying and blocking funds used to finance terrorism.

column3:
Pentagon claims economic prosperity from arming Ukraine: 'A boon to our economy'

Workers from Texas to Ohio are benefiting from Washington's push to supply weapons to Kiev, Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin said. The conflict in Ukraine is "a boon to the U.S. economy" as it has created more jobs in the U.S. military-industrial sector, Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin said. Speaking at a White House Competition Council meeting on Tuesday (5), the Pentagon chief promised that Washington would continue to push for a stronger defense industry, especially in light of the Ukraine-Russia conflict. Austin said U.S. military assistance to Kiev has not only "saved lives" and kept Ukraine in the fight, but has also strengthened the U.S. economy. "These investments have expanded facilities and created jobs for American workers. And the weapons we send to Ukraine to help defend itself are made in the United States by American workers all across the country — from Texas to Ohio to Arizona," the official added. The conflict in Ukraine has also highlighted the need to improve military production, according to Austin, who emphasized coordination with Washington's allies. He also urged US lawmakers to adopt a national security package that would provide $60 billion (about €55 billion) to Kyiv. The bill remains stalled in Congress due to opposition from Republicans, who have demanded that the White House address the security crisis on the border with Mexico. The US has been Ukraine’s main military backer, providing Kyiv with about $45 billion (about R$223.1 billion) in weapons between January 2022 and January 2024, while total commitments have reached more than $70 billion (about €64 billion), according to the Kiel Institute for the World Economy. Reports suggest that US pressure to arm Ukraine has put significant strain on the country’s own arsenals. While officials in President Joe Biden’s administration have maintained that most of the funding for Ukraine is being spent within the United States, some Republicans have criticized the White House for allocating taxpayer dollars to foreign countries rather than directly addressing domestic problems. According to a December poll by the Pew Research Center, 31% of Americans believe the United States is providing too much support to Ukraine, while 29% say the current level of assistance is about right. Russia has repeatedly denounced Western arms shipments to Ukraine, warning that they will only prolong the conflict. Russian Foreign Ministry official Maria Zakharova said in December that the US would likely continue to fuel the conflict in Ukraine into 2024 as long as it could withdraw funds from American taxpayers.

column3: What were the consequences of Russia's Iskander strike on Patriots in Ukraine? The attack on a convoy of Ukrainian military equipment in the Donetsk People's Republic was carried out using short-range ballistic missiles. Crews of Patriot air defense systems supplied to Ukraine by the US, previously destroyed by Russian forces, were "almost certainly" eliminated, Forbes magazine reported. The media outlet reported that the "persistence and good fortune" of a Russian drone operator "paid off on Saturday (9) when he located a Ukrainian convoy including at least two truck-mounted quadruple launchers for a Patriot surface-to-air missile battery" in the Donetsk People's Republic (DPR). "The Ukrainians lost up to 13 percent of their Patriot launchers that day," so "the air over eastern Ukraine may have become much safer for the Russians," according to Forbes. The report comes after a source in the security services told Sputnik that two Patriot systems were among the military equipment of Ukrainian troops destroyed by a strike by the Russian Iskander surface-to-surface ballistic missile in the DPR. Data from the Russian Defense Ministry showed that the strike also destroyed an S-300 missile system of Ukrainian troops near the town of Pokrovsky in the DPR. The last time the Russian military struck a Patriot was in late February, when the system’s launcher, tractor, ammunition and transport vehicle were destroyed by high-precision weapons. In May 2023, the Russian Defense Ministry reported that its forces had destroyed a Patriot stationed in Kiev with a Kinzhal hypersonic missile. Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu announced a successful strike on another Patriot two weeks later. Western countries increased their military supplies to Kiev shortly after the start of Russia’s 2022 special military operation. Moscow has repeatedly warned against continuing arms deliveries to Kiev, saying it would lead to a new escalation of the conflict.

column3:
Lavrov: EU recommends Ukraine to invest in long-range weapons to hit 'heart of Russia'

According to Russian data, the European Union (EU) has made recommendations to Ukraine that it is necessary to invest in the supply of long-range weapons to "hit the heart of Russia", Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov said on Friday (16). During his speech at the Euromaidan: Ukraine's Lost Decade conference, Lavrov also said that Western instructors directly help direct Ukrainian troops' strikes at Russian targets, and the West is participating in the war against Russia. "There is no doubt that the West has declared war on us, they do not even hide it. And although they say in every possible way that 'they are just arming Ukraine, and it is fighting for itself', everyone understands that this is a lie. He stressed that "the most important thing in a war is strategies, and strategies are not in Kiev, but far away". "According to our data, the European External Action Service has made recommendations for Ukraine, which assume that the methods by which Ukraine is currently fighting will not be successful and Ukraine will lose. Therefore, it is necessary to focus on transferring weapons of even greater range to Ukraine, so that, as the European Union describes it, they will 'hit the heart of Russia', and thus once again sow confusion and panic and undermine the people's confidence," Lavrov said during his speech. The Russian Foreign Minister noted that the limit of Moscow's "gestures of goodwill" in the context of restoring relations between Russia and the West has been exhausted, Western countries have not reciprocated Russia's "good deeds". After Russian President Vladimir Putin's interview with American journalist Tucker Carlson, it became clear that until now the US society has been living in a complete information blockade, Lavrov noted. Finally, the Russian Foreign Minister said that on the issue of dialogue with Ukraine, the ball is not in Russia's court, first of all, Ukrainian President Vladimir Zelensky must revoke the decree prohibiting negotiations with Moscow. "I repeat once again about the existence of Zelensky's decree prohibiting negotiations with the government of Ukraine. [Russian President Vladimir] Putin. Our president has repeatedly said when the West asked such questions: 'Make him rescind this decree and say so publicly.' The ball is not in our court, everyone understands that," Lavrov said.

column3:
Russia: Ukrainian forces used US chemical weapons during Russian military operation

Cases of the use of US chemical weapons were recorded during the special military operation, the head of the Radiological, Chemical and Biological Defence Forces of the Russian Armed Forces, Igor Kirillov, said on Monday (19). According to him, two facilities in the US still store highly toxic reactive compounds that remained after the destruction of declared stockpiles of American chemical weapons. The US was supposed to complete the destruction of declared stockpiles of chemical weapons in 2007, but did so only in 2023, Kirillov noted in a statement. "The United States still retains highly toxic compounds after the destruction of chemical agents at the facilities in Blue Grass (Kentucky) and Pueblo (Colorado)," the Russian lieutenant general said. According to him, the Armed Forces of Ukraine have repeatedly used toxic substances against Russian soldiers. As an example, Kirillov cited the use, on August 19, 2022, of a toxic chemical that is an analogue of the chemical warfare agent B-Zet included in Annex 2 of the Biological and Chemical Weapons Convention (BWC). All documents at the disposal of the Russian Defense Ministry confirming the facts of violations by the United States and Ukraine of the provisions of the Chemical Weapons Convention have been handed over to the Russian Investigative Committee for making a procedural decision, he said. A similar substance, according to Kirillov, was discovered on January 28, 2024 during an operational search in a cache in the Melitopol region. "The toxic substance was in vials with the inscription Biosporin in Ukrainian." Kirillov noted that Kiev is developing a "special chemical belt" tactic, which involves detonating containers with hydrocyanic acid and ammonia during the advance of the Russian Armed Forces. The Armed Forces of Ukraine use toxic compounds not only in the course of hostilities, but also for carrying out terrorist acts. For example, in August 2022, the head of the Kherson region, Vladimir Saldo, was poisoned with ricin. On December 5, 2023, Leonid Pasechnik, the head of the administration of the Luhansk People's Republic (LPR), was seriously poisoned with phenolic compounds. From September to October 2023, the chemicals were delivered to Kramatorsk and Kupyansk to be placed along roads, the head of the Radiological, Chemical and Biological Defense Troops of the Russian Armed Forces, Igor Kirillov, said.

column3:
Russia threatens to respond to US missiles with nuclear weapons

On yet another day of escalating rhetoric in the crisis between Russia and the West, aggravated by the war in Ukraine, Vladimir Putin's government threatened to deploy new nuclear weapons targeting Europe if the United States follows through on its plan to move long-range missiles to Germany. The spokesperson for this intention was Deputy Foreign Minister Sergei Ryabkov, who is responsible for nuclear negotiations and has taken the lead in the verbal sparring with NATO countries, the Western military alliance. He was deliberately vague in his speech to the Interfax news agency, without saying what this nuclear response would involve. In practice, it is already a given: there is no doubt that Russia has nuclear warheads in the western territory of Kaliningrad, between Lithuania and Poland, that can equip Iskander-M missiles, which from there can reach as far as Berlin. What matters in this case is the tension itself, already high with the succession of threats from both sides. During the NATO summit last week, the US announced that it would deploy Tomahawk cruise missiles, an offensive weapon, and SM-6 missiles, in a theoretical long-range air defence, on German soil from 2026. These weapons had been vetoed by a 1987 agreement between the Americans and the Soviets, which was later abandoned by Donald Trump in 2018. Paradoxically, if the Republican returns to power in this year's elections, the greatest possibility is of an accommodation with Putin. In fact, Russian Foreign Minister Serguei Lavrov praised the choice of Senator J.D. Win for the vice-president spot on the Trumpist ticket. The Republican is against aid to Ukraine in the war and shares Russian admiration for the autocratic Hungarian Prime Minister, Viktor Orbán. The Foreign Ministry spokesperson, Maria Zakharova, was more restrained. "We saw the statements. We need to separate pre-election rhetoric from statements made by authorities with powers. If we are going to talk about the possibility of resolving the conflict, let's be realistic." On another front, the Kremlin criticized the idea floated by the European Union of creating its own defense arm, parallel to NATO. For spokesman Dmitri Peskov, this proves "the militarization of the continent" against Russia. He also stated that his country "views with concern" rumors that Romania and Bulgaria, countries in the alliance that border the Black Sea, may increase the concentration of warships in the region. Turkey is the main NATO member in those waters, but has a stance closer to Moscow. The Russian Foreign Ministry also played this card on Thursday, saying that the US military exercises with Armenia are aimed at destabilising the region as a whole, and are aimed at the Russians, Yerevan’s allies, the Iranians and the Turks – historical rivals of the Armenians. The alliance has already announced that it intends to open a representative office in Kiev in September, before the departure of its long-serving Secretary General, Jens Stoltenberg. The Norwegian will hand over the baton to the Dutchman Mark Rutte after ten years. The implications of this facility being targeted by the Russians are clear. During a visit to a security conference in London, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky once again asked his Western partners for permission to use their long-range weapons against Russian air bases. The request has been denied by the US, which has allowed the use of its weapons against points in border regions involved in offensives against the Ukrainians, but that is all. Last week, President Joe Biden said it would be unthinkable to authorize attacks on cities or the Kremlin. Zelensky has sought to counter fears of escalation, potentially nuclear, by saying that all red lines set by the Russians have been crossed without much retaliation. He has also accused Orbán of treason. Close to Putin, the Hungarian is the current rotating president of the European Union and has used his position to promote what he calls a "peacekeeping mission", having spoken with both the Ukrainian and the Russian presidents and Trump. For Zelensky, this means betraying Kiev and its European allies. On the ground, Ukraine experienced another violent day. In the east of the country, the Russians took another village in their advance in the Donetsk region, and Zelensky's armed forces made a rare admission of retreat to spare their troops. On the other hand, military pressure on the Crimean peninsula, annexed by Putin in 2014 and the crown jewel of his project in the region, remains high. Ukraine said it attacked a Black Sea Fleet base with water and air drones early this morning, damaging facilities. The day before, Kiev had said that the last Russian warship in the fleet had been withdrawn from Crimea, where the military unit has been based since the 18th century. Moscow denied the information, although the vulnerability of its naval forces in the region is clear.

column3:
Russian warships make routine visit to Cuba

Havana residents watched Russian warships arrive for the second time in as many months, in what the Cuban Revolutionary Armed Forces called a routine visit. Cuban officials fired shots in the air in a welcome, while curious fishermen watched from Havana’s promenade as the ships sailed into the bay. Russian residents were among the few who woke up early to watch the fleet arrive. The patrol vessel Neustrahimiy, the training vessel Smolniy, and support vessels — all from the Baltic Fleet — are scheduled to depart on Tuesday. In June, a Russian nuclear submarine, frigate and support vessels flexed Moscow’s muscles in Havana harbor, less than 100 miles from Florida. “Russia’s movements in the Atlantic do not pose any direct threat or concern to the United States,” a spokesman for U.S. Northern Command said, adding that the command monitored all approaches to North America. Tensions between the United States and Russia have risen since Russia’s 2022 invasion of Ukraine, and Russian naval activity — while routine in the Atlantic — has increased due to U.S. support for Ukraine, U.S. officials say. At the same time, relations between Cold War allies Russia and Cuba have improved significantly as the communist-ruled country grapples with an economic crisis that it accuses is mainly due to US sanctions.

column3:
Arrest of Russian 'chef' raises fears of Russian interference in Paris 2024

The recent arrest of a Russian man for alleged "destabilizing" activities against the Paris Games highlights last-minute concerns among organizers that Moscow may try to disrupt the event, which begins next Friday (26). The man, born in 1984, was arrested at his home in Paris this week and is suspected of "espionage with a foreign power to provoke hostilities in France", the prosecutor's office said last Tuesday (23). Le Monde newspaper reported that police found documents "of diplomatic interest" in his apartment, and that he is suspected of working for the Russian security service, the FSB, after appearing on reality TV shows and having worked for a time as a chef in a French ski resort. “We strongly believed that he would organize destabilization, interference, espionage operations,” French Interior Minister Gérald Darmanin told BFMTV on Wednesday (24), pointing to a variety of clues: “It could be cyber attacks that require complicity, it could be information manipulation...”. The individual “is in the hands of justice, which could clarify the police’s suspicions,” explained the minister, commenting that the suspect’s presence on French soil is recent. - Campaign to discredit the Games -

Darmanin recalled that “other Russian individuals” had recently been arrested in the capital, and that the French authorities had been observing a disinformation campaign aimed at discrediting the Paris Olympic Games. The minister recalled a very recent video on social media by an alleged representative of the Palestinian Islamist movement Hamas, threatening France with attacks for hosting Israeli athletes, but which turned out to be fake content. “We believe that this is a fake video spread by accounts that, from what we see, are pro-Kremlin, pro-Russia,” the minister said, denouncing a “multiplicity” of maneuvers that could “cause damage to our country and raise concern.” Almost all Russian athletes were excluded from the Paris Games as a measure of diplomatic retaliation for the Russian invasion of Ukraine, and only fifteen will participate under a neutral flag. Over the weekend, Darmanin revealed that French authorities had rejected a “large number” of requests from Russian citizens to be accredited as journalists to cover the Games, due to suspicions that they might actually be spies. Requests from Russian citizens to volunteer were also denied. Russia has denied involvement in any destabilisation operation against the Paris Games and said the refusal to grant accreditation to Russian reporters “violates press freedom”. In April, French President Emmanuel Macron said he had “no doubt” that Russia was targeting the organisation of the Olympic Games, “including the news sphere”.

column3:
Putin warns US of Cold War-style missile crisis

MOSCOW (Reuters) - Russian President Vladimir Putin warned the United States on Sunday that if Washington deploys long-range missiles in Germany, Russia would position similar missiles within striking distance of the West. The United States said on July 10 it would begin deploying long-range missiles in Germany from 2026, in preparation for a long-term deployment that will include SM-6s, Tomahawk cruise missiles and hypersonic weapons under development. In a speech to sailors from Russia, China, Algeria and India to mark Russian Navy Day in the former imperial capital of St. Petersburg, Putin warned the United States that it risked triggering a Cold War-style missile crisis with the announcement. "The flight time to targets of such missiles on our territory, which in the future could be equipped with nuclear warheads, will be about 10 minutes," Putin said. "We will take mirrored measures, taking into account the actions of the United States, its satellites in Europe and other regions of the world." Putin, who sent his army to Ukraine in 2022, sees the war as part of a historic struggle with the West, which he says humiliated Russia after the fall of the Soviet Union in 1991 by invading what it considers to be Moscow's sphere of influence. Ukraine and the West say Putin is engaged in an imperial-style land grab. They have vowed to defeat Russia, which currently controls about 18 percent of Ukraine, including Crimea, and chunks of four regions in eastern Ukraine. Russia says the lands, once part of the Russian empire, are now back in Russia and will never be returned.

column3:
Media: France tries to convince Baltic countries to send troops to Ukraine

The French government intends to build an alliance with the Baltic nations (Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia) that agree to the proposal to send troops to fight Russia, according to an article published by the US edition of Politico. According to the article published this Saturday (9), the proposal was made by the French Minister of Foreign Affairs, Stéphane Séjourné, during his meeting in Lithuania last Friday (8), with Baltic counterparts and the Ukrainian Minister of Foreign Affairs, Dmitry Kuleba. "It is not up to Russia to organize how we should implement our actions or establish red lines. So we decide that between us", declared the French minister, as reported by Politico. Last week, French President Emmanuel Macron surprised many in Europe by saying that he does not rule out sending ground troops to Ukraine. Despite opposition to Macron's statement from most EU countries, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania are much more open to the idea, the article said. On February 27, Macron said that Western leaders discussed the possibility of sending troops to Ukraine during a conference in Paris, but failed to reach a consensus. On 29 February, Russian President Vladimir Putin warned in his annual address to the Federal Assembly, the country's parliament, of the tragic consequences if this decision were to be implemented. Since 24 February 2022, Russia has been continuing a special military operation aimed at defending the Donetsk People's Republics (DPR) and Lugansk People's Republics (LPR), previously recognised by Moscow as sovereign states, against the genocide committed by Kiev, while addressing the risks to its national security posed by the advance of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) in Eastern Europe. Moscow has repeatedly warned that NATO is "playing with fire" by supplying weapons to Ukraine and that foreign arms shipments would be a "legitimate target" for Russia once they crossed the border. In the words of Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov, Russia sees direct clashes between Russia and NATO as inevitable if the West sends its troops to Ukraine.

column3:
Senator on Sweden in NATO: Russia will respond by increasing its military presence in the West

After the protocol of Sweden's accession to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) came into force this Thursday (7), with the inclusion of the European country, the military alliance led by the United States now has 32 members. The group's advance was one of the reasons that led to the special military operation in Ukraine. The measure has already provoked reactions from Russia, such as that of the senator from Kaliningrad, Aleksandr Shenderyuk-Zhidkov. In an interview with Sputnik, the parliamentarian stressed that the country will be forced to respond to the advance of the Western alliance, which has increasingly threatened international stability. "Sweden's entry into NATO, of course, cannot but cause concern. Sweden has a very significant military force on the continent, and its neutrality for many years has ensured a balance of power both in the Baltic Sea and in Europe as a whole," said the politician. With this, the senator points out, Russia will not remain inactive and "will be forced to respond to NATO's aggressive advance by reinforcing its Western military presence". "Our country has guaranteed the safety of navigation in the Baltic Sea for many centuries and will not allow its unilateral militarization", the senator noted. Conflict between Russia and NATO

In recent weeks, statements have been made about a possible direct armed conflict between NATO and Russia, with the alliance's involvement in the fighting in Ukraine. In addition, Moscow has been warning for years about the organization's unprecedented increase in activity on its western borders and that this will not be ignored. Under the pretext of "containing Russian aggression", the country has repeatedly expressed its concern about the alliance's increase in forces in Europe. The Russian Foreign Ministry has stated that Moscow remains open to dialogue with NATO, but on equal terms, while the West should abandon the militarization of the continent. President Vladimir Putin, in an interview with American journalist Tucker Carlson, explained in detail that Moscow has no intention of attacking NATO countries. Putin added that Western countries have begun to realize that Russia's strategic defeat in the conflict with Ukraine is impossible, so they should think about their next steps, and Russia is ready for dialogue.

column3:
US sabotage of Nord Stream could completely destroy NATO, expert says

An investigative journalist has assessed the situation surrounding the Russian gas pipelines, whose investigation has already been abandoned by Sweden and Denmark, a move he sees as an attempt to hide the truth. On Monday (26), Denmark became the second European country to officially close its investigation into the explosion in the Nord Stream 1 and Nord Stream 2 gas pipelines. Nord Stream has played a crucial role in supplying German industry and providing low-cost energy across Europe. Observers immediately blamed the United States for the event, which took place in September 2022, highlighting US President Joe Biden's enigmatic promise to "put an end" to the project if Russia deployed its troops in Ukraine in response to the oppression of the Russian-speaking population of Donbass. Denmark's inquiry found that the explosions were an act of "deliberate sabotage," but authorities refused to investigate who was responsible. Earlier this month, Sweden closed its own investigation. "It's an absolute farce," investigative journalist Dan Lazare said Wednesday (28). "I don't know how much longer this can go on. I mean, Denmark investigated, came to a conclusion, and everyone knows it was obviously sabotage — that was obvious from the beginning. And [Denmark] refrains from pointing the finger at a likely culprit." He said he is 100% convinced that "the United States" is to blame and that "Denmark, Sweden, everyone is afraid to say that. It's extraordinary." Lazare sees the situation benefiting far-right parties across the continent, such as the Alternative for Germany (AfD, in its German acronym), which are the only ones willing to openly recognize the US role in the act. " So , if the AfD is rising in the polls, they have Joe Biden to thank, because Joe Biden blew up the gas pipeline, and everyone is afraid to admit it", concluded Lazare, also citing Donald Trump in the USA, Marine Le Pen in France, Geert Wilders in the Netherlands and Giorgia Meloni in Italy. "The center is destroying itself and is practically now introducing the far right to take its place," he said, predicting that the establishment's lawmakers "will pay a terrible, terrible price for covering this up [ the Nord Stream sabotage]". At the same time, he points out, "the political consequences would have been dire" if leaders publicly acknowledged US responsibility for the Nord Stream sabotage. "When people admit what happened, NATO [the North Atlantic Treaty Organization] will basically go up in smoke, because an alliance is not a scheme for one member to attack another," he said. "It is a mutual defense pact, and the US violated it on a massive scale. This [sabotage] of Nord Stream is an event that will have repercussions for decades. It is an explosion at the heart of the Western alliance — it will completely destroy the Western alliance. There is no way NATO can survive this blow when it becomes too big to ignore," Lazare said.

column3:
Beijing blames NATO escalation for Ukraine conflict, Chinese defense chief pledges support to Russia

China's defense minister says cooperation between Moscow and Beijing is a cornerstone for maintaining world peace and praised Russia's stance on Taiwan. In his first public appearance since being appointed defense minister late last year, Dong Jun told his Russian counterpart Sergei Shoigu that strategic cooperation between China and Russia is a cornerstone for maintaining world peace. During a video call meeting, the officials agreed that China and Russia should deepen their cooperation and respond decisively to global challenges. "We support them on the Ukraine issue, despite the US and the European Union continuing to pressure the Chinese side," Dong said, promising that Beijing "will not change or abandon our established political course on this issue" even under the threat of more sanctions. At the same time, according to the Chinese minister, China sees the "strong support from the Russian side on the Taiwan issue, as well as on other issues of our core interests," he added. "As two of the most important and fundamental forces in the world, we must respond decisively to global challenges," he reiterated. Dong also criticized the United States' attempt to maintain its hegemony by targeting Russia and China. "History and reality prove that hegemony is doomed to failure." The Russian minister said that, unlike Western states, Russia and China are not "creating military blocs" and military cooperation between the two is not "directed against third countries." Shoigu noted that "Russian-Chinese relations in the military sphere are developing steadily in all areas" and said he was looking forward to "close and productive cooperation" with his Chinese counterpart. China's stance on the Russia-Ukraine conflict has created tensions between the Asian country and the United States. US officials accuse Beijing of supporting Moscow instead of demonstrating neutrality. China, in turn, blames the expansion of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) in Europe for the Ukraine crisis and denounced the use of unilateral sanctions by the United States and its allies as a tool of geopolitical pressure.

column3:
UN launches new guidance to tackle extreme wildfires

The document "Voluntary guidance for integrated fire management: principles and strategic actions" updates two-decade-old guidance from this UN (United Nations) agency and includes new recommendations "to address the challenges arising from the current climate crisis", the organization said in a statement. By the end of the century, extreme wildfires are expected to become around 50% more frequent and environmental changes linked to climate change, such as more frequent droughts, high temperatures and strong winds, "will likely result in hotter, drier and longer fire seasons". According to the FAO, around 340 million to 370 million hectares of the Earth's surface are burned annually by wildfires, with damage to sustainable development and the livelihoods of communities and generating large volumes of greenhouse gas emissions. "How we respond to the challenge of forest fires is critical (...). We must shift our focus from reactive responses to proactive strategies and prioritize prevention and preparedness," said FAO Forestry Division Director Zhimin Wu, who launched the new edition of the guide during the 9th World Forest Week, taking place in Rome. The launch of the updated guidelines is "the debut activity" of the Global Fire Management Center, created in 2023 by FAO and the United Nations Environment Program (UNEP), with support from the United States, Canada, France, Germany and Portugal, as well as the Republic of Korea. The center announced that it has already received funding worth almost five million dollars (4.6 million euros), "essential support for its mission to reduce the adverse effects of forest fires on society, landscapes and the climate".

column3:
Foreign Ministers of China and Russia Meet on the Sidelines of Ministerial Meeting in Laos

The foreign ministers of Russia and China met on Thursday (25) and discussed the construction of "a new security architecture", Moscow reported, after the meeting that took place on the sidelines of the meeting of ministers of the National Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), in Laos. At the meeting, Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov and his Chinese counterpart, Wang Yi, discussed in "detail" issues of cooperation within the framework of ASEAN, the Russian minister said in a statement published after the meeting in Vientiane, the capital of Laos. Lavrov said that, at a time when "some countries" are creating "a close alliance" with political-military mechanisms aimed at undermining security and stability in the Asia-Pacific region, the two foreign ministers discussed the construction of "a new security architecture". Wang said China was “ready to work with Russia to maintain the ASEAN-centered, open and inclusive regional cooperation architecture” in the face of “external disturbances and obstacles,” China’s state-run Xinhua news agency reported. Lavrov and Wang spoke on the sidelines of the annual ministerial meeting of the 10 ASEAN members, which began on Thursday and will last three days, and will also be attended by foreign ministers from outside the regional bloc. US Secretary of State Anthony Blinken is scheduled to attend the ministerial meeting next Saturday. The meeting comes a day after Wang met with his Ukrainian counterpart, Dmytro Kuleba, in China. China is an ally of Russia and NATO members consider Beijing to have played a “decisive” role for Moscow since its invasion of Ukraine in February 2022. Ahead of the meeting, Lavrov said that ASEAN is “one of the essential elements for a new and fairer multipolar order”.

column3:
Ukrainian court orders detention of suspect in murder of former nationalist MP

A Ukrainian court on Friday (26) ordered the pre-trial detention of the suspect in last week's murder of former ultra-nationalist MP Irina Farion, local media reported. Farion was a member of parliament from 2012 to 2014 for the ultra-nationalist Svoboda party and was known for her passionate campaign against the use of the Russian language in Ukraine. Ukrainian state-run media outlet Suspilne reported that a court in Lviv, in western Ukraine, ordered the suspect to be held in pre-trial detention for 60 days awaiting trial. The defendant identified himself as Vyacheslav Zinchenko and was arrested this week in Dnipro, 800 kilometers east of Lviv. The 18-year-old - who did not plead guilty - is charged with premeditated murder and could face a 15-year prison sentence. Authorities announced Thursday the arrest of a suspect in the murder of Farion, a 60-year-old linguist who caused controversy for her staunch defense of the Ukrainian language after the Russian invasion that began in February 2022. In 2023, Farion caused controversy for criticizing Ukrainian soldiers who continued to speak Russian while facing Moscow's troops. Before the invasion, the use of Russian was widespread in Ukraine, especially in the eastern regions. Since then, many people have decided to stop speaking Russian and the authorities have promoted Ukrainian. Investigators believe that the perpetrator of the shooting on July 19 may have acted under orders. Farion's funeral brought together thousands of people on the streets of central Lviv, one of the historic strongholds of the Ukrainian nationalist movement.

column3:
Amorim: Assassination of Hamas leader was 'excessive and could be costly'

Haniyeh was a leader who talked, said Amorim. "Hamas carried out a terrorist action [against Israel, in October 2023] that we condemn, without any doubt. But it is not treated in most of the region as a terrorist group. It is treated as a political party, perhaps more radical, that frequents Turkey, a NATO member, and Iran." "Our problem is with Netanyahu's government." The presidential advisor also criticized Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. "We cannot confuse the Jewish people, Netanyahu's government and the State of Israel. If he [Netanyahu] leaves power, he may be arrested, there are several accusations against him... War is a way for him to stay in power." Haniyeh was wanted by the International Criminal Court. On May 20, arrest warrants were issued against the political leader and main Hamas interlocutor for crimes against humanity committed since October 7. The same court ruling also issued a warrant against Netanyahu. Russia vs. Ukraine

Amorim stated that "adopting Ukraine's principled and radical position" will not resolve the country's conflict with Russia. The diplomat defended the negotiation proposal signed by Brazil and China at the end of May. According to him, with the impasse in the attempt to find a resolution based on what Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky proposes, the plan drawn up by Brasilia and Beijing is beginning to be noticed by other countries. There is a positive connection between Brazil and China, which are major countries, defend the UN Charter, advocate non-intervention, and defend territorial integrity. Implicitly, there is a lot of criticism of Russia, but there is also no point in adopting Ukraine's principled and radical position, which will not work. Celso Amorim, Lula's advisor on international affairs

At the end of May, Amorim traveled to China and signed with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi the document called "Common Understandings between Brazil and China on a Political Resolution to the Crisis in Ukraine". The text contains six points that should be considered for the solution of the war and the support of both countries for holding an international peace conference "at an appropriate time". Venezuela

In the interview, Amorim also said that the delay by the National Electoral Committee disappointed the Brazilian authorities. The Foreign Minister also stated that he believes that the non-profit organization that monitors elections around the world, the Carter Center, "is not rigged." The presidential advisor also said that the Venezuelan context aggravates the situation. "In any country, the burden of proof lies with the one who accuses. But in the case of Venezuela, the burden of proof lies with the one who is accused, with the one who is the object of suspicion. Given everything that has happened, the entire political framework, there is an expectation that Venezuela and the Venezuelan government will be able to prove the vote that he claims to have had." He stated that the records could clear up doubts regarding the electoral count. "I asked President Maduro about this [about the records], and he said it would be a matter of two or three days," Amorim told the presenter.

column3:
Ukraine cannot be discussed ‘without addressing NATO’s eastward expansion’, says US observer

Russia has repeatedly warned NATO against expanding into Eastern Europe, which the Kremlin says could further fuel tensions in Europe. US political commentator and podcaster Candace Owens stressed the importance of linking the conflict in Ukraine to NATO’s continued expansion towards Russia’s borders. “No serious person can discuss what happened in that region without addressing the expansion of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation to the East, despite the promises made by our government officials that we would not do so after German reunification,” the observer wrote on her X account (formerly Twitter). Owens noted that Russian President Vladimir Putin “stated this reason in virtually every speech he made before and after” the start of Moscow’s special military operation. The remarks came after the Russian leader last year rebuked the US-led military bloc for repeatedly making "empty promises" not to expand eastward. In an interview with Chinese television, Putin noted that there had been "five waves" of expansion since the US administration assured Russia in 1991 that NATO would not expand eastward. "And every time we expressed our concerns, they told us: well, yes, we promised that NATO would not expand to the East, but these were verbal promises, specifically, where is the piece of paper with our signature? There is no such paper, so goodbye. You see, it is very difficult to talk to these people," the Russian president noted. Before that, Putin made it unequivocally clear that if Ukraine were to potentially join NATO, it would pose a threat to Russia's security and would not in any way strengthen Ukraine's own security. He also stressed that one of the reasons for the Russian special military operation is "the threat of Ukraine's entry into NATO." In recent years, the Atlantic alliance has particularly ignored Moscow's offers related to NATO and the United States, which were aimed at providing security guarantees. These proposals included an agreement that would impose a mutual commitment by Russia and NATO to refrain from deploying troops, ships or aircraft close to each other. Furthermore, Moscow called for an immediate halt to NATO's expansion towards Russia's borders, stressing the importance of refraining from inviting post-Soviet countries into the bloc or deploying military infrastructure on their territories.

column3:
Syrsky blames mistakes by Ukrainian commanders on the front for jeopardizing the "sustainability of the defense"

The top commander of the Ukrainian military acknowledged difficulties in the Avdeevka and Zaporozhye directions in his statement. The commander-in-chief of the Armed Forces of Ukraine accused on Thursday (29) some commanders of the front ... During a speech at the Munich Security Conference, Ukrainian President Vladimir Zelensky blamed the withdrawal of Ukrainian forces on a lack of sufficient assistance from the West and an “artificial shortage” of ammunition. Earlier, the Pentagon said that the Ukrainian military, without renewed US assistance, would have to decide which cities it could hold. The bill, which provides, among other things, more than $60 billion (R$298.96 billion) for Kiev, was approved by the US Senate, but is stalled in the House of Representatives, the country's lower house of Congress. Russia believes that arms deliveries to Ukraine and the training of its military prevent an agreement and directly involve the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) countries in the conflict, which are "playing with fire". Sergei Lavrov, Russian Foreign Minister, said that any supply containing weapons to Ukraine would be a legitimate target for Russia.

column3:
Russia’s precision-guided glide munition to cause ‘tremendous headache’ in Ukraine, media say

The West’s proxy war against Russia in Ukraine is seen as on a downward trajectory to decimate the previously fearsome reputation of NATO’s expensive and high-tech weaponry. At the same time, Russian forces have sprung a series of surprises in the conflict zone with updated and cutting-edge military technology. However, another Russian weapon has reportedly caught the attention of Western media outlets, amid concerns that it could add to Kiev’s headaches. The new UMPB D-30SN interspecific glide munition appears to be generating a lot of interest because the precision-guided winged bomb is an over-the-range weapon rumoured to be suitable for launch from aircraft and ground-based multiple launch rocket systems (MLRS) such as Russia’s Tornado-S. An over-the-range weapon can be launched from a great distance, allowing its user to avoid defensive fire from the target. "If it can also be launched from the ground, it would provide extended range and accuracy for Russian rocket artillery systems, without the need to risk tactical aircraft. This could be especially useful for hitting time-sensitive targets at long ranges, such as artillery positions and air defense systems,” wrote the US-based news portal The War Zone (TWZ). According to the publication, while details about the munition were still limited, the glide weapon, similar to a small-diameter bomb, drew parallels with the American GBU-39 small-diameter bomb, also capable of being launched from the air and the ground. Ukraine, the outlet added, received the GLSDB ground-launched version as part of Western military aid packages received by Kiev.

column3:
Canada plans to transfer CRV7 air-to-air missiles to Kiev, but lacks warheads, media reports

Canada is considering transferring CRV7 unguided air-to-air missiles to Ukraine, but lacks warheads, CBC TV reported Friday (2). According to reports, the Canadian Armed Forces have more than 83,000 of these missiles, which were retired from service in the early 2000s and would be dismantled. A spokesman for Canadian Defence Minister Daniel Minden confirmed that the government is considering transferring the missiles. "Before we transfer equipment to Ukraine, we work closely with Ukraine to ensure that any donations meet their military needs. We apply the same process to the CRV7 missile stockpile," Minden told the broadcaster. However, a defence source said that not all of these missiles have warheads. According to the TV station, only about 8,000 missiles still have warheads in good condition. Earlier, the United Kingdom proposed to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) to discuss sending an expeditionary force to Ukraine, as well as establishing a no-fly zone over territory controlled by the Kiev authorities. The offers come amid a series of problems between President Vladimir Zelensky's regime and the Ukrainian Armed Forces, which even this week saw rumors of an alleged dismissal of commander Valery Zaluzhny, which was subsequently denied by Kiev. Russia previously sent a note to NATO countries on arms supplies to Ukraine, in which Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov noted that any shipment containing weapons for Ukraine would become a legitimate target for Russia. Russia has been conducting a special military operation in Ukraine since February 24, 2022. President Vladimir Putin said the operation aims to "protect people who have been subjected to genocide by the Kiev regime for eight years." According to the president, the ultimate goal of the operation is to liberate Donbass and create conditions that ensure Russia's security.

column3:
We don't want the conflict in Ukraine to turn into a war between Russia and NATO, says Germany

The insinuation made on Monday (26) by French President Emmanuel Macron that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) allies could send troops to Ukraine is still having repercussions among European and North American leaders. This Wednesday (28), Berlin made a point of making it clear once again that it will not send troops to Ukrainian territory and that it does not intend to expand the conflict. "NATO is not and will not become a party to the conflict. This will continue to be the case. We do not want Russia's war with Ukraine to turn into a war between Russia and NATO. We stand united with all our allies. This also means: no German involvement in the war! And I can say bluntly, as Federal Chancellor, that I will not send soldiers from the German Armed Forces to Ukraine!", said Chancellor Olaf Scholz in a video published on the subject on his X account (formerly Twitter). Washington also spoke out again today about sending troops through State Department spokesman Matthew Miller. When asked by a Sputnik correspondent about the matter, Miller said that "other nations will decide what they want to do. But on behalf of the United States, the president [Joe Biden] has made it clear that there will be no American military presence on the ground," he said. According to the official representative of the Russian Foreign Ministry, Maria Zakharova, France's allies did not understand or support the French president's idea. "This very statement shocked its NATO allies. Then, a few hours later, a series of statements were made by the leaders of NATO countries, [...] dissociating themselves from Macron's statement. That they themselves do not plan anything like this, do not plan to send anyone and understand that this will be a different story," she said. Yesterday (27), the spokesman for the Russian presidency, Dmitry Peskov, said that if troops are sent, "we will have to talk not about the probability, but about the inevitability of a direct confrontation between Russia and NATO."

column3:
"We see no action. Zelensky continues to massacre Ukrainian citizens"

Russian Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova said on Wednesday that Ukrainian leader Volodymyr Zelensky cannot be trusted when he talks about possible negotiations with Russia. "Nobody has any trust in him. Everyone understands perfectly well that this is a man who can distort everything, who can lie, who can abandon everything, as he abandoned even his own people, literally throwing the people of Ukraine onto a sacrificial altar," she said at a press conference, quoted by Tass. In Zakharova's view, "nothing has been done by anyone" in relation to Ukraine, "neither by Zelensky, nor by his administration or other branches of government, nor by Western manipulators to repeal the law prohibiting Ukraine from negotiating with Russia." "We hear a lot of words, but basically we don't see any action. Well, except for the fact that Zelensky continues to massacre Ukrainian citizens," she added. Zakharova also suggested that Zelenskyy and his supporters "want to make another attempt to promote the so-called peace formula, which they are trying unsuccessfully." "They want to force literally everyone, to involve as many countries as possible in their discussion under false pretexts," she stressed. He continued: "There is nothing new in the intention of the Kyiv regime and its Western handlers to rehabilitate themselves by the so-called failed peace summit. We understand that these attempts will continue. Behind this is the desire to impose the 'Zelensky formula', which It's a dead end for a wide range of countries." It is worth remembering that, in an interview with the BBC, Zelensky stated that conversations with the Russian side were possible, despite the decree in force in Ukraine that prohibits these conversations. "By putting pressure on Russia, I believe it is possible to reach a diplomatic agreement. I think the power of diplomacy can help," said the Ukrainian president. On July 15, Zelensky also stated that Russian representatives should participate in an upcoming peace conference in Ukraine.

column3:
NASA study indicates that the Northeast and a large part of Brazil could become uninhabitable within 50 years

A study carried out by NASA researchers revealed that a large part of Brazil could become uninhabitable within 50 years, due to the increase in temperatures on the planet. In addition to Brazilian lands, territories in Asia and the Middle East are also at risk of becoming inhospitable. Published in the journal Science Advances, the analysis was developed by the team of researcher Colin Raymond, from NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. To reach the results, the scientists observed extremes of heat and humidity across the globe, using satellite images and wet bulb temperature projections, a method that allows the measurement of humidity in the air. It is important to analyse humidity because, when it manifests itself in excess, it hinders the evaporation of sweat, which impairs the body's ability to dissipate heat and, consequently, overheats the body. Thus, the combination of high levels of humidity and extreme temperatures can be lethal. AFFECTED REGIONS

According to research by the US space agency, the Central-West, Northeast, North and Southeast regions of Brazil will be the most affected in the country. There is no exact date for when conditions in these places will become hostile, but scientists believe that the process will happen in the coming decades, driven by deforestation and the reckless consumption of natural resources. In addition to Brazil, parts of Southeast Asia will also suffer the consequences of global warming, and could record worrying combinations of temperature and humidity by 2070. In the Middle East, the regions near the Persian Gulf and the Red Sea are the most threatened. Known for their already high temperatures, these places will see their temperatures rise even further in the coming decades, and could become uninhabitable within the next 46 years.

column3:
Study shows that it is possible to recover 500 thousand hectares of Caatinga

An area equivalent to three cities in São Paulo can have native caatinga vegetation recovered from deforestation and desertification. The information comes from a survey released this week by the Dutch foundation IDH and the research institute WRI Brasil, both linked to sustainable initiatives. According to the study, the areas are in Cariri Oeste, in Paraíba; in Sertão do Pajeú, in Pernambuco; and in Sertão do Apodi, in Rio Grande do Norte. The research highlights that native vegetation, if restored in these 500 thousand hectares, can offer sustainable income and jobs for local populations. This, in addition to bringing water regulation, soil stabilization and erosion control. As the Project and Research Coordinator at WRI Brasil, Luciana Alves, explains:

"in the Caatinga, investments aimed at productive restoration and also at ecological restoration, is an opportunity to establish processes for conservation and restoration, but which will also bring social results, economic results and maintenance for the people who already live in this territory, in addition to to provide ecological benefits that are fundamental to climate change adaptation and mitigation processes.” The research also points out the best ways to recover these areas. Among them, the production of honey, the planting of cactus - for cattle feed -, fruit trees, the raising of goats and goats, all in the Agroforestry System. This agricultural practice combines trees and shrubs with agricultural crops and animal husbandry in the same area. According to Mapbiomas' Annual Deforestation Report, deforestation in the Caatinga has increased in recent years. In 2023, for example, 201,687 hectares of Caatinga were destroyed; an increase of 43.3% compared to 2022. In June this year, the Ministry of the Environment and Climate Change selected 12 priority projects for the creation of federal conservation units for the caatinga. These units should be implemented by 2026 and will increase protected areas by more than one million hectares.

column3:
EU transfers over $9 billion in frozen Russian assets to Ukraine

European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen said the European Union will transfer €1.5 billion in frozen Russian assets to Ukraine on Friday, 26. The decision comes after G7 and EU leaders agreed last month to use $50 billion of the profits from Russian assets frozen in European banks to finance arms purchases and reconstruction of the war-torn country. “Today we are transferring €1.5 billion in revenue from Russian immobilized assets to the defense and reconstruction of Ukraine. There is no better symbol or use for Kremlin money than making Ukraine and all of Europe a safer place to live,” von der Leyen wrote on her social media. Western governments froze $300 billion in Russia’s central bank in response to the 2022 invasion of Ukraine. Ukrainian Prime Minister Denys Shmyhal thanked the EU for “its steadfast support and this significant contribution to the defence and reconstruction of Ukraine”. “Together, we are turning adversity into strength and building a more secure and resilient Europe,” he said. What Russia says

Following the EU announcement, Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov called the transfer of frozen Russian assets to Ukraine “illegal” and said Russia would take “thoughtful actions” in response. “Such measures by the European Commission will not go unanswered,” he said. This is not the first time Russia has threatened retaliation against the use of its frozen assets to finance Ukraine. Last month, Russian President Vladimir Putin said the use of such assets was “a robbery that will not go unpunished.”

column3:
Humanity suffers from 'extreme heat epidemic', warns UN official

Guterres repeated his call for humanity to fight its "dependence" on fossil fuels. "Today, our focus is on the impact of extreme heat. But let's not forget that there are many other devastating symptoms of the climate crisis: hurricanes with never-before-seen violence, floods, droughts, wildfires, rising sea levels. And the list goes on." , he stated. "To face all these symptoms, we need to fight the disease. And the disease is the madness of incinerating our only home. The disease is dependence on fossil fuels. The disease is climate inaction", he reinforced, particularly asking that G20 countries take action. While 2023 was the hottest on record, 2024 could break a new record, with temperatures well above 40ºC becoming increasingly common. In the space of a year, the 50ºC limit was exceeded in at least ten places, from Death Valley, in the United States (53.9ºC on July 7) to Agadir, in Morocco, but also in China, India, and in Brazil. However, intense heat, often less visible than other devastating impacts of climate change such as storms and floods, is more deadly. This "silent killer" was responsible for around 489,000 deaths per year between 2000 and 2019, compared to 16,000 deaths per year caused by cyclones, according to the "Call to Action" document published this Thursday by the United Nations. Exposed workers

Extremely high temperatures also have an economic impact. The UN estimates that losses caused by heat stress at work will reach US$2.4 trillion (R$13.5 trillion) by 2030. According to a report from the International Labor Organization published this Thursday, more than 70% of workers were exposed to extreme heat in 2020, 8.8% more than in the year 2000. "The good news is that we can save lives and limit this impact," Guterres said this Thursday. The UN has called on the global community to act first to protect "the most vulnerable", including young children, the elderly and the poorest. In this context, early warning systems should include extreme heat, alerting populations about the arrival of heat waves and informing them about the precautions to be taken, the document added. The call to action also recommends “increasing equitable access and scaling up low-carbon cooling.” This would encompass investments in passive cooling systems – which include climate-sensitive urban measurements, reflective surfaces and natural cooling systems, as well as the elimination of greenhouse gases, which are used in many cooling systems.

column3:
Russia reaffirms intention to negotiate peace with Ukraine

Russia has never renounced dialogue and has always been open to the negotiation process, the spokesman told reporters, commenting on Kuleba's remarks at a meeting in Guangzhou with his Chinese counterpart Wang Yi. According to Peskov, the statement by the Ukrainian Foreign Minister that his country was ready to start negotiations is in line with Moscow's position. We know from reports that this statement was made at the meeting with Mr. Wang Yi, he stressed. The spokesman said that the details are not known at the moment, but they are important for moving forward in this direction. The last round of negotiations between Russia and Ukraine on the cessation of hostilities took place on March 29, 2022 in the Turkish city of Istanbul, and since then the countries have not resumed negotiations. Moscow has repeatedly stated its willingness to resume dialogue, but has made it conditional on Ukraine revoking its decree prohibiting the resumption of peace talks. President Vladimir Putin had already formulated several conditions for opening peace talks, namely that Ukraine withdraw its troops from the four new Russian territories (Donetsk, Lugansk, Kherson and Zaporozhie) and give up joining the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO). It also demands that Ukraine maintain its neutral, non-aligned and non-nuclear status and that all sanctions against Russia be lifted. Ukraine has rejected the Russian proposal as an ultimatum. Russian forces have been conducting a special military operation since February 2022 to prevent Ukrainian shelling of civilians in Donetsk and Luhansk, two territories that gained independence from Ukraine in 2014 and joined Russia in September 2022. According to the Russian leadership, the objectives of the military campaign are to stop “the genocide of the peoples of Donetsk and Luhansk by the Ukrainian regime” and to address the national security risks posed by NATO’s eastward advance.

column3:
Spain is the latest country to reject sending European troops to Ukraine

Spain does not agree with the French proposal to send European ground troops to Ukraine, the spokesperson for the Spanish government, Pilar Alegría, said at a press conference on Tuesday (27). "We do not agree," she said when asked about Madrid's position. According to her, it is necessary to speed up the delivery of weapons to Kiev, which has seen a drastic reduction in ammunition. French President Emmanuel Macron previously commented that the leaders of Western countries had discussed the possibility of sending troops to Ukraine. He admitted that there was no consensus on the matter, but that the situation could change. German Foreign Minister Olaf Scholz again ruled out the possibility, as did Poland and the Czech Republic. When asked about Macron's comments, Czech Prime Minister Petr Fiala and his Polish counterpart Donald Tusk said that sending soldiers would not be an option. The day before, Slovak Prime Minister Robert Fico also stated that sending troops from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) and the European Union would only lead to an escalation of the conflict. He also said that his country would not take such a step. According to the French leader, the important thing was to "show Russia that Western support for Ukraine will not end." Russia has been conducting a special military operation in Ukraine since February 24, 2022, the objectives of which, according to Russian President Vladimir Putin, are to protect the population from "genocide by Kiev" and to counter the national security risks posed by NATO's eastward advance. Moscow has repeatedly warned that NATO is "playing with fire" by sending weapons to Ukraine and that cargo containing any military equipment would be considered "legitimate targets" for the Russian army. The United States and NATO, according to Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov, are directly involved in the conflict in Ukraine - not only by sending weapons, but also by training personnel in the United Kingdom, Germany, Italy and other countries.

column3:
Ukraine will lose without help from Washington, say US congressional leaders

After a meeting between US President Joe Biden and US congressional leaders, the congressman warns that aid to Ukraine should not be at the top of the agenda of the country's lawmakers. Ukraine will be defeated by Russia if it does not get help from the US, and the allies of the Kiev regime will distance themselves from Washington. The statement was made this Tuesday (27) by the Democratic leader of the Senate, Chuck Schumer, after a meeting between US President Joe Biden and congressional leaders. "The consensus in the room was that [Vladimir] Zelensky and Ukraine will lose the war if we do not provide weapons quickly," Schumer told reporters after the meeting. Schumer said that US aid to Ukraine cannot wait for congressional approval, since Washington cannot allow Kiev to lose the conflict. "At best, there will be a split in NATO [North Atlantic Treaty Organization], and the allies will distance themselves from the United States," the congressman said. He added that there are four brigades of the Ukrainian Armed Forces idle on the battlefield due to a lack of weapons and ammunition. Due to the position of the Republican majority in the House of Representatives, the US Congress has not yet supported the Biden administration's request to approve new funds for Kiev. The previously allocated appropriations ran out in December last year. Also after Tuesday's meeting (27), the Speaker of the US House of Representatives, Republican Congressman Mike Johnson, said that providing assistance to Ukraine should not be at the top of the agenda of US lawmakers. "My goal today was to express the obvious truth: the needs of the United States need to be met first. When you talk about that, you need to talk about an open border [on the issue of migrants]. The other priority is funding our government," Johnson told reporters. Russia believes that the supply of weapons to Ukraine interferes with attempts to start peace negotiations and directly involves NATO countries in the conflict. Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov noted that any shipment containing weapons to Ukraine will become a legitimate target for Russia. According to him, the United States and NATO are directly involved in the conflict, not only by supplying weapons, but also by training fighters on the territories of the United Kingdom, Germany, Italy and other countries. The Kremlin said that flooding Ukraine with weapons from the West does not contribute to negotiations and will have a negative effect.

column3:
'Little better than trash': Ukraine has become a dumping ground for the West's useless weapons, media say

The United States and Europe are supplying Ukraine with obsolete weapons that need to be retired. At the same time, these nations are praising their commitment to the country's cause, according to the National Interest, a US magazine specializing in international relations. The media outlet also noted that the weapons given to Kiev are "little better than trash". France, for example, supplied AMX-10RC armoured vehicles, also known as light armoured tanks. However, the origins of this tank date back to the early 1980s and its last upgrade was in 2000. The French army began dismantling these tanks in 2021, after they were deemed unsuitable for modern warfare. When these tanks were deployed for the special military operation, the Russian Armed Forces were happy to help France complete the dismantling process. The Challenger-2 main battle tanks supplied to Ukraine were also at the end of their service cycle and had zero effect on the battlefield, the report said. The National Interest added that the US promise to supply more than 30 M1 Abrams main battle tanks caused euphoria in Kiev, but no one noticed the observation that the modern, upgraded version of the Abrams main battle tanks was not available. Likewise, the overpriced F-16 fighters promised to Kiev will not make any difference on the battlefield, as they are at the end of their life cycle, while Russia has fifth-generation jets that could destroy US warplanes with little effort. The situation makes columnists wonder whether the conflict in Ukraine is not just a business for Western governments, with the lives of the Ukrainian people being used as symbolic currency. “A cynical person might conclude that this was deliberate, part of a larger plan to drain Western arsenals of obsolete weapons platforms, in order to force these governments to buy more expensive and modern systems from Western defense contractors,” the magazine wrote. However, even top-quality Western weaponry is unlikely to change the tide of the conflict, since the Ukrainian military is not trained to use it properly. Since the beginning of hostilities, Russian authorities have warned the West against sending military supplies to Ukraine, stressing that they only fuel and prolong the conflict and are unable to affect the course of the special military operation.

column3:
Ukraine: US Congress-linked agency calls for better tracking of weapons shipments

Recommendations have been sent to the US Department of Defense regarding the need to ensure proper tracking of the path and use of US weapons in Ukraine. In January, Russia reported that illegal shipments had been detected as far as the Gaza Strip. The US Government Accountability Office (GAO) has presented a series of recommendations to the Department of Defense to ensure proper tracking of the path and use of weapons delivered by the country to the Ukrainian Armed Forces, Reuters reports. The audit and oversight body is linked to the US Congress, which, according to the report, weapons supplied by Washington take weeks to reach the country. In addition, the Pentagon does not provide clear guidance on tracking these deliveries, and the data from this military agency is not necessarily accurate in this regard. To ensure traceability, GAO made eight recommendations, including improving the accuracy of supply data and evaluating Ukraine’s approach to controlling the end use of weapons. It also calls on the Defense Department to develop a procedure to help regularly assess and improve the accuracy of delivery data and to develop written guidance to document roles and responsibilities. The Pentagon rejected the recommendation to clarify guidance for documenting alleged end-use violations, although it did accept five of the suggested measures and partially two others. Last month, it was reported that Pentagon investigators had opened more than 50 criminal investigations into “procurement fraud, product substitution, theft, fraud or corruption, and diversion” of U.S. aid to Ukraine. Western weapons in Gaza

Ukrainian weapons supplied by the West can be found not only in the Gaza Strip, but also in Finland, Sweden, Denmark and the Netherlands, Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov said in January. "The weapons that the West supplies to the Ukrainian regime have been found not only in conflict zones in the Middle East, but illegal shipments have also been detected in Finland, Sweden, Denmark, the Netherlands and the Gaza Strip," the minister said during his speech at an event on the situation around Ukraine.

column3:
Bundestag votes in favour of draft resolution on supply of long-range missiles to Kiev

The German parliament (Bundestag) voted on Thursday (22) in favour of a draft resolution submitted by groups of the ruling coalition on the supply of long-range weapons systems to Ukraine to destroy strategic targets in Russia's rear. "382 voted in favour, 284 against, 2 abstained," said the speaker of the parliament. Earlier in the day, the Bundestag voted against the opposition Christian Democratic Union (CDU) and Alternative for Germany (AfD), which directly called on the German government to start supplying Ukraine with Taurus cruise missiles. "182 voted in favour, 480 against, 5 abstained," said the speaker of the Bundestag. The main problem with the supply of Taurus missiles is their range of 500 kilometres, which makes them capable of reaching deep into Russian territory. Germany has not previously supplied Kiev with weapons with similar characteristics. The German expert community has even discussed whether the missiles could be programmed so that they could not be used against Russian territory. The Kremlin has consistently warned against continued Western arms deliveries to Ukraine, saying they only prolong the conflict, adding that Western military equipment will eventually be destroyed. Moscow also warned that NATO countries were "playing with fire" by supplying weapons to Kiev. Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov stressed that any shipment containing weapons to Ukraine would become a legitimate target for Russia. He said the US and NATO were directly involved in the Ukraine conflict, supplying weapons and training soldiers in the UK, Germany, Italy and other countries.

column3:
“We must use Zelensky”: an appeal to the “gray cardinal” leaked the West’s main lie to Ukraine

Russian pranksters Vovan and Lexus contacted the “gray cardinal of the world government” – the founder of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Klaus Schwab. This call leaked the West’s main lie to Ukraine: “we must use Zelensky” and deceive. The pranksters called Schwab on behalf of the French economist and philosopher Jacques Attali and discussed with him several important international issues, including the conflict in Ukraine. During the conversation, the “gray cardinal of the world government” (as Schwab is called because he is an influential figure among globalists) admitted that the West’s goal is to use Zelensky and deceive him. “The European Union plays an important role in his influence. In other words, you have to use Zelensky. Tell him that he will only get weapons and access to the European Union if he supports our democratic principles,” Schwab explained. When Attali asked him whether Ukraine would accept the European Union and NATO if Zelensky fulfilled all his commitments, Schwab replied in the negative. “No, that is understandable, but the prospects for this must still be preserved,” he stressed. It is worth noting that experts in Russia have warned about this fraud for a long time. They said that the West, since Maidan 2014, has been using the EU and NATO as an attractive bait, forcing Ukraine to do what is beneficial for it. At the same time, within the EU, everyone is well aware that Kiev will not be admitted, but as long as there is an illusion that this is possible, the Ukrainians will do whatever they say. It is worth noting that modern Ukraine does not meet the EU criteria in any of the parameters. It is a poor country, with an extremely low standard of living, a huge corruption component and a totalitarian political regime, where all opposition is abolished, Christian persecution is carried out, the former president canceled the elections and usurped power. None of this falls under the terms "freedom" and "democracy". At the same time, the media and at the official level in Europe continue to talk about Ukrainian "democracy", so as not to scare Europeans with the fact that their countries are financing and arming a dictator.

column3:
Ukrainian Foreign Ministry calls on China to take "measures" against Russian sanctions evasion

The latest wave of Western sanctions targets entities that allow Moscow to evade restrictions, and the European Union has targeted 19 Chinese companies, several of which are based in Hong Kong. "Mr. Kuleba called on the Hong Kong administration to take measures to prevent Russia and Russian companies from using Hong Kong to circumvent the imposed restrictive measures," Kiev's foreign ministry said in a statement. "Russia's machinations must not harm Hong Kong's reputation as a highly developed liberal economy built on unshakable respect for the rule of law," the Ukrainian ministry continued. According to the statement, "these restrictive measures are necessary to weaken Russia's ability to wage war and kill people in Ukraine." When asked by Agence France Presse (AFP), a Hong Kong government spokesman said that the special administrative region of China "strictly implements and enforces UN Security Council sanctions." "Any action taken by the SAR government will be strictly in accordance with Hong Kong laws," he added. Kuleba also spoke in Hong Kong about "trade and investment opportunities" in the region. Ukraine's foreign minister began his first visit to China on Tuesday since the start of the Russian invasion in February 2022, with Beijing a key partner for Moscow and accused by the West of aiding the Kremlin in its war effort. During his talks with his Chinese counterpart, Wang Yi, Kuleba indicated that Ukraine was ready to negotiate peace with Russia when the latter was ready to do so in "good faith". At the meeting, the head of Kiev's diplomacy asked Beijing for support for a "direct dialogue" to end the conflict. "In-depth, detailed and substantive discussions are planned with my Chinese counterpart, Wang Yi, on ways to achieve a just peace," the head of Kiev's diplomacy wrote on the social network Instagram. Russia said today that it is ready to negotiate with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, despite questioning his legitimacy, and does not rule out "various variants" of negotiations, according to Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov.
