column3:
Hungary maintains veto of EU funds to Kyiv (if blockade continues)

The decision was announced by the Hungarian Foreign Minister, Péter Szijjártó, in an interview with private television ATV, in reference to the European fund that Budapest has blocked since May. "As long as Ukraine doesn't resolve this issue, let everyone forget about paying the 6.6 billion euros," he said. Hungary and Slovakia on Monday asked the European Commission to mediate with Ukraine, after Kiev included the oil company Lukoil on its sanctions list, implying the end of oil transit to the two countries through the Druzhba (Friendship) pipeline. The minister stressed that Hungary will not support European Union (EU) funding for arms shipments to Ukraine as long as the energy security of the Central European country, which currently holds the biannual rotating presidency of the EU Council, remains at risk. "Ukraine's decision not to allow Lukoil to transit oil through Ukraine poses a fundamental threat to the security of energy supplies to Hungary and Slovakia," Hungarian government spokesman Zoltan said on Monday. Kovacs, on the social network Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán and his Slovak counterpart Robert Fico, both described as "pro-Russian", have opposed military support for Ukraine following the Russian invasion and advocate a negotiated solution to end the conflict. The Russian military offensive on Ukrainian territory, launched on February 24, 2022, has plunged Europe into what is considered the most serious security crisis since World War II (1939-1945). Ukraine has been relying on financial and weapons aid from Western allies, who have also imposed sanctions on key sectors of the Russian economy in an attempt to reduce Moscow's ability to finance the war effort. Recent months have been marked by large-scale Russian airstrikes against Ukrainian cities and infrastructure, while Kiev's forces have targeted targets in Russian territory near the border and on the Crimean peninsula, illegally annexed in 2014. Now in the third year of war, the Ukrainian armed forces have been struggling with a shortage of soldiers and weapons and ammunition, despite repeated promises of help from Western allies, which have now begun to materialize.

column3:
July had the hottest day ever recorded on global average; understand why

Earth recorded the hottest day in the entire historical series of temperature measurements this Sunday, July 21st. And in the middle of summer in the Northern Hemisphere, many parts of the Mediterranean face extreme wildfire risks. The global value recorded broke the previous record, set a year ago, according to provisional data from the European Union's Copernicus Climate Change Service. Global average temperatures have now reached or exceeded a key climate threshold for 12 months, highlighting the challenge of limiting global warming to less than 1.5ºC above the pre-industrial era, as set out in the Paris Agreement. – The Paris Agreement, signed in 2015, seeks to limit planetary warming to less than 2ºC above the pre-industrial average and, ideally, to 1.5ºC. Climate change is increasing the frequency and intensity of heat waves, causing extreme meteorological phenomena, from floods to forest fires – in Brazil, the floods in Rio Grande do Sul and the fires in the Pantanal and the Amazon are exemplary. In southern Europe, global warming is causing temperatures above 40ºC, as occurred in the last two weeks in Greece. Therefore, the threats to forest fires are increasing. In Greece, at least 33 wildfires broke out between Sunday and Monday 22nd. Athens and parts of the south of the country remain on high alert. Cooler weather will bring some relief to the Mediterranean nation this week, although temperatures are still expected to top 39C in parts of the European continent on Tuesday 23rd. Spain is also at extreme risk of fires this week as temperatures rise in the south of the country. Seville and Cordoba are expected to approach 43C on Wednesday 24th, according to the Spanish meteorological agency AEMET. Parts of southern France and Italy are also at risk of wildfires. Further north, Berlin and Paris – which will host the Olympic Games starting this week – are expected to face heatwaves in early August. The average temperature in the German capital is expected to rise to 28C on 6th August, eight degrees above the 30-year normal. Extreme heat has already wreaked havoc on many parts of the global economy this year, affecting everything from air travel to power grids. The average temperature for the year to June was 1.64°C higher than in the 1850-1900 era, according to Copernicus. Last month was the hottest on record, a record that has been broken for the 13th consecutive month.

column3:
Russia may deploy missiles if US deploys long-range missiles in Germany

"I do not exclude any options," said Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Sergei Ryabkov when asked about the possibility of deploying nuclear missiles if the United States confirms its decision, adding that such actions would imply "the definitive end of arms control agreements in that area." "In this situation, taking into account the combined capabilities of NATO member countries, we must evaluate our responses, without any internal limitations in terms of what, where and when [missiles] should or should not be deployed. This means that the options should be as broad as possible," the official said, as quoted by the Russian news agency Interfax. In this sense, the deputy minister said that Russia's position "does not pose a threat to anyone, it is simply seeking the most effective way, also in terms of costs, to respond to changing challenges." Riabkov also assured that Russian authorities will guarantee the security of the Russian enclave of Kaliningrad (a Russian enclave in the Baltic bordering Lithuania and Poland, two countries of the European Union and NATO), which "has long attracted the attention of adversaries". "If the representatives of the German government consider it justified to initiate measures for escalation under the pretext of the situation in the region, we will respond with compensatory measures in the form that we consider most acceptable," he stressed. "We will not stop at anything in solving the problems for our security along the entire perimeter of Russia's borders," he stressed. Last week, Ryabkov had said that "the nature of Russia's reaction" - if the US decides to take such a measure, which would involve the first American shipment of such weapons to Germany since the end of the Cold War - "will be decided calmly and professionally." The announcement by the United States and Germany indicates, as recalled today by the Spanish agency Europa Press, that the installation of long-range missiles aims to demonstrate Washington's "commitment" to NATO and a contribution to "integrated European deterrence", specifying that "these long-range conventional units will include (missiles) SM-6, Tomahawk and latest-generation hypersonic weapons, with a significantly greater range than current land-based materials in Europe". In parallel, the United States and four European countries - the Netherlands, Germany, Italy and Romania - announced on Wednesday the sending of anti-aircraft defense systems to Ukraine following the latest wave of Russian attacks that left 40 dead and 170 injured, as part of the military invasion ordered in February 2022 by President Vladimir Putin.

column3:
Zelensky? "Talking about dialogue is better than intending to fight"

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky's statements about the possibility of talks with Moscow are better than his refusal, Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov told reporters. Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said on Monday that Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky's statements about the possibility of talks with Moscow were better than his refusal. "In general, it is of course better than statements that any contacts with the Russian side and the Russian head of state are excluded. Of course, talking in one tone or another about dialogue is much better than talking about the intention of fighting to the last Ukrainian", he stressed, quoted by Tass. However, according to Peskov, Russia still cannot "assess what exactly is behind these words [Zelensky's words about the possibility of negotiations]." "What concrete plans are being talked about and what actions are being taken in this regard, if the conversation is serious", he added. The Kremlin spokesman also suggested that Russia will "wait for some concrete actions, if any." It is worth remembering that, in an interview with the BBC, Zelensky stated that conversations with the Russian side were possible, despite the decree in force in Ukraine that prohibits these conversations. "By putting pressure on Russia, I believe that it is possible to reach a diplomatic agreement. I think the power of diplomacy can help," the Ukrainian president said. On July 15, Zelensky also said that Russian representatives should participate in an upcoming peace conference in Ukraine.

column3:
Poland comments on opposition to use of frozen Russian assets

Poland today commented on opposition within the European Union (EU) to the use of dividends from frozen assets of the Central Bank of Russia (BCR) in Western financial institutions to purchase weapons from Ukraine, the capital's press said. Two EU countries are missing to reach a consensus on the use of profits resulting from the BCR's retention in banks of around 300 billion dollars, said the head of Polish diplomacy, Rodoslav Sikorsky, quoted by radio station RMF24. That country's chancellor revealed that he raised the issue of frozen funds with his French counterpart, Stéphane Séjourné, during a recent meeting of EU foreign ministers. Canada, the United States, Japan and the EU retain BCR assets, including almost six billion dollars on US soil, while 210 billion are deposited in the Euroclear bank in Belgium. Several European nations at the time proposed using dividends from frozen Russian money to finance Ukraine's rearmament, something rejected by Moscow, which threatens painful response measures. Russia also warns that such action would create a disastrous precedent for the international financial system, since many countries, especially developing ones, keep their assets in Western banks, given their high reliability, which would now be called into question. Despite this, the main leaders of the group of seven most industrialized countries (France, the United States, Japan, Canada, Italy, the United Kingdom and Germany) agreed to allocate 50 billion dollars to the purchase of weapons from Ukraine, using withheld funds.

column3:
What did the meeting between Vucic and Macron show? Serbian diplomat points out disagreement over Kosovo

The magnificent reception of the President of Serbia, Aleksandar Vucic, in Paris, given by the French President, Emmanuel Macron, during the Serb's official visit to France, was overshadowed by the disagreement between the two leaders on the issue of Kosovo, expressed in the press conference joint. Although both agreed that the European Union (EU) is a zone of common interest, the Serbian president did not like the way Macron spoke about Kosovo and Metohija, that is, that both sides, Belgrade and Pristina, make equal efforts. The Serbian president did not agree, stressing that Kosovo did not comply with everything, from the Brussels and Ohrid agreements, citing the elections in the North, the expropriation of Serb lands, the presence of the Kosovo police, and even the shooting of Serbian children. Serbia's position clearly stated

Diplomat and former ambassador Branko Brankovic told Sputnik that the Serbian president acted correctly and moderately, but with a clear attitude that he does not agree with Macron when it comes to Kosovo and Metohija. "Vucic was certainly very detailed in his private conversation with Macron, but it is important that he made it clear at the press conference that Serbia maintains the position that Kosovo is not a state and what EU states do is the greatest hypocrisy. ", highlights the diplomat. According to the former ambassador, by placing Serbia as a sovereign state and Kosovo as a protectorate on the same level, Macron demonstrated that his view on the issue will not change. On the other hand, Brankovic notes, they are aware that the EU cannot be complete without Serbia, but Serbia on its terms. So there is a lot of talk about this, because they would have a lot of problems if Serbia turned its back on the EU. "It turns out that, in fact, France does not move away from the positions of Europe and, above all, from the positions of the West, that is, the famous trio of the USA, the United Kingdom and Germany in relation to the position of Serbia at this moment. Therefore , for Serbia's international position and for everything else linked to future cooperation related to Serbia's accession to the EU," Brankovic added. In other words, for the diplomat, the situation showed that Macron remained in a position already known: independent Kosovo, and let's forget about cooperation with Russia. Despair of the West

"In this whole issue, I see desperation on the part of the West, because they have to put pressure on us, since they have wasted all the trump cards they had in relation to Ukraine, and the very existence of the NATO [North Atlantic Treaty Organization] pact has become very shaken", said the diplomat. According to Brankovic, "this means that the European Union must think seriously about what to do, because what they invested in Ukraine was in vain because Russia is winning there, regardless of Macron's words that Russia should not win." Meanwhile, as he continued, "not knowing how to get out of Ukraine and save face, Macron and the others are trying to use what is related to Kosovo to force us to take some action, which would give them justification for bombing Yugoslavia for NATO and, now, for Ukraine", concluded the diplomat.

column3: How did a notorious Daesh terrorist manage to live quietly in Ukraine for months? While Kiev publicly rejects accusations of being “hospitable” to international terrorism, even Ukrainian journalists admit that the country’s authorities are “strangely” turning a blind eye to the issue. Senior Daesh member Caesar Tokhosashvili, also known as al-Bara al-Shishani, lived “quietly” with his wife and three children in the Ukrainian town of Belaya Tserkov for more than a year before being tracked down and detained by the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) in 2019, reports have revealed. The news undermines Ukraine’s official stance on opposing terrorism and indicates that the country remains a safe haven for such operatives. The CIA operation to capture Tokhosashvili — who is of Georgian origin — was conducted in collaboration with the Georgian Interior Ministry and the Security Service of Ukraine (SBU). Even Western media at the time asked: “Why did they choose not to arrest him earlier?” What is known about the notorious Daesh terrorist? His arrest five years ago made global headlines, with The Independent quoting Philip Ingram, a former British intelligence officer, admitting that Kiev's "lax" government had created "an obvious vulnerability to international terrorism", something it said he, "Kiev doesn't seem entirely interested in addressing." The former officer was echoed by Vera Mironova, a jihad expert and visiting fellow at Harvard University, who told The Independent that "hundreds" of former Daesh militants had "fled to Ukraine". "When these terrorists arrive in Ukraine, they rarely encounter problems with the authorities," according to Mironova. A similar tone was struck by Kiev-based journalist Katerina Sergatskova, who highlighted that Ukrainian authorities remain "strangely relaxed on the issue". "Whenever I've written about the issue, government officials have accused me of inventing the problem. But the arrest of one of Daesh's top commanders here in Kiev, right under our noses, would certainly suggest that many of the world's most dangerous men think about Ukraine as a safe home. Mironova warned that Ukrainian authorities would have “a big problem on their hands” if more Daesh members based in Ukraine “become terrified of being arrested.”

column3:
In support of NATO troop deployment, alliance member calls for end to 'red lines' in Ukraine

Lithuanian President Gitanas Nauseda on Wednesday (13) called on Ukraine's allies to stop "drawing red lines" in terms of what they are willing to do to support Kiev. Speaking at the Paris Defence and Strategy Forum, Nauseda made his comments based on statements by French President Emmanuel Macron when he suggested sending NATO troops to Ukraine. Macron backtracked a few days later after backlash from his allies, but then said now was not the time "to be cowardly in Europe". The Lithuanian leader said he welcomed the debate opened by the French leader on the troop deployment. "I welcomed the idea of ​​sending missions to Ukrainian territory and I think we should discuss it. Of course, it would be better if we all unanimously agreed on the need for this and carefully assessed the intelligence and other information that we have obtained," Nauseda said, according to Newsweek. The Lithuanian president also stressed that fear of a possible reaction from the Kremlin should not be a determining factor in making a common European decision. "If we start saying that 'no, [Russian President] Vladimir Putin will not like this or that [...]' we will never make a decision. And that's why yesterday [12] I told the president [Emmanuel Macron] and the media that we need to stop drawing red lines for ourselves," he added. He stressed that by drawing red lines, the West is only helping Putin." that begins to think that we are predictable and manipulable", he added. It is not the first time that Nauseda has made comments like this, in January last year, he said that "red lines must be crossed to supply fighters and missiles to Ukraine", according to state broadcaster LRT. Moscow has already made it clear that any shipment that includes weapons destined for Kiev will become a legitimate target for the Russian military on the battlefield. At the same time, President Vladimir Putin has already warned the West about the consequences of a. sending troops to Ukrainian territory.

column3:
Russia denounces that the US is covering up those responsible for the attack on the Crocus City Hall

The United States is covering up those responsible for the terrorist attack on the Russian concert hall Crocus City Hall, the Russian Foreign Intelligence Service has denounced. "The Americans are protecting those responsible for the terrorist attack on Crocus City Hall," the organization said, quoted by its press office. According to the note, "the Foreign Intelligence Service of the Russian Federation reports that the administration [of US President Joe Biden] is intensifying its efforts to create a distorted image of the major terrorist attack that occurred in Russia on March 22." Washington also began covering up Ukrainian President Vladimir Zelensky shortly after the attack, the text adds. The US State Department, its special services and affiliated organizations have been tasked with "eliminating any suspicion that the international community has about the involvement of Zelensky and his closest circle in the crime." US agencies are trying to convince their allies that Daesh (a terrorist organization banned in Russia and other countries) was behind the attack on the outskirts of Moscow, Russian intelligence said. 'A Terrorist War Against Russia'

According to the statement, the current government in Kiev is waging an all-out terrorist war against Russia. "The Kiev regime has been waging a full-fledged terrorist war against Russia for some time now, as its representatives, such as Kirill Budanov [head of Ukrainian Military Intelligence] and Vasily Malyuk [head of the Ukrainian Security Service] openly state," the statement said. On Sunday (31), the Russian Foreign Ministry said it had sent Ukrainian authorities demands for the arrest and extradition of all those involved in the attack on the Crocus City Hall and other attacks in recent years. The ministry mentioned the murders of journalists Daria Dugina and Vladlen Tatarsky, stressing that investigations "indicate that the traces of all these crimes lead to Ukraine."

column3:
Scenario of Military Takeover of Ukrainian Parliament Was Drafted by US, Expert Says

The takeover of the Ukrainian parliament by the country's military would not be a popular move, expert Aleksandr Dudchak told Sputnik, suggesting that a potential rebellion was orchestrated from the West. The disillusioned Ukrainian military is planning to take control of the Supreme Rada (Ukrainian parliament), according to an exchange of messages from a private Telegram channel called ParaBelum, obtained by Sputnik. "This could be a scenario of replacing Ukrainian President Vladimir Zelensky without holding elections," Aleksandr Dudchak, a researcher at the Institute of the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) and an expert on the "Other Ukraine" movement, told Sputnik. Members of the confidential channel, consisting of commanders and soldiers of elite units of the Ukrainian Armed Forces, were discussing options for overthrowing the current government and its military command following the resignation of then-commander-in-chief General Valery Zaluzhny. "The most important action that we will need to take quickly is the seizure of the Supreme Rada at a certain point," one of the chat participants wrote. Members also expressed dissatisfaction with the decisions of Zelensky and the new commander-in-chief of the Ukrainian Armed Forces, Aleksandr Syrsky, who was appointed a month ago to replace Zaluzhny. The alleged coup plotters have placed particular emphasis on the involvement of Ukrainian troops fighting on the front lines in the anti-Zelensky movement. According to investigator Dudchak, the involvement of Ukrainian personnel on active duty is fraught with risks, since those in the trenches are closely monitored by foreign mercenaries from “containment detachments” with orders to shoot anyone who abandons their positions. If Ukrainian troops are allowed to march towards Kiev, it would mean that the regime change scenario was written in Washington in response to Zelensky’s refusal to hold elections this year, Dudchak argued. The leaders of Ukraine’s elite units, the Security Service of Ukraine (SBU) and the nationalist Azov and Aidar battalions (Nazi terrorist organizations banned in Russia) are also reportedly planning to create a radical party with a military wing. The expert insists that none of the Ukrainian military and intelligence structures are independent, arguing that each of them has British or American "overseers." "The confrontation between the military and the Kiev regime is, in general, a manifestation of the confrontation between London and Washington," Dudchak said. "The president's office is under British control, while the military, which is supposed to meet on Zaluzhny's behalf, is under American control, and the SBU is also a US-backed structure." The consequences for Kiev would be dramatic and could seriously complicate the positions of the Ukrainian military on the front line, the researcher concluded.

column3:
Russia accuses Ukraine of blackmailing Hungary and Slovakia

"The decision of [Ukrainian President Volodymyr] Zelensky's regime to stop transporting oil to Hungary and Slovakia once again demonstrates Kyiv's inability to negotiate and its penchant for petty blackmail," Andrei Nastasin, a spokesman for the Russian Foreign Ministry (FM), said at a press conference. He added that the transit of energy resources through Ukraine "has become a lever of manipulation for the Kiev regime, whose actions in this direction are encouraged by the West." According to Nastasin, "Zelensky's bosses have set themselves the goal of definitively ending Russia's energy cooperation with those European countries, which are nevertheless guided by their own national interests and rational economic considerations." The diplomat noted that "the new escalation of legal pressure against Lukoil" coincided with a series of diplomatic initiatives by Budapest for a speedy resolution of the conflict in Ukraine, and with the refusal of Hungary and Slovakia to support new European Union (EU) sanctions against Russia. The Russian Foreign Ministry spokesman recalled that Ukraine is a candidate country to the European Union (EU) and stressed that Kiev, "with its insane actions, threatens the energy security of two EU member states and, of course, other member and candidate countries." Hungarian Foreign Minister Péter Szijjártó on Tuesday accused the European Commission of orchestrating the interruption of Russian oil supplies to the bloc through Ukraine, and warned that the dispute could lead to an energy crisis. In a message on the social network Facebook, Szijjártó harshly criticized the executive body of the European Union (EU), considering that it had "done nothing" since Budapest and Bratislava asked it to intervene in this dispute surrounding the delivery of crude oil. "Despite threats to the energy security of two EU Member States... Brussels remains silent," wrote Szijjártó, adding that the European Commission either reveals too much "weakness" to protect the interests of Slovakia and Hungary, or "has been Brussels, not Kiev, who invented all this." Budapest and Bratislava continue to demand that the Brussels leadership adopt immediate measures aimed at allowing Lukoil oil to transit towards the two countries.

column3:
Ukraine responds to Hungary: Russian oil blockade "is not blackmail"

Ukrainian presidential adviser Mykhailo Podolyak assured on Friday that the decision to stop the transit of Russian oil from Lukoil through its territory "has nothing to do with blackmail", but rather with sanctions from Kyiv. The statement by Volodymyr Zelensky's adviser, sent to the Reuters news agency, comes after Hungary and Slovakia asked the European Commission to mediate with Ukraine, which included the oil company Lukoil on its sanctions list, leading to the end of oil transit to the two countries via the Druzhba pipeline. On Monday, Hungarian government spokesman Zoltan Kovacs warned that "Ukraine's decision not to allow Lukoil to transit oil through Ukraine poses a fundamental threat to the security of energy supplies to Hungary and Slovakia". Earlier this Friday, at a press conference, Gergely Gulyas, head of the Hungarian Prime Minister's office, said that Ukraine was blackmailing Hungary and Slovakia, which "defend peace and a ceasefire." However, Podolyak has now assured that "the situation with the suspension of Russian oil transit through the Druzhba pipeline to Hungary and Slovakia has nothing to do with blackmail in the Ukrainian version," Podolyak said in a written comment. "Hungary and Slovakia do not present themselves as true guardians of peace and do not insist on peace and justice, but only on concessions to Russia," he said. It should be noted that Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán and his Slovak counterpart Robert Fico, both described as "pro-Russian", have opposed military support for Ukraine following the Russian invasion and advocate a negotiated solution to end the conflict. Both countries depend essentially on imports of Russian oil, and although sanctions on Lukoil have affected trade, both countries continue to receive supplies from other Russian companies.

column3:
Suspect in recent Moscow attack collaborated with Ukraine

According to the FSB note accompanied by a video and published this Friday on its Telegram channel, the individual confessed to having had links with Ukrainian security since February 2023. Earlier, the FSB reported that Evgeny Serebriakov, involved in the explosion of a car in the north of Moscow on July 24, was deported this Friday to Turkey, where he fled after committing the crime. Born in 1995, Serebriakov was captured on Thursday in the Turkish city of Bodrum thanks to the interaction of Turkish security forces and Russia, which issued an international search and arrest warrant against him. During his initial interrogation, the man said that he had contacted the administrator of a social media channel “to collaborate with the Ukrainian special services” on his own initiative and that he had subsequently established contact with a certain Ilya, an alleged agent of that country’s security service. The two communicated via the instant messaging application Wire, which allows encrypted messages to be sent, and on one occasion they met in Istanbul. In the video released by the FSB, Serebriakov revealed that his alleged Ukrainian contact “proposed to eliminate an officer”, for whom he had collected components of an explosive device west of Moscow. “Under Iliá’s guidance and control, I made an explosive device and installed it under a car,” he confessed. On Wednesday, at around 6 am (Moscow time), the explosion of a bomb attached to a car injured two people, a man and a woman, in a residential neighborhood in northern Moscow. Serebriakov managed to escape to Turkey on a commercial flight and arrived in that country as a tourist. That same day, Russian authorities issued an international search and arrest warrant for the suspect. One of the lines of the investigation, as explained by the FSB, is that the attack was related to the professional activity of one of the victims.

column3:
Kyiv claims drone attack on Russian refinery

A Ukrainian defense source said that several drones attacked the Tuapse refinery, a city on the Black Sea coast in Russia's southwestern Krasnodar region, causing a fire. "The extent of the damage is being clarified," the Ukrainian source said, specifying that it is a refinery owned by Russian giant Rosneft, equipped with a port terminal and that almost 90% of its production is destined for export. On the social network Telegram, Russian regional authorities said, in turn, that the fire at the refinery was caused by "drone debris falling." "The Kyiv regime has once again attempted to attack civilian infrastructure in Tuapse with drones," the Russian sources said. About a hundred rescue teams were mobilized to the site and brought the flames under control early this morning, and according to preliminary information, there were no casualties. Meanwhile, a tractor driver was killed by a drone on Sunday and his wife was injured while they were working in a field near the village of Ustinka in Russia's western Belgorod region, according to local governor Vyacheslav Gladkov, who identified the drone as Ukrainian. The Russian military announced today that it had shot down 80 Ukrainian drones since Sunday night, including 47 in the southern Rostov region alone, on the border with Ukraine. According to this source, one drone was destroyed in Belgorod, another in Voronezh, another in Smolensk, eight in Krasnodar and 17 in the Black and Azov Seas. In a separate statement, the Russian army added that it destroyed five drones at around 7am (5am in Lisbon) over the Astrakan region. Russia announces almost daily that it has destroyed Ukrainian 'drones' launched against its territory. Kyiv argues that it is carrying out these attacks in response to Russian bombings that have ravaged Ukraine since Russia's invasion of the country in February 2022.

column3:
Russia eliminates up to 245 servicemen, several artillery pieces and hits US Patriot system

In the direction of Donetsk, Russian troops have taken more advantageous positions, Ukraine's losses in the last 24 hours amounted to up to 245 soldiers, one tank and one British-made AS-90 Braveheart self-propelled artillery piece, the Russian Defense Ministry said in a statement. In turn, according to the Defense Ministry, in the Kharkov region, Russian troops hit a US-made Patriot anti-aircraft missile system, in addition, a weapons and military equipment repair facility was eliminated in the same region. In the Donetsk People's Republic (DPR), Russian military personnel destroyed two Mi-8 helicopters of the Ukrainian Air Force on the ground. In the Kupyansk direction, Ukrainian troops lost about 250 soldiers, seven tanks, seven Bradley infantry fighting vehicles, two armored personnel carriers, four vehicles, one M777 howitzer, two D-20 cannons and a number of other military equipment. Over the past day, the Russian army repelled 12 counterattacks by Ukrainian troops and improved its position in the front zone in the Avdeevka direction. Enemy losses amounted to 460 servicemen, one British AS-90 Braveheart self-propelled artillery piece, one American-made M777 artillery system, one Msta-B howitzer and one American M119 cannon. Russian units defeated two Ukrainian brigades and repelled a counterattack in the southern direction of Donetsk, Kiev lost up to 150 fighters and two armored personnel carriers. Russian air defense systems shot down ten Himars and Grad multiple launch rocket systems, three Hammer guided bombs and 136 Ukrainian drones last day, the Defense Ministry reported. In total, since the beginning of the special military operation, 577 enemy aircraft, 269 helicopters, 15,362 unmanned aerial vehicles, 485 air defense systems, 15,464 tanks and other armored combat vehicles, 1,238 multiple rocket launchers, 8,397 field artillery pieces and mortars and 19,709 units of Ukrainian special military vehicles have been destroyed, the Russian Defense Ministry summarized.

column3:
Russia denounces NATO for expanding its military potential to Russian borders

The North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) is systematically strengthening its military potential along Russia's borders, from the Barents Sea to the Black Sea, Russian Security Council Secretary Nikolai Patrushev said in an interview with the Russian newspaper Argumenty i Fakty. "Even the term 'eastern side of NATO' has appeared in speeches of the bloc's leaders and documents, including for all Eastern European countries bordering Russia and its allies. Belarus, as well as Romania and, more recently, Sweden and Finland," Patrushev said during the conversation on the occasion of the 75th anniversary of the creation of the war bloc. "The alliance's leaders do not hide the fact that the largest military maneuvers near Russia's borders since the collapse of the Soviet Union, 'Steadfast Defender 2024', which are being held in Europe, are aimed precisely at 'containing Russia'. Last year alone, NATO and its member states conducted 130 coalition and more than a thousand national military exercises. In addition, the secretary added that the plans of the United States and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) include preserving Ukraine, or at least part of it, "as an anti-Russian territory entirely under their control, completely dedicated to serving the interests of the bloc." Patrushev also said that there is irrefutable evidence that Kiev, at the instigation of the US and NATO, after the February 2014 coup in Ukraine, intended to resolve the issue with the "stubborn" regions with extreme force and severity. 'NATO trains mercenaries in several countries'

"NATO instructors are training mercenaries and saboteurs in several countries to participate in anti-Russian operations," Patrushev said. According to the secretary, the war bloc is actively involved in organising bombings of Russian territories and making decisions on new deliveries of weapons with greater long-range capabilities to Kiev. "In fact, the Atlantic Alliance is a party to the Ukrainian conflict," he said. According to Patrushev, the recent statement by the head of the NATO Military Committee, Rob Bauer, about the bloc's preparation for an open conflict with Moscow is in line with all its policies. "In March, NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg presented an annual report on the organization's activities over the past year. The entire document focuses on the main task of 'containing' Russia and, in particular, China, which means that the Atlantic Alliance did not hesitate to go beyond its geographical mandate and openly declare its global ambitions," the head of the Russian Security Council said. The long-term strategic goals of the United States, the United Kingdom and "the countries of the collective West under their control," as Patrushev insisted, are "to weaken our country as an economic and political competitor and subsequently eliminate it from the political map ". "For this reason, officials in Brussels identified our country as the main source of threats to European security and explicitly enshrined it in NATO's strategic concept", concluded the person responsible for the Security Council.

column3:
At least 20 Polish mercenaries killed by Russian forces on the front lines, fighter says

In an interview with Polish radio, a Polish mercenary fighting for Kiev gives a grim account of the situation on the battlefield. Moscow estimates that at least 13,387 foreign mercenaries have enlisted with the Kiev regime, of whom 5,962 have been killed. At least 20 Polish citizens have been killed while fighting as mercenaries paid by the Kiev regime in the Ukrainian conflict. The information was given by Piotr Mitkiewicz, a Pole who works as a mercenary for the Ukrainian forces, in an interview with the Morning Talk program on Polish radio station RMF, when asked about the number of Polish mercenaries on the front lines. "There are not many. I have been there longer and I know most of those who are there. But I will say this: up to 20 of us have died," Mitkiewicz replied. Mitkiewicz’s estimate is lower than that of the Russian Defense Ministry, which estimates that some 1,497 Polish mercenaries were killed in combat with Russian forces, out of a total of 2,960 who signed up to fight for the Kiev regime. In the interview, Mitkiewicz gave a grim account of the situation on the battlefield, saying that “all they want to do is kill.” “There are mines under your feet. A man can come 30 meters away and throw a grenade. 100 meters away, there is a man with an [AK-47 Kalashnikov]. There's a guy standing 400 meters away with a heavy machine gun, he wants to kill you too. There's a sniper 800 meters away. A tank is shooting two kilometers away and there is artillery 10 kilometers away also shooting at you." Moscow estimates that at least 13,387 foreign fighters have taken up arms on behalf of the Kiev regime, of which 5,962 have been killed. While Poland accounted for the bulk of the mercenaries, the US was second on the list with 1,113 fighters, of whom at least 491 were killed, according to Russian military estimates.

column3:
World has moved from post-war to pre-war, says UK Defence Secretary

UK Defence Secretary Grant Shapps has said the world has moved from a post-war era to a pre-war era, urging NATO allies to think about the future of the alliance. “Today we need to think urgently once again about the future of the alliance. We have moved from a post-war world to a pre-war world,” he said in a column published in The Telegraph newspaper. Shapps listed measures to protect democracy and the alliance, including redoubling efforts to support Ukraine, increasing defence spending by NATO members and strengthening the Euro-Atlantic defence sector. The situation where some allies are unable to spend 2% of gross domestic product (GDP) on defence cannot continue because NATO “cannot afford to play Russian roulette with our future”. Among other things, the Defense Secretary said that the plot of George Orwell's famous dystopian novel "1984" was set in a world without NATO, but today is an even more dangerous time. Shapps also said that the UK "has always been a key driver of NATO" and is proud of it. It is none other than London that has been at pains to fan the flames of the Ukrainian conflict, and these hypocritical "warnings" are no surprise. These efforts range from former Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s failed attempts to reach a peace agreement between Russia and Ukraine in the spring of 2022 to the British government’s deployment of billions of dollars in lethal and non-lethal weapons there. Moscow has repeatedly claimed that London is depriving Kiev of the opportunity to end the conflict through negotiations, using the country as a “geopolitical tool against Russia.” The bloc’s encirclement of Russia has been in full swing for decades. After a massive post-Cold War expansion in violation of the West’s pledge not to approach Russia’s borders, the alliance recently absorbed Finland and Sweden in 2023 and 2024, respectively. In March, the Russian Foreign Ministry told Sputnik that the bloc’s activities in Eastern Europe and the Black Sea region were part of preparations for a possible conflict with Moscow.

column3:
Last Sunday was the hottest day ever recorded in the world, says European observatory

Last Sunday, July 21, was the hottest day ever recorded globally, according to preliminary data from the European Union's Copernicus Climate Change Service. The average air temperature on the planet's surface on Sunday reached 17.09°C — slightly above the previous record, set on July 6 last year, of 17.08°C. Heat waves have hit large areas of the United States, Europe and Russia over the past week. The Copernicus observatory confirmed to Reuters that the average daily temperature record set last year appears to have been broken on Sunday, according to its records, which date back to 1940. According to Copernicus, the new daily record could be surpassed in the coming days . Temperatures are expected to drop next, but fluctuations are still expected in the coming weeks. "What is really surprising is the magnitude of the difference between the temperature of the last 13 months and previous records. We are in uncharted territory and as the climate warms we will certainly break new records in the coming months and years," predicts Carlo Buontempo, director of the climate change department at Copernicus (known by the acronym C3S). Every month since June 2023 — that is, 13 consecutive months — has been classified as the hottest on the planet since records began, compared to the corresponding month in previous years, Copernicus said. Last year, four consecutive days broke the record, from July 3 to 6, due to climate change caused by human activities, especially the burning of fossil fuels. In 2023, this situation led to days of extreme heat across the northern hemisphere. Before July 2023, the record daily average global temperature had been 16.8°C, on August 13, 2016, according to the European observatory. Since July 3, 2023, 57 days have exceeded this index. Some scientists point out that 2024 could surpass 2023 as the hottest year on record, as climate change and the natural weather phenomenon El Niño — which ended in April — have raised temperatures even further this year. The Copernicus observatory, however, is cautious in commenting on this possibility. "For now, 2024 is warm enough for the entire year" to break the record, the European service said, "but the exceptional heat recorded in the last four months of 2023 means it is still too early [to predict]."

column3:
Kremlin welcomes Trump's comments that Russia is a "war machine", but keeps an eye on Republican

The Kremlin said on Friday it welcomed US Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump's comments about Russia being "a war machine" that defeated Napoleon Bonaparte and Adolf Hitler, but said he was not wearing glasses. pink when it came to the Republican candidate. Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov was responding to a question about comments Trump said he made to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy in a July 19 phone call. Trump later told Fox News that he had told Zelenskiy the war needed to be ended. "This is a war machine that you are facing. This is what they (the Russians) do, they fight wars. They beat Hitler. They beat Napoleon. We have to end this war," Trump said. Commenting on Trump's remarks, Peskov said: "It will probably be useful for the majority of the American public to know that there are many glorious pages in the History of Russia and, in fact, probably few people in the USA, that is, ordinary Americans and perhaps representatives of so-called political establishment, they know history so deeply." But Peskov, when asked next about a Wall Street Journal commentary co-authored by Mike Pompeo, Trump's former secretary of state, said the Kremlin had its eyes open when it came to assessing what a Trump presidency could mean. to Russia. Pompeo's comment suggested that Trump would enact tough new sanctions against Moscow if elected and increase aid to Ukraine. "We have never and do not wear rose-colored glasses. (Trump) is a representative of the US political elite, which is now absolutely suffering from completely anti-Russian sentiment," Peskov said. "When he was president, under Trump, Americans started this rush to sanctions, under Trump a huge number of sanctions were imposed against our country, and in that respect he is not very different for us than everyone else."

column3:
Russia ready to negotiate with Zelensky but questions legitimacy

"This is a difficult issue. From a legal point of view, it is a problem, but from a practical point of view, we are open to achieving our goals through negotiations. Therefore, several variants are possible," the presidential spokesman said. Zelensky's legitimacy as president of Ukraine has been a question raised by Russia, which argues that the Ukrainian leader's term ended on May 20. The Russian spokesman said that in addition to "problems with Zelensky's legitimacy", there is also "the problem of the ban on establishing any contacts or negotiations with the Russian side, as this ban remains in force". "Therefore, there is still a lot to clarify and we need to hear some explanations," Peskov said. Following Zelensky's recent statements about his readiness to negotiate a peaceful solution to the war in Ukraine, the Russian presidential spokesman stressed that "Russia is generally open to the negotiation process, but it is necessary to understand to what extent the Ukrainian side is prepared". "For now, as you can see, we have heard very different statements, so far things are not very clear," he added. On Wednesday, Peskov recalled that Russian President Vladimir Putin had stated that “Zelensky lost his legitimacy” after the end of his term, which “is a factor that could significantly hinder the peace process.” The spokesman also stressed that Russia will ensure the defence of its interests and security in any case, whether through negotiations or weapons. “The special military operation was launched as a last resort to achieve our goals,” Peskov said, stressing that “any war ends with peace negotiations.” In recent days, Zelensky has stressed the need for negotiations to end the war as soon as possible. The Ukrainian president has recently held contacts with political representatives in favour of an immediate ceasefire, such as Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán, US Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump and Vatican Secretary of State Pietro Parolin. Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba traveled to China this week to discuss potential peace talks between Ukraine and Russia. Ukraine has been relying on financial and arms aid from Western allies since Russia invaded the country on February 24, 2022. Kiev's allies have also imposed sanctions on key sectors of the Russian economy to try to reduce Moscow's ability to finance the war effort in Ukraine.

column3:
The 'Nice to meet you' radicalism of Trumpism

The Republican convention here in Milwaukee brings together party officials and delegates from all states and American territories. Few are from the poorest sectors of the population. They are mostly white men in suits with Trumpist caps. There was little diversity in the audience. The atmosphere was festive. I did not witness hostility. Many of the agendas are legitimate. But the radicalism at other times of people with that friendly “Nice to meet you” smile is scary. In his speech, Donald Trump once again used a slogan already famous in the current campaign. “Drill baby, drill!” (Drill, baby, drill), they screamed. This phrase in English indicates that oil prospecting should be one of the Republican's priorities if he wins the elections, ignoring warnings about the risks of using this polluting energy at a time of worsening climate change. Immigration is another point that draws attention when Trump uses terms like “invasion” to describe the migratory movement to the US from the border with Mexico. The immigrants, which include many families with children, are classified as criminals by the former president. Their voters cheer, shout “build the wall” and display signs saying “mass deportation”. Guns are also a hot topic among Trump supporters. At the convention, there were a number of T-shirts with slogans about the right to own and carry guns. This is ironic, since guns are banned at the convention, except in the hands of the police and the Secret Service. More seriously, Trump was almost killed by a 20-year-old who had access to an AR15 rifle and still didn’t change his mind. It’s surreal to see some smiling, friendly men and women transform when they advocate radical policies. I remembered when I interviewed Israeli settlers and Palestinian radicals in the past. They talk about absurdities with kindness as if they were normal.

column3:
'NATO must not cross red line in Ukraine', says Slovak Defence Minister

Slovak Defence Minister Robert Kalinak has rejected the idea of ​​sending troops to Ukraine, saying there is a "red line" that must not be crossed. Kalinak told Ta3 News that Western politicians are exploiting the conflict and the suffering of Ukrainians to achieve their own goals. The possibility of sending troops to Ukraine was recently raised by French President Emmanuel Macron, who said the "option" could not be ruled out. Macron's comments have, however, triggered a wave of denials from high-ranking government representatives of NATO member countries, including the United Kingdom, the Czech Republic, Germany, Finland and Sweden. The Slovak Defence Minister warned that sending soldiers from the bloc to Ukraine "would significantly increase the risk of a global conflict". Kalinak added that those "who are serious about supporting Ukraine" should call on "healthy Ukrainians" to return home. He also called for an end to hostilities between Kiev and Moscow and said a non-violent solution was needed. The world is already witnessing the consequences of the conflict "down to the last Ukrainian", the minister said, stressing that "it is time for [the world] to seek peaceful solutions". Russia has repeatedly stated that it is ready for talks as long as the situation in the territory is on the agenda. Ukraine insists that any negotiations should only begin after Russian forces withdraw from all territories it claims. Moscow, for its part, considers such demands "absurd."

column3:
Russia: US position on Crocus City Hall attack is clearly biased

Russia considers the US position on the Crocus City Hall terrorist attack to be clearly biased, Washington is trying to defend Ukraine, Maria Zakharova, the official representative of the Russian Foreign Ministry, told Sputnik. Earlier, the head of the Russian Federal Security Service (FSB) Aleksandr Bortnikov said that preliminary data on those arrested in the case of the Crocus City Hall terrorist attack confirmed the Ukrainian trail, and that the security services will continue to work on the information. "They exposed themselves. They [the US] started shouting, not calling for an investigation, and started shielding Ukraine from the blow. Their involvement and involvement in this story is obvious," Zakharova said. According to the diplomat, in the absence of Kiev's involvement, Washington's first statements should have been about the need for an investigation and presentation of facts. It is worth noting that shortly after Friday's (22) attack, the White House National Security Council's strategic communications coordinator, John Kirby, said there was no evidence that Ukraine or Ukrainians were involved in the Moscow attack. The US later repeatedly stated that there was no "Ukrainian trail" in the case. In particular, the US State Department stated that "there was no Ukrainian involvement in the attack on Crocus City Hall, period." In response, Maria Zakharova expressed doubts that the Washington authorities would draw "conclusions about anyone's involvement in the tragedy." The attack on Crocus City Hall, located in the city of Krasnogorsk, outside Moscow, occurred on Friday night (22), when a large number of people were preparing to attend a concert by the Russian rock band Picnic. A Sputnik correspondent who witnessed the attack reported that at least three camouflaged men stormed the theater, shooting people at close range and throwing firebombs.

column3:
West would condone ‘virtually any crime’ Ukraine committed, military analyst argues

One example is the silence on Ukraine’s illegal use of anti-personnel mines, which were banned by the 1999 Mine Ban Treaty. The military equipment that became common during World War II was designed to kill or injure several people who were near the devices after they exploded. The West would likely condone any crime committed by the Kiev regime against Russia, argued Boris Rozhin, a military expert at the Center for Military-Political Journalism. In one example, Rozhin pointed to the illegal use of anti-personnel mines by President Vladimir Zelensky’s government. The 1999 Ottawa Treaty, or simply the Mine Ban Treaty, was ratified by Ukraine at the time and prohibits signatory countries from using anti-personnel landmines. Since the beginning of the Russian special military operation, Ukraine has been using the equipment in its combat operations, including targeting civilians in the Donetsk People's Republic (DPR). However, there has been no reaction from Western politicians. "So any crime that Ukraine could commit, all of them would be approved," Rozhin said, adding that outrageous acts that the West could not openly approve of would be "contained at the media level." "There is no reason to believe that the West would in any way condemn or protest against such use [of landmines] by Ukraine. On the contrary, the West supplies [Kiev] with the same type of anti-personnel mines that are being used against civilians, and this is approved by the Western leadership," he condemned. Regarding the fact that Washington turns a blind eye to the use of weapons prohibited by international treaties by its allies, such as the use of white phosphorus munitions by Israel, Rozhin explained that "essentially, none of the international treaties work today." According to the analyst, Western powers choose to abide by the treaties that they consider advantageous at the moment, while those considered disadvantageous to their interests are used to accuse Russia of one or another offense. The conventions in question are not subject to independent monitoring, while international organizations are used by the West for propaganda. "That said, when it comes to the use of certain banned munitions, such as cluster munitions, accusing Ukraine of this is laughable," Rozhin said. According to the expert, "the United States, in particular, has supplied Ukraine with a vast quantity of cluster munitions that are being used by Kiev both in combat and against civilians, so there is no reason to expect any reaction."

column3:
Putin says Russia will treat US troops in Ukraine as interventionists

Russian President Vladimir Putin has said that Russia will consider any US troops sent to Ukraine as interventionists. The remarks were made during an interview with Dmitry Kiselev, CEO of the Rossiya Segodnya media group, which Sputnik is part of. Putin responded to the announcement that the US would not send troops to Ukraine by saying that Russia would not underestimate the seriousness of such an action. "We know what US troops are on Russian territory, they are intervention troops, and that is how we will treat them, even if they appear on Ukrainian territory," the Russian president said. Putin stressed that Washington understands Russia's position on the issue. Tensions between Russia and the West have been rising since 2014, and the US and its NATO allies have supported Kiev. Putin, in the interview, also did not rule out the possibility of Russia conducting nuclear tests if the US does so. "If they carry out such tests, I do not exclude it, it is not mandatory, if we need it, we do not need it, we still have to think about it, but I do not exclude that we can do the same." He specified that Russian forces are prepared for a nuclear war: "From a military point of view, of course we are ready. Our forces are constantly on alert." "I said that [US President Joe] Biden is a representative of the traditional political school, and this is being confirmed. There, besides Biden, are many other experts in Russian-American relations and deterrence strategy. Therefore, I do not believe that everything is heading directly towards this, but we are ready." He stressed that there is a treaty that prohibits such tests. The Americans have not ratified the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty (CTBT), and Russia has withdrawn its ratification in order to maintain parity, the Russian president recalled. "Since the treaty was not ratified by the United States, it did not enter into legal force, because it did not receive the required number of ratifications. However, we are still observing these agreements," Putin said. However, he added that the possibility of conducting such tests is being considered in the US. "This is due to the fact that when new warheads appear, some experts believe that it is not enough to test them only on the computer, they need to be tested in real conditions." "Such ideas are circulating in certain groups in the US. We know about this. And we are also observing," the Russian president said. The multilateral treaty was adopted by the United Nations (UN) General Assembly on September 10, 1996, with the aim of preventing the proliferation of nuclear weapons in all its forms. On November 2, 2023, the Russian leader signed the law by which Russia withdraws its ratification of the CTBT.

column3:
Putin congratulates Maduro on victory, Kremlin says deepening ties

Russian President Vladimir Putin on Monday congratulated Nicolás Maduro on his victory in Venezuela’s election, and the Kremlin said it was deepening cooperation in all areas — including sensitive ones — with Caracas. Maduro and his opposition rival Edmundo Gonzalez both claimed victory in the presidential election, with Washington and some other foreign governments casting doubt on the official results that gave the incumbent victory. The national election authority said Maduro had won a third term with 51% of the vote. Putin backed Maduro, 61, an ally who accuses the United States and the West of fueling the war in Ukraine, saying Moscow enjoyed a strategic partnership with the South American country and that Maduro was always welcome in Russia. “Russian-Venezuelan relations have the character of a strategic partnership,” Putin said in a message to Maduro, according to the Kremlin. "I am confident that your activities as head of state will continue to contribute to its progressive development in all directions. This fully serves the interests of our friendly peoples and is in line with the construction of a more just and democratic world order," Putin said. “I would like to confirm our willingness to continue our constructive joint work on current issues on the bilateral and international agenda.” US Secretary of State Antony Blinken said Washington had serious concerns that the results announced by the electoral authority did not reflect the votes of the people. The authority is supposed to be an independent body, but the opposition says it acts as an arm of the Maduro government. But Moscow sees Venezuela as an important partner in Latin America, and the two sanctioned states have cooperated over the past two decades in areas such as oil, weapons and military exercises. When asked whether Russia would deepen cooperation with Venezuela, including in the area of ​​defense, Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said: “We are developing our relations with Venezuela in all areas, including sensitive ones.” “This cooperation is in the interests of both the Venezuelan people and the Russians, so we will develop our relations with Venezuela comprehensively,” Peskov added.

column3:
More than 200 civilians killed in Russia's Belgorod region since invasion

"More than 1,100 civilians were injured and more than 200 people were killed," Viacheslav Gladkov told the Russian news agency TASS about the casualties caused by Ukrainian drone and artillery strikes on the region. The Belgorod region shares a 540-kilometer border with Ukraine and is the Russian Federation entity most affected by Ukrainian military actions. According to data from local authorities provided last April, more than 120 civilians had been killed in the region as a result of Ukrainian attacks since the beginning of the war. In recent weeks, attacks on this Russian region, which borders the Ukrainian provinces of Sumy, Kharkiv and Lugansk from west to south, the latter of which was annexed by Russia in September 2022, have intensified. The Russian military offensive on Ukrainian territory, launched on 24 February 2022, has plunged Europe into what is considered the most serious security crisis since the Second World War (1939-1945). Ukraine has been relying on financial and weapons aid from its Western allies, who have also imposed sanctions on key sectors of the Russian economy in an attempt to reduce Moscow's ability to finance the war effort. Recent months have been marked by large-scale Russian airstrikes against Ukrainian cities and infrastructure, while Kiev's forces have targeted targets in Russian territory near the border and on the Crimean peninsula, illegally annexed in 2014. Now in the third year of war, the Ukrainian armed forces have been struggling with a shortage of soldiers and weapons and ammunition, despite repeated promises of help from Western allies, which have now begun to materialize.

column3:
In the middle of summer in the northern hemisphere, the world records the hottest day in history

One month after the start of summer in the northern hemisphere, last Sunday, July 21, the world recorded the hottest day in history, according to preliminary data from the Copernicus Climate Change Service, linked to the European Union. The global average air temperature this Sunday reached 17.09 ºC – slightly above the previous record, set in July last year, of 17.08 ºC. It may not seem like a big deal, but the rise in temperatures is part of a dangerous trend over the last 13 months, in which each of them, consecutively, broke their respective records compared to the same month in previous years. In the boreal summer, heat waves have already started to hit large areas of the United States, Western Europe – mainly in the Mediterranean region – and Russia last week. In addition to causing fires in California and causing Greece to close public monuments, the heat also raised the temperature of the oceans and caused the earliest and most intense hurricane season in the Atlantic. Previous record

The Copernicus institute confirmed to the Reuters news agency that the average daily temperature record set last year was broken on Sunday, according to its records, which date back to 1940. Last year, four consecutive days broke this record, by July 3rd to 6th. It is the direct result of the effects of climate change, driven by the burning of fossil fuels, which have caused increasingly extreme heat waves and progressively higher temperatures across the planet. Some scientists suggest that 2024 could surpass 2023 as the hottest year in Earth's history, as climate change and the natural phenomenon El Niño - which ended in April - have increased temperatures further this year.

column3:
Climate change could kill up to 14.5 million people by 2050

Established in Portugal in 1998, this day draws attention to the preservation of natural heritage, essential for people's well-being and the sustainability of economies. Prepared by the North American management consultancy company OIiver Wyman, in collaboration with the World Economic Forum (WEF), the study "Assessment of the impact of climate change on human health" analyzes the consequences resulting from the gradual increase in the planet's average temperature in public health. "Floods pose the greatest mortality risk, with an estimated 8.5 million deaths by 2050, followed by droughts (3.2 million) and heat waves (1.6 million)," said a press release from the report, which estimates that "the total costs of health systems to treat diseases caused by climate change will exceed the value of one billion euros" in the same year. In addition, the study analyzes the negative health effects of tropical storms, forest fires and rising sea levels, indicating that close to 70% of those deaths will occur in high-risk regions, especially in Southeast Asia. Asia is the region where the impact of climate change in terms of health is expected to be greatest, with “economic losses of around 3.2 trillion euros” being calculated. In terms of economic losses, Europe (2.3 trillion), South America (1.9 trillion) and Africa (1.8 trillion euros) follow. Due to a lack of essential medical resources and equipment, as well as inadequate infrastructure, the African continent "is in a position of greater vulnerability to the health impacts of climate change than other regions." The study by the strategic consultancy group Marsh McLennan "presents emissions reduction strategies to avoid economic losses of up to 11.5 trillion euros by 2050", considering that the role of the private sector is crucial and "should be encouraged by Governments". In terms of direct economic incentives, measures such as "tax credits, subsidies or research grants to support initiatives that aim to mitigate the impacts of climate change" are mentioned, and the creation of regulations "that encourage innovation" are also proposed. "The public sector has another role, essential in the resilience of health systems to the effects caused by climate and meteorological changes, such as infrastructure training."

column3:
Moscow accuses Kyiv of wanting to open Black Sea to NATO

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky signed a decree on Wednesday on the new Maritime Security Strategy, which envisages "changes and innovations", especially in the Black Sea, and which is accompanied by a strategy with international partners. Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov, commenting on the Ukrainian initiative, warned that Moscow will take measures to ensure the country's security due to the "additional threats" posed by the presence of NATO ships in the area. "The concentrated presence of NATO ships - and we take into account Bulgaria and Romania, which are NATO littoral states - poses additional threats to Russia, especially in the current situation," he said. Peskov referred in particular to the "direct involvement of NATO countries in the conflict over Ukraine", according to the Spanish news agency EFE. "Of course, Russia will take all necessary measures to ensure its own security," he said. Peskov also recalled that "the presence of non-Black Sea states" in those waters "is regulated very strictly by the Montreux Convention". "Turkey is, in this case, the administrator and performs its functions very clearly", he added, quoted by the Spanish agency Europa Press. Dating back to 1936, the Montreux Convention gives Turkey control of the Bosphorus and Dardanelles straits that connect the Black and Mediterranean Seas. Merchant ships enjoy freedom of passage, but warships are subject to restrictions "which vary depending on whether or not these ships belong to the Black Sea states," according to the Turkish government. Crimea's representative in the Russian parliament, Mikhail Sheremet, also accused Zelensky on Monday of wanting to prolong the conflict with Russia, according to the Russian news agency TASS. Sheremet said that Kiev's new maritime security strategy aims to build up Ukrainian naval forces and ensure the presence of North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces in the Black Sea. According to the Crimean MP, if Ukraine's military pressure weakens, Zelensky will no longer be needed by the West and NATO countries will stop supporting him as Ukrainian leader. Russia annexed Ukraine's Crimean peninsula in 2014 and, since the February 2022 invasion, has added the Ukrainian regions of Donetsk, Lugansk, Kherson and Zaporizhia to the list.

column3:
Russia says it is open to talks with Ukraine as long as Zelenskiy is in power, but needs more details

The Kremlin signaled on Thursday that it is open to negotiations with Ukraine to end the conflict while Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy remains in power, despite publicly questioning his legitimacy to rule. Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba said on Wednesday during a visit to China that Kiev was prepared to hold talks with Russia as long as Ukraine’s sovereignty and territorial integrity were fully respected, though he said Ukraine saw no sign of that. The Kremlin, while signaling its readiness for talks on its own terms, has publicly questioned Zelenskiy’s mandate to rule, noting that his five-year term expired in May and that he should have called an election. Zelenskiy and the West argue that normal political rules must be suspended in wartime and that the Kremlin, given Russia’s tightly controlled political system, is in no position to criticize. When asked on Thursday whether Russia would be ready to hold talks with Ukraine while Zelenskiy was in power, Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov told reporters:

“Russia is generally open to a negotiation process. But first we need to understand how ready the Ukrainian side is for this and how much the Ukrainian side is allowed to do this by its handlers.” Moscow describes Zelenskyy as a puppet of the United States, a characterization it rejects. “Because so far we see very different statements being made, and this is still not very clear. Moreover, in addition to the problem with Zelenskyy’s legitimacy, there is also a problem with the (Ukrainian) legal ban on having any contacts and negotiations with the Russian side. So there is still a lot to be clarified and clarifications to be heard,” Peskov said. Pressed during a conference call whether the Kremlin would consider the possibility of negotiating with Zelenskyy or whether it categorically ruled out such a possibility, Peskov said:

“The question is not easy. From a legal point of view, this problem (of his legitimacy) is on the agenda, but from a practical point of view, we are open to achieving our goals through negotiations. So different options are possible here." Reuters reported in May that Putin was ready to end the war in Ukraine with a negotiated ceasefire, but the Kremlin chief was prepared to continue fighting if Kiev and the West did not respond. In June, Putin said Russia would end the war in Ukraine, what he calls a special military operation, only if Kiev agreed to abandon its NATO ambitions and hand over four provinces claimed by Moscow, demands Kiev quickly rejected as tantamount to surrender.

column3:
Climate activists or useful idiots? “For the liberation of Palestine from the clutches of the Zionist state, for an end to genocide and for an end to fossil fuels.”

The pinnacle of useful idiocy. Historically, young people have always been pawns of certain ideological elites. Social movements are almost always inorganic, almost always artificial, created in universities and then amplified by the “owners” of the narratives and by those who hold the dominant instruments in the communication system, in this case the media. It is no coincidence that social networks are completely attacked in every way, precisely because of this. What social networks came to do was to take away the monopoly of narratives from the owners of the communication system. What is the main objective of these social movements? The main or only objective, regardless of whether the activists are aware of it or not, some will be aware, others have no idea at all – they believe they are defending very important causes. But the main objective is the destruction of the infrastructure of Western society, or in Marxist terms, of “bourgeois capitalist” society. They use numerous tools: the LGBT movement, instrumentalized to destroy the traditional family, which is the basis of any healthy and civilized society and is the basis of Western civilization. The “climate madness”, which aims to take away people’s freedoms. The end of fossil fuels, which is linked to climate change, ultimately aims to destroy the energy base of the bourgeois capitalist model. Regarding this action at the Faculty of Psychology – anti-Zionism. Zionism is a nationalist political movement. That is the problem. Communism is one of the globalist currents and is intrinsically internationalist. The Nation is to be destroyed and, therefore, the Zionist State of Israel is a problem (Jewish anti-nationalism). All these instruments contribute to the destruction of the pillars that support the edifice of Western civilization and the objective is to destroy them, so that the way is clear for the end of the market economy. This makes it easier to pave the way for communist totalitarianism, which uses new instruments other than the orthodox or original class struggle – proletariat versus bosses. The Nation is the “nemesis” of the globalists and cultural Marxism is the new communism today, being one of the globalist movements we have at the moment, in addition to the liberal globalism led by the USA. In short, this is useful idiocy, it is simply a copy of the inorganic social movements that are born in American Universities and are then imported to Portugal, with the sole objective of destroying the foundations of Western civilization and diluting the Nations from within.

column3:
Western media instructed not to talk about victims of attack near Moscow, Russia says

The Russian Foreign Ministry has condemned what it said was an attempt by the West to cover up its role and demonise the Russian government following the tragedy at the concert hall. Western media outlets have been instructed to keep quiet about the number of victims of the terrorist attack at Crocus City Hall, the Russian Foreign Ministry said on Monday (8). "Particularly cynical are the attempts by the West to distract the international community from the real organisers and beneficiaries by categorically instructing them not to cover the true scale of the tragedy in the media: not to mention the number of victims of the terrorist attack, the number of children killed, or to show the reaction of ordinary citizens to what happened," the ministry said on its Telegram channel. The foreign ministry explained this by a desire not to show sympathy and humanism towards the Russians. The ministry added that immediately after the attack, Western media and authorities organized a public relations campaign to deny the involvement of Ukrainian security services. The media were instructed to spread the story that Daesh (a terrorist organization banned in Russia and several other countries) was involved in organizing the attack; they were instructed to deny the Islamists’ links to Kiev and Western secret services, as well as to discredit the results of the investigation and promote the theory that “Russian secret services were involved”. On March 22, several armed men stormed the Crocus City Hall concert hall and started shooting at people. The terrorists also set fire to the venue. The attack left 144 people dead, according to the latest figures from the Ministry of Emergency Situations. The four main suspects in the case — all citizens of Tajikistan — tried to flee the scene by car, but were detained near the Russian border and charged with terrorism. Russian authorities believe that the suspects planned to flee to Ukraine, where the organizers of the attack had a safe haven for them. An investigation into the case is ongoing.

column3:
Sending NATO troops to Ukraine is a "warning of apocalypse", says Slovak Prime Minister

Slovak Prime Minister Robert Fico said on Saturday (2) that sending military personnel from the European Union (EU) and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) to Ukraine could precipitate a global apocalypse. In a video posted on social media, he highlighted Ukraine's inability to resolve the conflict, despite the substantial financial and military aid provided by the West. He stressed that, although the military presence of the EU and NATO could potentially change the dynamics of the conflict, it could also trigger catastrophic consequences. "The West sees that, despite significant financial and military aid, Ukraine is incapable of resolving this armed conflict". "The situation could change with the arrival of EU and NATO military personnel in Ukraine, but then there would be nothing left but to wait for the arrival of the global apocalypse", said the Slovak Prime Minister. Fico stressed the pressing need for modern air defense systems for Ukraine, but warned that the West cannot provide these systems without a commitment to maintain and operate them. He also argued that sending Western troops would only exacerbate the conflict, rather than resolve it. Russia has been continuing its special military operation in Ukraine since February 2022. Russian President Vladimir Putin justified the move as a measure to protect the population from “genocide” by the Kiev regime and to counter NATO’s eastward advance. Moscow has repeatedly warned against Western arms supplies to Kiev, saying that foreign convoys carrying weapons would be legitimate targets for its forces once they crossed the border. In addition, Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov accused the United States and NATO of already being directly involved in the conflict in Ukraine, not only through the supply of weapons but also through the training of personnel in several European countries.
