column3:
Russia held secret meetings with the US about the war in Ukraine

Sergei Lavrov confirmed “never-disclosed contacts” with Americans. They did not produce the desired result. Russia held secret meetings with the US to try to end the war in Ukraine. Sergei Lavrov, Russia’s Foreign Minister, confirmed that a group of Russian political scientists and experts met with US experts. “We had never-before-disclosed contacts with Americans, through political scientists who knew and understood the governments’ policies,” Lavrov announced on the sidelines of the United Nations Security Council. The statement was quoted this Thursday by Folha de S. Paulo, the newspaper that reported on these attempts at a peace agreement in March. The meetings served as a sort of screening of what was acceptable to both countries – but Ukraine never had representatives at these meetings. The governments of Russia and the US authorized these meetings, even though they were not official. The negotiations lasted just over a year, but according to the Russian minister, they did not produce the desired result. In practice, they were of no use. Sergei Lavrov only shared one more topic addressed in these meetings: the status of ethnic Russians within Ukraine. It is worth remembering that Russian President Vladimir Putin had said before the war that Russian culture was being pushed aside in Ukraine, for example with the law restricting the use of the Russian language in the Ukrainian education system. Until now, there have only been official meetings between Russians and Ukrainians at the very beginning of the war. But, like these, these negotiations, first in Belarus and then in Turkey, did not end in a peace agreement – ​​and have never been held again.

column3:
Russia denies openness to negotiating Kiev's accession to NATO in exchange for territories

Citing sources close to the Kremlin, the Bloomberg news agency had reported that Russian President Vladimir Putin was trying to understand whether Washington was in favour of starting talks on ending the war in Ukraine. Russia denied this Friday that President Vladimir Putin had expressed any willingness to the United States to negotiate Ukraine's entry into NATO in exchange for Russian control over the territories annexed in the neighbouring country. "This information is wrong and does not coincide at all with reality," said the spokesman for the Russian Presidency (Kremlin), Dmitry Peskov, at the usual daily press conference. Previously, and citing sources close to the Kremlin, the Bloomberg news agency had reported that Russian President Vladimir Putin was trying to understand whether Washington was in favour of starting talks on ending the war in Ukraine. According to two sources cited by Bloomberg, the Russian leader had sent signals to the United States of America (USA) about a possible willingness by Moscow to engage in dialogue. According to information provided by the news agency, the Kremlin leader may be willing to consider Ukraine's eventual accession to the Atlantic Alliance, provided that Kiev accepts the new "territorial realities", referring to the Ukrainian regions annexed by Moscow. Until now, Ukraine has always opposed making territorial concessions to Moscow or freezing the conflict because, according to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, this would only benefit Moscow. Russia wants international assessment of military plane downing

The Kremlin also criticized Western countries for failing to condemn the downing of the Russian Il-76 military transport plane, which was carrying Ukrainian prisoners and which Moscow says was Ukraine's responsibility, during Thursday's meeting of the United Nations Security Council. "So far, there is no categorical condemnation from Western countries of this horrific terrorist attack. We have not heard a single word of condemnation," Peskov said. According to the Kremlin spokesman, "this event requires a proper assessment by the international community," since, he claimed, "this is not the first time that Kiev has killed its own people." Asked about the Russian presidency's willingness to present evidence to the UN or other international organizations that Ukraine was involved in the downing of the plane or that Ukrainian authorities knew who was traveling on board the aircraft, Peskov replied only that, at this moment, he had "nothing to add". "Investigators are working and decisions will be made as they obtain all the necessary information," he added. According to the Russian version, the Il-76 military transport plane was shot down on Wednesday by Ukraine with 65 Ukrainian prisoners of war on board, as well as six crew members and three Russian guards, which was allegedly traveling to Ukraine for a prisoner exchange. In turn, Ukraine, which confirmed that an exchange was being prepared, claims that the plane was carrying weapons and not prisoners of war. The Russian military offensive on Ukrainian territory, launched on February 24, 2022, plunged Europe into what is considered the most serious security crisis since the Second World War (1939-1945).

column3:
Former Russian president says Ukraine joining NATO would mean ‘war’

Former Russian President Dmitry Medvedev said Ukraine joining NATO would be a declaration of war against Moscow and that only “prudence” on behalf of the alliance could prevent the planet from being torn apart.

North Atlantic Treaty Organization leaders pledged at their summit last week to support Ukraine on an “irreversible path to full Euro-Atlantic integration, including NATO membership,” but left open the question of when that membership might happen.

Medvedev, deputy chairman of Russia’s Security Council and a leading voice among Kremlin hawks, told the Argumenty I Fakty media outlet that Ukraine’s accession would go beyond a direct threat to Moscow’s security.

“This would essentially be a declaration of war – albeit a belated one,” he said in comments published on Wednesday.

“The actions that Russia’s opponents have been taking against us for years, expanding the alliance, are bringing NATO to a point of no return.”

In a standard Kremlin line since Moscow’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine in 2022, Medvedev said Russia was not threatening NATO but would respond to the alliance’s attempts to advance its interests.

“The more such attempts there are, the harsher our responses will become,” Medvedev said. “Whether this will tear the entire planet apart depends solely on the prudence of the (NATO) side.”

column3:
G20 Summit. The challenges facing world leaders in managing peace, debt and climate

G20 world leaders will meet for a two-day summit on 9 and 10 September, hosted by the Indian G20 Presidency in New Delhi. Under the slogan “One Earth – One Family – One Future”, the tense debate will focus on deep differences over Russia’s war in Ukraine, debt restructuring and the phase-out of fossil fuels, making it difficult to reach a joint declaration on Sunday. Joe Biden, Rishi Sunak, Emmanuel Macron and other G20 leaders will be in New Delhi for the 18th G20 Summit. Xi Jinping and Vladimir Putin will not be present, leaving national representation to Li Qiang, the Chinese prime minister, who will lead the Chinese delegation, and Sergei Lavrov, the Russian foreign minister, who will lead the Russian delegation. Narendra Modi, the prime minister of India, the host country for the annual summit, hopes to assert his country’s growing diplomatic clout and facilitate dialogue on the issues that divide the G20: Russia’s war in Ukraine and climate change. A lack of consensus on the war in Ukraine threatens to derail the summit, undermining progress on issues such as food security, debt restructuring and cooperation on climate change. “The cost of inaction will be catastrophic”

The G20 Summit is taking place as “the world is on a knife-edge. The climate crisis is inflicting immense harm on people, and the human rights of billions of people are under threat,” said Agnès Callamard, Secretary General of Amnesty International, in a statement this week. According to Amnesty International, “it is vital that the G20 recognises the magnitude and urgency of these crises and acts quickly to prevent the escalation of climate disasters and debt”, otherwise “the cost of inaction will be catastrophic”, she added. At the previous G20 summit in November 2022, hosted by the Indonesian G20 presidency in Bali, leaders discussed the impact of Russia’s war on Ukraine on the global economy, and in particular food and energy security. Despite issuing a joint declaration, Amnesty International believes that it has so far failed to be honoured and calls for its implementation, as well as for new commitments. This G20 summit comes ahead of other key occasions when countries will come together again, such as the UN General Assembly’s High-Level Week and the UN Secretary-General’s Climate Ambition Summit later this month, both in New York, as well as the COP28 climate meeting in Dubai, which starts on 30 November.

column3:
Humanity faces “triple extinction” that will eradicate all life from Earth. But only in 250 million years

For years, experts have been warning humanity about the impact of global warming: as temperatures rise, there is concern about the world's food supply, rising sea levels and the fact that regions of the Earth are becoming too hot. to live. Now, in a study published in the journal 'Nature Geoscience', scientists have predicted the moment when humanity will witness the “triple extinction” event that will wipe out human beings and what will cause it. The study, led by the University of Bristol (UK), indicates that the Earth could become a hot, dry and largely uninhabitable supercontinent, with the entire landmass merging into one giant terrain – were used for the research the first supercomputer climate models of the distant future and showed that the world will have more volcanic eruptions that will emit huge plumes of carbon dioxide, increasing temperatures even further. The Sun could become hotter and brighter in the sky, heating the Earth more than ever and causing the average temperature to be between 40 and 50 degrees Celsius. According to Alexandrer Farnsworth, lead author of the study and senior research associate at the University of Bristol, “the newly emerged supercontinent would effectively create a triple whammy, comprising the effect of continentality, a hotter Sun and more CO2 in the atmosphere, increasing heat. across much of the planet.” The result is a hostile environment, without sources of food and water for mammals. Widespread temperatures between 40 and 50 degrees Celsius and even greater daily extremes, worsened by high humidity, would ultimately seal our fate. Humans — along with many other species — would die due to their inability to release this heat through sweat, cooling their bodies. According to the study, even if humanity stopped using fossil fuels, this would not prevent extinction. Even if humanity survives until the event, there will be total extinction. The only advantage is that the event is 250 million years away. Eunice Lo, co-author of the study and researcher in Climate Change and Health at the University of Bristol, said “it is vitally important not to lose sight of our current climate crisis, which results from human emissions of greenhouse gases.” “Although we are predicting an uninhabitable planet within 250 million years, today we are already experiencing extreme heat that is harmful to human health. This is why it is crucial to achieve net zero emissions as soon as possible,” he concluded.

column3:
Lula makes federal government available to help cities in Rio Grande do Sul affected by flooding

President Lula spoke about the flooding that hit several regions of Rio Grande do Sul between Monday and Tuesday. On the program "Conversa com o Presidente", he spoke about the situation in the municipalities of Serra and the North of the state and guaranteed federal aid. "Now, we have excessive rain. It rained a lot in several regions, there are floods and from what I saw, there are deaths. I want to make a statement to the people of Rio Grande do Sul saying that the head of Civil Defense is going to Rio Grande do Sul. I would like to tell the people of Rio Grande do Sul that we are ready to help in whatever way is necessary. Wherever there is a problem, the federal government will be ready to help people", he assured. Lula recalled that, in the first half of the year, a delegation of ministers visited the state to assess the losses caused by the drought that affected 400 municipalities and impacted agricultural production. In February, the federal government released 392.8 million euros for mitigation actions. In March, 12 cities in Rio Grande do Sul affected by drought received aid of over 360 million euros. For the president, these extreme events are a warning that the climate issue is not a minor issue. “It’s not a question of a university professor, it’s not a question of an environmentalist, it’s a question of humanity, of the planet suffering the consequences of human irresponsibility,” he said, reaffirming that he has a plan to include the topic of climate change in the school curriculum. Earlier on Tuesday, Lula used Twitter to express his solidarity with the families who lost people in the floods in RS.

column3:
Fungi are more resistant to body heat, researchers say; know what the risks are

There are millions of fungi in the world. Although 150,000 are catalogued, scientists believe that the real number could vary between 1 and 5 million different species. However, a minority of them are at risk of infection. The group of researchers investigated 98 infections caused by fungi between 2009 and 2019, recorded in Chinese hospitals. They claim to have discovered a new species that causes infections. “We identified two independent cases of human infection with a previously undescribed invasive fungal pathogen,” the study says. Rhodosporidiobolus fluvialis was the identified species. In general, high body temperature prevents fungi from surviving. The researchers then carried out tests in laboratories with mice that were induced to a body temperature of 37ºC and discovered that this species of fungus not only remained alive, but recorded an increase in mutation rates, compared to milder temperatures. As a result of the accelerated mutation, fungi can become even more resistant to drugs, which would make it difficult to treat any disease. “Temperature-induced mutagenesis can also trigger the development of pan-resistance to three of the most widely used antifungals (fluconazole, caspofungin and amphotericin B),” the researchers say. The group also put forward the theory that rising global temperatures, as a result of the climate crisis, could encourage the spread of infectious diseases. “Global warming could promote the evolution of new fungal pathogens,” the article states. On the other hand, Toni Gabaldón, a biologist at the Institute for Biomedical Research in Barcelona, ​​says caution is needed. “Direct evidence that these two observations are related is lacking and more research is needed,” he told German broadcaster Deutsche Welle.

column3:
Tragedy in RS exposes urgency to mitigate climate change

A new storm hits Rio Grande do Sul, with unprecedented amounts of precipitation. In two days, it rained more than triple the average for the month of May. The frequency of meteorological disasters requires authorities to change the way they face them. This is the fifth climate scourge to hit Rio Grande do Sul in less than a year. In June 2023, a cyclone swept through the state; From July to December, storms affected the lives of millions of people. The state administration has now returned to declaring a public calamity. As of Friday morning (3), 351,600 people and 235 municipalities had been affected. By late afternoon, there were 39 dead. The support of the federal government is essential, which has already announced the sending of one hundred National Force agents and 31 transport vehicles. But, given the scale of the tragedy, which left thousands without homes and means of subsistence, in addition to the loss of loved ones, all action seems insufficient to alleviate such suffering. It seems clear that something abnormal is afoot and that global warming is at its root. Although extreme events can result from natural climate variation, this is increasingly unlikely. Public authorities therefore need to prepare for the worst-case scenarios. Nothing that happens now is unpredicted by science. It is still urgent to mitigate global warming by cutting greenhouse gas emissions more drastically and decisively than has been done so far — but in reality, they continue to rise worldwide. In the short and medium term, adapting to climate change should already be a priority for policymakers. The federal government, states and municipalities need to create integrated action plans to mitigate the effects of global warming and the fatalities caused by events, in areas such as forestry legislation, since green areas are essential to contain floods, and basic sanitation, which is shameful in Brazil. If there are obstacles to reducing and cutting carbon emissions at a global level, local authorities must take precautions to ensure that extreme events do not become, at the very least, catastrophic events.

column3:
Activists who blocked Segunda Perimetral and ended up arrested have now been released. Tomorrow they go to court

The 11 climate activists from the Climáximo movement, who this Tuesday morning began blocking the Second Circular, in Lisbon, from 9 am, during peak hour, in three of the four lanes in the Benfica-Airport direction, already were released by authorities after being arrested at the protest. The young people were released at 5pm from the PSP and Benfica police station, where they were being held. On the way out, there were some family members and colleagues from the movement, who clapped and shouted new slogans, calling for Government action to stop climate change. A sign was displayed that said “They are destroying everything you love.” “Fires, floods, droughts, heat waves that kill thousands of people. They know this and continue to increase emissions. We need peace and a disarmament of the weapons that are aimed at all of us”, said Noah Zino, one of the activists. The activists will be presented to the judge tomorrow, at 10am, at the Justice Campus, in Lisbon. Saying that they did not yet know the crimes of which they were accused, they admit that it is most likely that they will be charged with disobedience and disturbing public order. “We have stopped accepting a normality that kills more people every two days than died in Pedrogão Grande, in the fires. We will accompany anyone who wants to stop this genocide”, continued the activist, ensuring that actions of this type will continue to happen. Nine of the detained activists, who had cut the Second Circular, were taken away by a special police unit vehicle, and the two hanging from the viaduct ended up being removed by the authorities, especially the Lisbon Sapadores Firefighters, and detained. Several INEM ambulances, two cars from the Lisbon Firefighters Sapadores with more than 10 officers, four cars from the special police unit and five officers from the Prevention and Immediate Reaction Team (EPRI) of the metropolitan command of the PSP of Lisbon were mobilized to the scene. . Remember here the videos of the protest and chaos this morning in Lisbon:

On social media, the group published several videos about the moment, including when the police were forced to intervene to remove two protesters hanging from a rope on the 2nd Perimetral viaduct, in which they held a banner that read “governments and companies declared war on society and the planet.”

column3:
Is your favorite destination in danger of disappearing? This is what could happen if sea levels continue to rise

According to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, climate change will lead to an average rise in global sea levels of between 32 and 84 centimeters by 2100. Researchers from financial comparison service Money.co.uk have produced travel posters imagining the impact of dramatic sea level rise in famous destinations. Although exaggerated, the artworks are a way to draw attention to the plight faced by many coastal areas due to rising sea levels. However, there are several destinations that are likely to be affected by rising sea levels over the next hundred years. The team created a map of tourist destinations around the world that are at risk of flooding and even disappearing completely. Fiji, a country where the economy is largely dependent on tourism, has already started to see the effects of rising sea levels, with research showing that water levels will continue to rise to 1-2 meters by 2100, which puts the island at risk of being completely submerged. Seychelles, Solomon Islands and Palau are also at risk of disappearing by 2100, which would be a devastating loss for the planet. Some of the world’s most popular tourist destinations, including London, Dubai, Tokyo and Rio de Janeiro, are vulnerable to extreme flooding by 2100. In Dubai, a three-meter rise would cause the city to lose much of its infrastructure. If sea levels rise by nine meters, Dubai could be completely submerged, making it the shortest-lived urban infrastructure in human history. The Maldives – famous for its iconic overwater villas – could lose up to 77% of its land area to the sea by 2100, according to some experts.

column3:
Russia restricts civilian access to villages in Ukraine-bombed border region

Access to 14 villages in the southern Russian Belgorod region bordering Ukraine will be closed to most civilians, Governor Vyacheslav Gladkov said Tuesday, citing the “extremely difficult” situation due to Ukrainian shelling. Announcing the new restrictions in a video posted on his Telegram channel, Gladkov said that starting next week, only adult men accompanying military or government officials will be allowed to enter the settlements. Men must travel in armored vehicles and wear bulletproof vests and helmets, he added. “I hope you will agree that it is unacceptable to allow women and children to enter the settlements that are shelled every day,” Gladkov said. “We have already lost too many civilians, we have too many wounded. And of course, our task is to maximize security measures.” The Belgorod region has come under frequent fire from Ukrainian shelling and drones. Air raid sirens sound almost daily in the regional capital of the same name, just 40km north of the border. Ukraine says Russian shelling of Ukrainian cities has been devastating and, after nearly two and a half years of war, Russian forces are now in control of about a fifth of Ukraine. Russian President Vladimir Putin said in May that Russian forces were working to create a buffer zone in northeastern Ukraine to protect Russia from attacks launched by Kiev’s forces across the border. Gladkov’s announcement is a sign that the security situation in the region may have become more dire, prompting authorities to do more to protect civilians. More than 200 civilians have been killed in the Belgorod region since the start of what Moscow calls its “special military operation” in Ukraine in February 2022, Gladkov told the state-run Tass news agency on Tuesday. More than 1,100 have been wounded.

column3:
"Short-sighted policy" of the West helped Russia to get closer to the "global south"

"The plans of the Western minority to isolate Russia and create a kind of cordon sanitaire around us have failed. The promoters of these initiatives themselves are forced to admit this," said Sergei Lavrov, during a speech in the Russian State Duma (lower house of parliament), quoted by the official news agency TASS. In his speech, Lavrov considered that the West, led by the United States, used the "Kiev regime" to achieve these goals, in addition to having made available "a wide arsenal of hybrid warfare tools", including economic and diplomatic sanctions, which also covered the sectors of information, culture and sports. However, he stressed that the "collective hostility" of the West also allowed the emergence of "new opportunities" to direct Russia's relations in "various geographical directions", giving as examples China and Africa, which has become "one of the poles of the emerging multipolar world". Lavrov, who will visit Cuba, Venezuela and Brazil next week, noted that during his visit to Rio de Janeiro on Wednesday and Thursday - where he will participate in the G20 foreign ministers' summit (the world's 20 largest economies) - Russia will continue to oppose "selfish goals" that have emerged within the group, including "the 'Ukrainianization' of the agenda." Still on Ukraine, Lavrov reiterated that Russia is willing to start negotiations, as long as its "legitimate interests" are respected, which are completely contradictory to Ukrainian demands, which are committed to recovering the entire territory. These words from the Russian Foreign Minister follow statements from other Russian sources who, on Tuesday, assured that Russian President Vladimir Putin's suggestion of a ceasefire in Ukraine and negotiations, following contacts between intermediaries last December, was rejected by the United States of America (USA). An official US source denied on condition of anonymity that there had been any formal contact and said that Washington would not engage in negotiations that excluded Ukraine. The Russian military offensive on Ukrainian territory, launched on February 24, 2022, plunged Europe into what is considered the most serious security crisis since the Second World War (1939-1945). Ukraine's Western allies have supplied arms to Kiev and passed successive sanctions packages targeting Russian interests to try to reduce Moscow's ability to finance the war effort.

column3:
Ukraine has already received Western F-16s, but Zelensky says they are insufficient

Ukraine has received its first Western F-16 fighter jets, which have been expected for more than two years, President Volodymyr Zelensky announced today, showing them to reporters and stressing that their number is “insufficient”. “We have held hundreds of meetings and negotiations” with allies to obtain these planes and strengthen the country’s air defense and “we often hear the words ‘it is impossible’ in response,” Volodymyr Zelensky said during a ceremony at a secret location in Ukraine, according to AFP. “Now it is reality, reality in our skies. The F-16s are in Ukraine,” he said. Since the beginning of the Russian invasion in February 2022, Kiev has been begging for the delivery of F-16s in the hope of ending Russian dominance in the air and better protecting its cities and military against incessant bombing by Moscow’s forces. Made in the United States, the planes are considered the crown jewel in the extensive list of military equipment that Ukraine has requested from its allies in an attempt to repel the advance of Russian forces on its soil. The President of Ukraine did not reveal the number of aircraft received by Kiev, saying only that it was “insufficient”, nor the number of Ukrainian pilots trained in the West to fly these aircraft. The delivery date and the country that supplied this first batch were also not revealed. “What is positive is that we expect more F-16s” and that “many of our men are being trained”, assured Zelensky. AFP journalists saw at least two F-16s flying over the site during the ceremony. Behind Volodymyr Zelensky, two other gray aircraft similar to F-16s were placed on the ground, partially covered by camouflage nets and with their tails emblazoned with the national coat of arms, the trident. In mid-May, President Zelensky stated in an interview with AFP that he needed 120 to 130 of these aircraft to achieve parity with Russian aviation.

column3:
Hungarian party wants to annex Ukrainian region if Ukraine loses war

The leader of the Hungarian far-right party Our Homeland Movement, Laszlo Toroczkai, said on Saturday that he would claim the Ukrainian region of Transcarpathia, which borders Hungary in western Ukraine and is home to around 150,000 Hungarians, if the country invaded by Russia loses the war. According to the Reuters news agency, Toroczkai's words were spoken at a party press conference, which was also attended by leaders of the far-right Alternative for Germany (AfD) and the Forum for Democracy, among others. "Regarding the war, our message is very simple: an immediate ceasefire, peace and a resolution through talks," the politician said. "If this war ends with Ukraine losing its statehood, because that is also happening, then, as the only Hungarian party to take this position, let me signal that we will reclaim Transcarpathia," he stressed. It should be noted that Russia invaded Ukraine on February 24, 2022, with the argument of protecting pro-Russian separatist minorities in the east and "denazifying" the neighboring country, independent since 1991, after the disintegration of the former Soviet Union, and which has been moving away from Moscow's sphere of influence and closer to Europe and the West. The war in Ukraine has already caused tens of thousands of deaths on both sides, but there has been no significant progress in the theatre of operations in recent months, with both belligerents remaining unyielding in their territorial positions and unwilling to make concessions in negotiations. Recent weeks have been marked by large-scale air strikes by Russia against Ukrainian cities and infrastructure, while Kyiv's forces have targeted targets in Russian territory close to the border and in the Crimean peninsula, illegally annexed in 2014.

column3:
Russia threatens to shoot down F-16s promised to Kiev

Russia threatened on Thursday that the F-16 fighter jets promised to Ukraine by the West will be shot down, arguing that these aircraft will have little effect on the battlefield. "There is no magic remedy or panacea and the Kiev regime's air force will not have such a panacea," Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said, adding that "these planes (...) will be shot down". "But it is clear that these deliveries cannot have a significant impact on the course of events on the front line," he added. For almost two years, Ukraine has been asking its Western allies for the supply of F-16s, considered the 'crown jewel' of the extensive list of military equipment that Kiev has requested from its supporters. According to some media, the US-made fighter jets have already been delivered. Several NATO countries have committed to supplying a varying number of fighters and have been training Ukrainian pilots and crews for months. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has made improving air defenses a top priority in meetings with allies following Russia’s aggressive air campaign in recent months. In an interview with Agence France Presse in May, Zelensky outlined the need for about 130 F-16s to ensure parity with the Russian air force. However, Ukraine's partners have committed to sending fewer than 100 F-16s to date, with most of the planes likely to arrive over several years after pilot training.

column3:
Pay attention to El Niño and ocean anomalies. It came late but summer is here: August will be hot

The month of August begins to approach but summer seems to remain far away. Pedro Sousa, meteorologist at the Portuguese Institute of the Sea and Atmosphere (IPMA) confirms that, this week, “we are witnessing an episode of hot weather” and, last week, “there were also some”. The heat that is being felt at the end of July is “relatively normal” and the meteorologist classifies these periods as typical “summer heat”. “Without records and without very prolonged heat episodes, it has been a calm summer”, admits the meteorologist. And it is, in fact, like that, especially because there have been many complaints that the heat arrived late. For August, temperatures are expected to be above average in the interior and below average on the coast, says Pedro Sousa. The weeks are therefore predicted to be dry and hot, with cooler trends on the coast. “The probability of August being hot is high”, he explains, due to the global warming trend over the years and also the El Niño phenomenon which, “whenever it happens, the planet experiences high temperatures”. Furthermore, there are ocean anomalies above normal which cause the sea to become warmer, which also reduces the influence of the sea breeze on temperature. Despite this, the IPMA meteorologist warns that this is not an absolute certainty, as “forecasts are losing reliability” and a “forecast for three weeks from now can always change”. “Forecasts change quickly,” he concludes. Comparing the temperature of August 2024 with the last three decades, he highlights, the meteorology of the next month should be higher, but “nothing guarantees that it will be hotter than last year or 2018”, which were marked by temperature phenomena . “The predicted and observed temperatures are above those of the last thirty years, which does not mean that they are very high”, he explains. The end of July and the first week of August are predicted to be hot and dry with above average interior and negative anomalies on the coast. “The normal summer thing,” says the expert. Regarding this week, everything indicates that it will be "very hot". The next one should continue with above average temperatures.

column3:
Extreme heat, fires and rain that doesn't fall: Water-stressed Greek islands are already banning swimming pools and turning to desalination

Water scarcity has led some Greek islands to ban the use of swimming pools and resort to desalination. Just weeks after Greece faced its earliest-ever heat wave in June, several parts of the country are now dealing with a new crisis: severe water shortages. An emergency has been declared in Sifnos, the Cyclades, Leros, the Dodecanese islands, Sami, Cephalonia, and parts of Crete. Residents of these regions are demanding urgent intervention as water resources become depleted. Water levels are also low on the Attica peninsula, which encompasses Athens. On the southern Aegean island of Naxos, the largest reservoir has dried up due to low rainfall and hot weather, according to Reuters news agency. The lack of rain in recent months, combined with scorching temperatures of up to 40ºC, has caused this situation. Inadequate infrastructure and lack of maintenance of desalination units on the islands further aggravated the problem. Forest fires also contributed to the crisis. In June, a fire on Serifos destroyed part of the island's water supply network, which now faces its lowest water reserves in 20 years. With the maximum need for water for supply and irrigation, farmers are the most affected. Many are being forced to turn to seawater-contaminated wells due to low water levels, Reuters reports. With the tourist season in full swing, visitor infrastructure is putting further pressure on water resources. Increased construction and uncontrolled use of swimming pools have contributed to water shortages on the islands, Elissavet Feloni, a hydrologist and professor at the University of West Attica, told Greek channel Naftemporiki. Last month was the hottest June on record globally and the 13th consecutive month of record temperatures, according to European climate service Copernicus. It was also the 12th month in a row in which the world was 1.5ºC warmer than in pre-industrial times, extremes attributed to man-made emissions. With dry conditions expected to persist in the coming months, Feloni called for controls on water consumption and stricter government monitoring. Some islands have already taken action on their own. Karpathos and Serifos have imposed restrictions on refilling swimming pools. In Viannos, Crete, strict limits have been set on the use of water for irrigation. The small Dodecanese island of Lipsi has gone ahead and banned the construction of swimming pools in the hot summer of 2023 to encourage a more sustainable approach to tourism. The northern island of Thassos is investing in a desalination plant to make its seawater drinkable, according to Reuters. In places where an emergency was declared, processes for transferring water, improving supplies and accessing government funds were accelerated. Three new wells are planned in Crete, while the navy has transported water to Leros, according to local press reports. This water crisis on the Greek islands highlights the urgent need to adapt to climate change and more sustainable management of natural resources.

column3:
Green paint in the eyes, or the courage to tell the truth

In recent years, with the recognition of climate change as a global phenomenon, a mode of protest has spread, from young ‘climate activists’. Integrated into anti-system vanguard parties, which, believing they are saving the world from the apocalypse, consider themselves above the Law. The protests of these activists or radicals take different forms. All over the world, they stick to works of art to draw attention to their causes, usually forgetting that those works of art represent the best that the human spirit has produced over thousands of years of existence. Another form of protest they encounter is by sticking themselves to the ground in the most diverse places, occupying a space that is not theirs, believing that they can freely impose themselves on others. We have already had a few episodes like these here, some of them involving the pretense of believing that they are the only ones who care about the future of the planet and Humanity, intending to represent the vanguard of contemporary society. They interrupted a private event where the Minister of Economy was present. They invaded and stuck to the floor of the Ministry of Economy. They blocked access to the building where the Council of Ministers was supposed to meet. In another case, the leader of the JS of Oeiras, after insulting the Municipal Executive in a session of the Oeiras Municipal Assembly, addressed the Executive's bench throwing a 10 euro note, in order to reinforce the municipal budget in the fight against climate change. This week, the holders of truth and above good and evil, invaded a CNN conference where the Minister of the Environment was present, attacking the minister with bags of green paint, protesting against the minister's presence at an event supported by companies of the energy sector. All of this is possible and all of this is tolerated because the poor 'young free radicals' are drawing attention to a greater cause, and because they want to save Humanity from itself. In reality, all of this is tolerated because the vast majority of the political class, as well as other institutions, live in a state of cowardly surrender to political correctness. Politicians are insulted or subjected to insinuations and are afraid to react. Fear is the worst advisor for decision makers. Governments, and the President of the Republic, have been particularly responsible for establishing this state of affairs. Portugal is a country absolutely conditioned by these groups, and by the hand that rocks their cradle. A substantial part of blocking national decisions involves imposed public conditioning (with strong support from newsrooms), and this conditioning afflicts our society with fear. Yesterday it was public that 40% of judges admit to being conditioned by the media. How many of the remaining 60% still don't tell the truth? By reacting softly to these arrogant protests, we are tolerating the intolerable and recognizing legitimacy where none exists. In a free society there are no vanguards, nor does any group have moral superiority over others. It is regrettable that, today, saying this is an act of courage

column3:
Climate activists dye Venice canal green in protest against COP28

Italian environmentalists used dye to dye Venice's Grand Canal green on Saturday (9) in protest against what they considered a lack of progress at COP28, the UN Climate Change Conference taking place in Dubai until next Tuesday (12). Hanging from the Rialto Bridge over the canal with the help of climbing ropes, activists from the group Extinction Rebellion also displayed a banner that read: "COP28: While the government talks, we are hanging by a thread". Small stretches of rivers and canals in other Italian cities have also been dyed green in similar protests. "In a few hours, these waters will be back to what they were before," the group said in a statement. "In the meantime, we count the damage and victims of the constant floods and fires." According to the protesters, the visual effect was created by a dye used by companies to track items in the water. Boat traffic was halted during the protest, and the canal water and columns had to be checked for safety reasons, according to Venice Mayor Luigi Brugnaro. The politician criticized the activists' actions, calling them "eco-vandals," and called on Italian authorities to punish them. "Venice is a fragile city that must be loved and respected! Enough is enough," he said. Brugnaro borrowed the nickname given to the protesters from figures such as the current Italian Minister of Culture, Gennaro Sangiuliano. The head of the department is waging a crusade against protests by environmentalists who target monuments and works of art — acts that have become more common in recent years. In April, the government of Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni announced a bill that provides for stricter fines, between 10,000 and 60,000 euros, for those who destroy, tarnish or disfigure, totally or partially, cultural and scenic assets. The measures were added to sanctions already present in the penal code for this type of crime, which currently reach five years in prison and a fine of R$15,000. “Whoever damages our artistic heritage cannot and should not get away with it,” said the ultra-rightist on social media at the time.

column3:
Young people take centre stage in environmental discussions

Three out of four young people aged 16 to 25 consider the “climate future frightening” and fear that world leaders will not be able to implement effective measures. This is according to the survey Young People’s Voices on Climate Anxiety, Government Betrayal and Moral Injury: A Global Phenomenon, which interviewed 10,000 people from countries such as the US, India, France, Nigeria and Brazil in September. The survey also showed that 45% of these young people feel distressed, overwhelmed, anxious and guilty about the environment. These figures explain and reflect the leading role that young people are demanding – albeit by force – in decisions to combat the climate crisis. “Our leaders are not our leaders. This is what a leader should look like”, said Greta Thunberg, pointing to the thousands of young people listening to her in Glasgow. In Glasgow, young people from all over the world called for greater participation and representation in the negotiations. A declaration signed by 40,000 of them was delivered to the COP presidency and other leaders. “Youth action and scrutiny are essential to keeping the 1.5 degrees Celsius target alive and creating a zero-emissions future,” said Alok Sharma, president of the Conference. The Brazilian delegation included around 80 young people, the largest youth representation to date. And the only Brazilian to participate in the COP-26 opening ceremony was Txai Suruí, a 24-year-old indigenous girl. He shared the stage with António Guterres, UN Secretary General, and Boris Johnson, British Prime Minister, and spoke to diplomats from more than 190 countries. In his speech, Txai cited the murder of Ari Uru-Eu-Wau-Wau, his friend and indigenous guardian killed in 2020 for protecting nature, and warned about the urgency for change. “Today the weather is getting warmer; animals are disappearing; the rivers are dying; our crops don't flourish like they used to. The Earth is speaking. It tells us we don’t have any more time.”

TESTIMONIAL

Eduarda Zoghbi, Political scientist from UnB and master's student at Columbia (USA)

The search of new generations for more space

“At 16, I was at COP-15, in Copenhagen. I couldn't get in, I stayed outside. There was no space for youth. In 2016, there were ten of us in the Brazilian youth delegation. This year, there were 80 of us, in the most diverse young delegation we have ever had. He wasn't one young indigenous man, there were ten. He wasn't one young black man, there were ten. We had trans women, young people from different regions of Brazil."

column3:
UN event brings together young people in Porto Alegre to address climate change

Young people from all over Rio Grande do Sul will gather in Porto Alegre next weekend, August 17 and 18, for the LCOY - Local Conference of Brazilian Youth on Climate Change. The event, which will be held at the Caixa Econômica Federal Staff Association in Rio Grande do Sul (APCEF), is an initiative of YOUNGO, the official youth group of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC). The event seeks to engage young people in discussion and action on climate change. During the conference, a document will be prepared to be sent directly to the Youth Conference (COY 19) and the Conference of the Parties (COP 29), international discussion events on climate change that will take place in Azerbaijan this year. "Having an international advocacy event here in the state is incredible, as it is an opportunity for us to show the world the challenges we face here, such as the increase in extreme weather events, the rampant degradation of the Pampas and the dismantling of environmental laws. At the same time, we created solutions collaboratively, together with other young people from the state", says Thais Yutori, a climate activist who is organizing the event and is part of Eco Pelo Clima. For her, the presence of young people from Rio Grande do Sul at LCOY reinforces the importance of community involvement and collaboration in initiatives that seek immediate solutions to climate challenges. "Rio Grande do Sul has been highly impacted by the climate crisis. We recently experienced the worst flood ever seen in the history of our state, we need to involve young people in building solutions that will impact the future that is already ours," says Thais.

column3:
Appetite for bigger cars increases around the world and makes the fight against global warming more difficult

The negative impact of passenger vehicles on the climate, which is considerable, could have fallen by more than 30% in the last decade if not for the world's appetite for large cars, suggests a new report from the Global Fuel Economy Initiative. Transportation is responsible for about a quarter of all climate-warming gases from energy, and much of that can be attributed to passenger transport, according to the International Energy Agency. But the negative environmental impact of SUVs could have been reduced by more than a third between 2010 and 2022 if people had continued to buy the same size cars, according to the initiative, a global partnership of cleaner vehicle groups. One solution to this could be electric vehicles (EVs). George Parrott, a 79-year-old avid runner who lives in West Sacramento, California, decided to switch to cleaner vehicles in 2004 when he purchased a hybrid Toyota Prius. Since then, he has owned several pure electric cars and currently has a Genesis GV60 electric SUV and a Tesla Model 3. Not all consumers feel the same way about energy consumption and environmental benefits, especially in the US. While EV sales accounted for 15 percent of the global auto market last year, that share was just 7.3 percent in the U.S. Meanwhile, smaller vehicles, or sedans, have lost a lot of ground in the U.S. market over the past decade. In 2012, sedans accounted for 50 percent of U.S. auto retail space, with SUVs at just over 30 percent and trucks at 13.5 percent, according to the auto-buying firm Edmunds. By 2022, sedans’ share in the U.S. had fallen to 21 percent, while SUVs reached 54.5 percent and trucks had grown to 20 percent. “People don’t want to be limited by the space in their car,” said Eric Frehsée, president of the Tamaroff Group of dealerships in southeast Michigan. “Everybody wants a seven-passenger car.” “It was all a combination of broad environmental concerns,” he said. More efforts are underway by the U.S. Department of Transportation, the Environmental Protection Agency and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration to improve the fuel economy and tailpipe emissions of gasoline-powered vehicles. Some initiatives could include SUVs, which have the industry buzzing.

column3:
Drought in Manaus: Rio Negro reaches 3rd lowest level in history

The Rio Negro, in Manaus, reached its third lowest level this Friday, the 13th, at 13.93 meters. The level is 28 centimeters away from breaking the record low level recorded in 2010, when the river reached 13.63 meters. With the low level, the city of Manaus issued a statement reinforcing the closure of Ponta Negra beach, which has been closed to bathers since October 2nd. The decision to close the beach for bathing, for reasons of safety and to prevent drowning, is due to the proximity between the end of the perennial landfill and the natural riverbed, which may present changes in the terrain, such as holes, unevenness and depressions. Last Monday, October 9th, the beach was fenced off to physically delimit the area where bathers are prohibited, with signs measuring 1.20 meters high and 1,500 meters long. This physical restriction is intended to prevent people from passing through and to raise awareness among those who insist on bathing in the river in the restricted section. Climate change is altering the landscape in several parts of the country

The Negro River has seen a very rapid decline, with a reduction of more than 7 meters in water column in just 20 days in September. The explanation lies in the El Niño phenomenon, which has prolonged the intensity of the drought in Amazonas. The capital of Amazonas declared a state of emergency on September 28th due to the drought. Furthermore, the city hall also recommended that the population not practice physical activities. This is because Manaus was once again covered in smoke. “I recommend not practicing sports. You can't breathe carbon monoxide, which causes problems. As a result, we will postpone our city's marathon, which was scheduled for the weekend. It is also necessary to avoid being exposed to smoke, close the windows of the houses, and hydration is essential at this time. Unfortunately, we are going through this, as a result of climate change”, said Mayor David Almeida.

column3:
Ethiopia and FAO sign programme to combat climate change

The Regional Livestock and Pastoralism Programme for Climate Adaptation in the East/North Africa region will be implemented in four transboundary group areas, including Mandera and Karamoja (Ethiopia), Mara-Serengeti (Tanzania) and Bahr Al Arab (Sudan and South Sudan). Kenya, Somalia and Uganda are other countries targeted by the EU-funded project with €47 million, of which €6.25 million is for Addis Ababa, the local state portfolio revealed. Fikru Regasa, Ethiopia’s Minister of State for the sector, highlighted the fight against climate change and local efforts to deal with its effects, especially in pastoralism. In turn, FAO’s representative in the country, Farayi Zimudzi, said that the programme is aligned with the UN agency’s strategic framework for “Better Production, Better Nutrition, Better Environment, Better Life”. Zimudzi added that the Ethiopian Ministry of Agriculture is the main implementing partner of the initiative and plays a coordinating role at the federal, regional and cluster levels (a group of interrelated and geographically concentrated companies and institutions competing in the same business). The regional programme is also expected to improve resilience to man-made disasters in pastoralist and farming communities in the target areas. Cattle in pastoral areas have been reported to perform various functions, including economic, social and cultural. Over the centuries, livestock farmers have also provided ecosystem services that are difficult to convert into commercial and intangible values, encompassing many interrelated environmental benefits.

column3:
“Apocalyptic” fires force evacuation of tourists on Greek islands: five firefighters injured

Several tourists were forced to be evacuated from hotels in Greece due to the threat posed by the numerous forest fires spreading across the country: according to the British from 'The Independent', firefighters fought fires on the islands of Chios and Kos, in the east of the Aegean Sea, this Monday, which injured five people. Greek Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis has already warned of a dangerous summer ahead, highlighting that the population's help was essential to limit the impact of forest fires: it is worth remembering that in 2023 20 people died in forest fires during the summer months . Greece has experienced a recent past marked by several forest fires: however, hotter, drier and windier weather, which scientists associate with the effects of climate change, has increased their frequency and intensity. On Monday morning, emergency services issued evacuation orders for people in the Metohi area of ​​western Chios to move to a nearby beach – by evening, more than 140 firefighters, along with eight specialist teams in forest fires, seven planes and three helicopters were fighting the fire. According to fire department spokesman Vasilis Vathrakoyiannis, two firefighters were slightly injured: state television 'ERT' later reported that two other firefighters and a volunteer suffered non-life-threatening burns. “The situation remains difficult in Chios, and all Civil Protection forces will make great efforts to limit it,” assured Vathrakoyiannis. Further south in the Aegean, another fire broke out on the tourist island of Kos, which forced the evacuation of several people, including tourists from hotels as a precaution: the fire was fought by more than 100 firefighters, including reinforcements sent from Athens, as well as six planes and two helicopters, Vathrakoyiannis added. Greece has seen 52 forest fires break out in the past 24 hours, 44 of which were put out in the early stages, Vathrakoyiannis noted: The fires came a day after the fire department managed to control two large forest fires near Athens that were fueled by winds. strong. “We had an exceptionally difficult June in terms of weather conditions, with high levels of drought and exceptionally strong winds for this season”, highlighted Kyriakos Mitsotakis, this Monday, adding that this summer “is expected to be particularly dangerous” for forest fires. Clare Smith, who is on holiday in Kos with her husband and 9-year-old daughter, told Sky News that the situation had “worsened significantly” throughout the day, with “thick clouds of black smoke”. “It's very windy here, it's going to be like a powder keg. The sky is covered in smoke and you feel like you're in the apocalypse, or in some kind of war movie.”

column3:
Study concludes that recovery of biodiversity in European rivers stagnated in the 2010s

An international study with the participation of Maria João Feio and Manuel Graça, researchers from the Center for Marine and Environmental Sciences (MARE) at the Faculty of Science and Technology of the University of Coimbra (FCTUC), published in the journal Nature, concluded that, despite From the positive trends of the 90s, from 2010 onwards, the recovery of river biodiversity has stagnated. In Europe, over the last three decades, and especially after the publication of the Water Framework Directive in 2000, several mitigation measures have been implemented to combat the degradation of rivers and their ecosystems. However, the number of factors threatening these ecosystems continues to increase around the world. Thus, «this study aimed to analyze whether, over the last few decades, there has effectively been a recovery of aquatic biodiversity in riverine systems over time, as a result of mitigation measures implemented in Europe, and what factors determined this», he explains. Maria João Feio, adding that it was possible to conclude «that there really was a small increase in the number of species (0.73% per year), functional richness (2.4% per year) and abundance (1.7% per year) in the aquatic macroinvertebrate communities'. However, the researcher continues, «despite these positive trends, the number of species still decreased in 30% of the sites. The riverine ecosystems where there was less recovery were those located downstream of dams, in urban areas and agricultural lands. Furthermore, invertebrate communities located in areas with faster warming rates had less recovery, which shows the impacts of climate change, namely the effect of increasing temperatures», he warns. According to experts, the increases seen in biodiversity mainly occurred before the 2010s and have since stagnated. Gains in biodiversity in the 1990s and 2000s reflect the improvement in the physical-chemical quality of water, due to the implementation of more effective treatment systems and ecological rehabilitation or restoration projects. The slowdown in the recovery of riverine biodiversity in the 2010s shows that current measures are not sufficient, resulting in fewer and fewer positive results in the recovery of biodiversity. This stagnation, says the researcher, “occurred because new threats also emerged, namely emerging pollutants, such as medicines and microplastics, climate change and invasive species. In fact, the number of non-native species (found in 69% of the locations analyzed) has been increasing sharply (4% per year)», he states. Given these results, the researchers consider it «urgent to continue ecological restoration based on the renaturalization and recovery of species, not merely aesthetic, or focused on runoff, or the removal of nutrients from the water, but also on new planning focused on new impacts, such as such as emerging pollutants, climate change and invasive species. Furthermore, the research also shows the importance of continuing the ecological monitoring of rivers so that studies can be carried out that address temporal evolutions», they conclude. This research, which involved 96 European researchers from 70 institutions, was coordinated by researchers from the Senckenberg Research Institute and Natural History Museum Frankfurt, Germany.

column3:
Climate crisis could impact insects’ sex lives, study finds

In cold weather, an insect with a darker body is better at capturing a mate than a rival with a brighter structure. Darker males can warm up more easily in the early morning and therefore have more time to mate while others are still warming up. This is one of many examples of how temperature affects insects’ coloration and, in turn, can affect their ability to mate, according to a new review paper published in the journal Ecology and Evolution and reported by the Guardian. Scientists are still trying to figure out what will happen to insects’ sex lives now that man-made climate breakdown is pushing temperatures to unprecedented levels. “On the one hand, we could be happy and say, ‘How are the insects? They’re responding to climate change. We don’t need to worry about them,’” said Mariella Herberstein, a behavioral ecologist at Macquarie University in Sydney, Australia, who is one of the study’s authors. The prevailing theory among scientists, Herberstein says, is that as temperatures rise, insects largely evolve to produce less of the pigment that regulates their hue, becoming lighter and brighter. That’s because darker objects absorb more heat and warm up more quickly, while lighter objects reflect more radiation and can stay cooler longer. For example, the wing colors of some North American mountain butterflies have faded over time as temperatures have risen—their bright sulfur-yellow wings have become paler, according to a 2016 study. Between the 1980s and 2000s, it became increasingly unlikely that the two-spotted ladybug would be black with red spots rather than red with black spots. But Herberstein’s team found that the pattern isn’t always that simple. A follow-up study of Meadii butterflies, which looked at more than 800 animals collected for museum specimens between 1953 and 2013, found that in some areas, their yellow wings became richer and darker in color over time. “The mechanism is not so clear – it’s confusing,” said another of the study’s authors, Tonmoy Haque, a PhD student at Macquarie University. This may be because the researchers are working with a limited set of data from similar studies on similar insects, he says. It’s also likely because melanin doesn’t just have a heat-related function, but is involved in immune defenses and helps protect against ultraviolet radiation from the sun.

column3:
Russia ready to talk to Ukraine to end war

Russia said Thursday it is ready to talk to Ukraine, but warns that it must first understand to what extent Volodymyr Zelensky's government is willing to negotiate. Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov told reporters that Moscow is ready to start negotiations. "This is a difficult issue. From a legal point of view it is a problem, but from a practical point of view, we are open to achieving our goals through negotiations. Therefore, several variants are possible," the presidential spokesman said. Zelensky's legitimacy as president of Ukraine has been a question raised by Russia, which argues that the Ukrainian leader's term ended on May 20. The Russian spokesman said that in addition to "problems with Zelensky's legitimacy", there is also "the problem of the ban on establishing any contacts or negotiations with the Russian side, as this ban remains in force". "Russia is generally open to the negotiation process, but it is necessary to understand to what extent the Ukrainian side is prepared. So far, as you can see, we have heard very different statements. Things are not very clear," he added. Peskov's comments come after Ukraine announced on Wednesday that it was ready to negotiate with Russia, demanding "good faith". The Ukrainian president has recently held talks with political figures in favour of an immediate ceasefire, including Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán, US Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump and Vatican Secretary of State Pietro Parolin. Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba also travelled to China this week to discuss potential peace talks between Ukraine and Russia.

column3:
Ukraine accuses officials of embezzling funds intended for weapons purchases

According to the Ukrainian security services (SBU), five people were charged and one of them was arrested when trying to cross the Ukrainian border and faces a sentence of up to 12 years in prison. The investigation comes as Kyiv tries to crack down on corruption in an attempt to accelerate its membership of the European Union and NATO, one of the conditions imposed by European partners. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy was elected on an anti-corruption platform in 2019, long before Russia's full invasion of Ukraine in February 2022. Both the president and his aides have touted the recent dismissals of senior officials, notably Ivan Bakanov, former - head of the State Security Service, in July 2022, as proof of his efforts to crack down on corruption. Security officials say the current investigation dates back to August 2022, when officials signed a contract to purchase artillery shells worth 1.5 billion hryvnias (€37 million) with arms company Lviv Arsenal. After receiving payment, company officials were supposed to transfer the funds to a company registered abroad, which would then deliver the ammunition. However, the goods were never delivered and the money was sent to various accounts in Ukraine and the Balkans, according to investigators. The Ukrainian Prosecutor General's Office says the funds have since been seized and will be returned to the country's defense budget. Meanwhile, Ukraine reported a wave of Russian attacks on its infrastructure in several regions of the country on Tuesday, and Russia announced that it had repelled new Ukrainian advances in Kharkiv and Donetsk. Zaporizhia was one of the worst-hit regions, having seen at least 130 Russian shellings in the past 24 hours, according to the head of the Ukrainian regional administration, Yuri Malasko. At least 24 communities were hit by shelling in 33 drone strikes. Another 15 communities in the Sumy region were hit by Russian shelling, according to the Ukrainian military administration in the region, in a message also posted on its Telegram account. "Ninety-one explosions were recorded at the regional level," according to the authorities. Russia, for its part, said today that its forces repelled five attacks and counterattacks by assault groups of two brigades of the Armed Forces of Ukraine in the direction of Kupiansk, near Sinkovka, in the Kharkiv region, and Terniv, in Donetsk. "The motorized rifle units of the group, in cooperation with artillery, repelled two attacks and three counterattacks by the assault groups of the 32nd mechanized brigade and the 103rd Ukrainian territorial defense brigade in the Sinkovka and Ternov areas. All attacks and counterattacks were repelled. The enemy was forced to withdraw to the south and west," military spokesman Sergei Zibinsky told the Russian news agency TASS.

column3:
Russian Defense Ministry: Russian troops advanced towards Donetsk, killed 175 enemy servicemen

The Russian military has killed about 500 Ukrainian personnel over the past 24 hours and destroyed military vehicles and self-propelled artillery systems, according to the Russian Defense Ministry. Russian troops in the Donetsk direction have taken advantageous positions with the Yug (South) grouping of troops, the losses of the Armed Forces of Ukraine have reached 175 servicemen, the Russian Defense Ministry reported on Monday (25). At the same time, it said that Russia destroyed six military vehicles, including a Bradley infantry fighting vehicle, as well as a Krab self-propelled artillery system, a Rapira anti-tank gun and two Nota and Anklav-N radars.

In the Kupyansk and Kherson directions, Ukrainian casualties in the last 24 hours amounted to about 60 men in combat with Russian forces, and an attempted attack on Russian troops failed, which used the efforts of units of the Zapad (West) and Dnieper troop groups to also destroy two cars, nine pick-ups and a Gvozdika self-propelled artillery system. Meanwhile, according to the Russian military body, in the Avdeevka and southern Donetsk directions, the Ukrainian Armed Forces conducted ten unsuccessful counterattack attempts and lost some of their positions, but Russia, with the Vostok (East) and Tsentr (Center) troop groupings, destroyed about 230 personnel, 13 military vehicles, an Akatsiya self-propelled artillery system, an AN/TPQ-48 radar and other Ukrainian weapons. In addition, Russia successfully shot down 103 drones and 31 Himars, Vampire and Uragan rocket launchers. In total, during the special military operation, 577 aircraft, 270 helicopters, 17,011 unmanned aerial vehicles, 489 anti-aircraft defense systems, 15,598 tanks and other armored combat vehicles, 1,256 multiple rocket launchers, 8,521 field artillery pieces and mortars, and 20,192 units of Ukrainian special military vehicles were destroyed, the Russian Defense Ministry summarized.

column3:
Earth's core is slowing down and may rotate in the opposite direction; understand how this affects the planet

Radical natural phenomena and events caused by climate change are scaring people about the future. Concerns apparently grew after a group of scientists recently suggested that the rotation of the Earth's core is slowing down and may start rotating in the opposite direction. The theory was presented in a study published in the scientific journal Nature Geoscience. According to the publication, the process began in 2019 and the new cycle may last up to 70 years, with the possibility of changing the length of days. However, the researchers reinforce that this is a structural phenomenon of the Earth and not a catastrophic event. The authors of the research used seismic records to understand the change in the rotation of the Earth's core, and claim that this process may be related to some natural disasters. After analyzing data on the planet's inner core between the 1990s and 2020, scientists identified a noticeable change in recent years. On the other hand, this hypothesis does not come from these researchers alone. Professor John Vidale, dean of Earth Sciences at the California Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences (USC Dornsife), explained in an article in Nature Geoscience that the planet has undergone a slow deceleration until it began to spin in reverse in recent years. This new movement would cause major changes in the functioning of all forms of life on Earth. The scientific community concluded that the rotation of the core is not completely consistent, as it seemed to be constantly slowing down. Even so, experts emphasize that understanding the Earth's core is extremely difficult because direct observations are impossible. “Here we analyze repeated seismic waves from the early 1990s and show that all paths that previously showed significant temporal changes have shown little change over the last decade. This globally consistent pattern suggests that the differential rotation of the inner core has recently stopped,” says the study. Why is the Earth's core spinning backwards? The first discovery about the functioning of the Earth's inner core was made in a study conducted by seismologist Inge Lehmann in 1936. At that time, the Danish woman realized that this region functioned like a "solid metal ball." On the other hand, research into the variation in the core's rotation speed occurred in the 1970s and 1980s. Then, in the early 1990s, the first seismological evidence was released. Researchers used data from seismic waves and earthquakes to understand interactions with the planet's inner core. Even so, there are disagreements among scientists about this theory. Some of them argue that the data is still limited due to the difficulty of gathering samples and making accurate observations.

column3:
Russia takes control of another town in eastern Ukraine

The Russian Defense Ministry announced Saturday that Russian forces had taken control of the town of Lozuvatske in the Pokrovsk sector of Ukraine’s Donetsk region, the site of some of the fiercest frontline fighting in the 29-month war. Ukraine’s General Staff did not mention the town in its report, but said the area around it had been engulfed in heavy fighting. Unofficial military sources reported the loss of at least two other towns in the sector. Russian forces have been advancing slowly through the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine, making steady, incremental gains since taking the key town of Avdiivka in February. The Russian Defense Ministry said the “central” group of Russian forces had captured Lozuvatske, northwest of the Russian-held regional center of Donetsk. Russia also said its forces launched strikes elsewhere in the sector and repelled three Ukrainian counterattacks. Ukrainian authorities have reported for several weeks that the Pokrovsk sector is experiencing the heaviest fighting along the 1,000-kilometer front line. President Volodymyr Zelenskiy discussed the sector twice on Thursday with his top commander, Olexandr Syrskyi. The Ukrainian General Staff reported on Saturday that Ukrainian forces had repelled 17 attacks in the area, with 10 clashes still ongoing. “The situation is difficult, but under the control of the armed forces,” the report said. Ukraine’s popular unofficial military blog DeepState did not mention Lozuvatske in its latest report, but over the past two days it has reported the fall of two villages in the sector — Prohres and Vovche.

column3:
Climate change? A lie of socialism, says Argentina's President-elect

Javier Milei believes in property rights and the privatization of natural resources to solve environmental problems. Why are whales becoming extinct but chickens are not? Global warming? “Nothing, it's another lie of socialism. There's a whole agenda of cultural Marxism,” said Javier Milei, the anarcho-capitalist President-elect of Argentina, with a hairstyle that resembles an out-of-fashion football player. He doesn't believe in climate change, wants to abolish the Ministry of the Environment (among many others), privatize the Ministry of Science and believes in private property as a way to regulate pollution. Climate change is not the fault of humans, he said, against all scientific evidence. “The world has had other peaks of high temperatures. It's a cyclical behavior, independent of the existence of man. Therefore, all these policies that blame humans for climate change are false and only serve to raise funds to finance lazy socialists who write fifth-rate documents,” he said in the second debate with Sergio Massa, the defeated candidate. s
Milei’s speech became famous in which he said that “a company can pollute a river however it wants.” Pause: “And? Where is the damage?” The problem, said the far-right politician, is that property rights are poorly defined. An economist, former rock singer and former football goalkeeper, among other colorful biographical details, Javier Milei defines himself as a libertarian who believes in defining property rights to solve potential environmental problems. “A company can pollute a river however it wants, and do you know why? Because this is a society where there is plenty of water and the price of water is zero. Consequently, who is going to claim ownership rights to that river? No one, because they can’t make money,” he said. Now, if someone owns the water in that river, they will have an interest in negotiating with those who pollute it. “They will see how the contamination is going to end,” said Milei. These policies that blame humans for climate change are false and only serve to raise funds to finance lazy socialists who write fifth-rate documents. His main advisor, Alberto Benegas Lynch, illustrated the idea that involves the widespread privatization of state resources and assets using whales. “Why are whales on the brink of extinction, while chickens and cows are not? The difference is in the fence that protects them. Where there is an owner, there is economic benefit, and this protects the fauna,” he said, suggesting privatizing the sea.

column3:
India: heat wave would have caused at least 24 deaths in 24 hours

A severe heat wave in the eastern Indian states of Bihar and Odisha could have caused the deaths of at least 24 people from heatstroke, local officials said. This extreme weather phenomenon is expected to last until Saturday. India has been buffeted by an extremely hot summer and a part of the capital, Delhi, this week recorded the country's highest-ever temperature at 52.9 degrees Celsius, although this figure may be revised after the meteorological department Check the weather station sensors that recorded the reading. While temperatures in northwest and central India will come down in the coming days, the heat wave prevailing in eastern India is likely to continue for two days, said the India Meteorological Department (IMD), which declares a heat wave when the temperature is 4.5 to 6.4 degrees Celsius higher than normal. 14 people died in Bihar on Thursday, officials said, including ten people who were working on organizing the seven-phase national elections that are currently underway. Citizens of some parts of Bihar will vote this Saturday. Authorities told Reuters that ten people died at the government hospital in Odisha's Rourkela region on Thursday. The Odisha government has banned outdoor activities for its employees between 11am and 3pm, when temperatures peak. Three people have died of suspected heatstroke in the state of Jharkhand, neighboring Bihar, local media reported. Animals in suffering

In Delhi, where high temperatures have caused wild birds and monkeys to faint or become ill, the city's zoo is turning to swimming pools and sprinklers to relieve its 1,200 occupants. “We have switched to a summer diet, which includes a more liquid diet as well as all seasonal fruits and vegetables that contain more water,” Sanjeet Kumar, director of the zoo, told news agency ANI. New Delhi, where temperatures are expected to reach 43 degrees Celsius on Friday, recorded its first heat-related death this week and faces severe water shortages. Thousands of people across Asia, including neighboring Pakistan, have been struggling with rising temperatures – a trend that scientists say has been worsened by human-caused climate change. India, which is holding its national elections in the heat, is the world's third-largest emitter of greenhouse gases but has set a goal of carbon neutrality by 2070. As heat affects parts of the country, the northeastern states of Manipur and Assam were hit by heavy rains following Cyclone Remal, with several areas flooded on Friday. Monsoon rains also hit the coast of the country's southernmost state of Kerala on Thursday, two days earlier than expected.

column3:
Brazil is among places that could become uninhabitable in 50 years, says NASA

Wet-bulb temperatures are rising around the world, and Earth's climate has begun to exceed the 35°C threshold. A study by NASA, the American space agency, showed that some places in the world could become uninhabitable in the coming decades because of climate change. According to the report, areas of the Central-West, Northeast, North and Southeast of Brazil are included in a study that mapped five regions. Colin Raymond, of NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory and author of a 2020 study on extreme heat and humidity, analyzes that "climate models tell us that certain regions are likely to exceed these temperatures [35ºC] in the next 30 to 50 years ". In addition to Brazil, Raymond mentions South and parts of Southeast Asia, East China, the Persian Gulf and the Red Sea. The US is not immune either: Within 50 years, the country's Midwestern states such as Arkansas, Missouri and Iowa will likely be in dire straits as well. The 35ºC reported in the research refers to the wet-bulb temperature used as a standard for measuring heat and humidity, especially in long-term global climate research. According to Raymond, this is the highest wet-bulb temperature that humans can survive when exposed for at least six hours. Wet-bulb temperatures are rising around the world, and Earth's climate has begun to surpass this 35°C threshold. This means that the hotter it is, the more tension our bodies feel, and the more we need to sweat to cool down.
