column3:
Brazil's first protest at COP28 uses a giant pink dolphin against oil exploration in the Amazon

A 4-meter-long pink dolphin, made by artist Gil Reais, was the protagonist of Brazil's first protest action at COP28, in Dubai, held this Sunday (3). The initiative, entitled “Boto Alerta: Queremos nadar na água, não no petrol!”, was carried out by the youth organization Engajamundo, in partnership with Greenpeace Brasil, in the Blue Zone of the UN climate conference. The objective was to denounce the socio-environmental impacts that oil exploration in the Amazon region can cause, one of the issues that is clouding Brazil's presence at the first COP of the Lula government. Brazil's protest at COP28 inspired by the death of dolphins

The inspiration for the sculpture was the death of dolphins impacted by the severe drought of the last period, representing the fauna and oil exploration in the Amazon River Basin. For Marcelo Laterman, spokesperson for Greenpeace Brazil, the action carried out in partnership with Engajamundo denounces the contradiction of the Brazilian government in defending the expansion of oil frontiers in the country, especially in sensitive areas such as the Amazon, while at the same time seeking to reposition the country in a leading role in the climate agenda. “These young activists are creatively sending an important message: there is no virtuous future for the Amazon with the advance of oil in the region. The opening of this new frontier could be marked as President Lula’s worst socio-environmental legacy. The government must fulfill its promises and defend the Amazon, its people and face the climate crisis responsibly.” According to Engajamundo, between 2012 and 2020, the number of oil fields in the Amazon increased by 13% and, if this new frontier on the Amazon coast is opened, this number will increase exponentially. Brazil is the 9th largest oil producer in the world. Engajamundo and Greenpeace criticize Basil’s entry as an observer in OPEC+ (Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries), in the middle of COP28, “which shows that the country and its leaders still have oil as an economic priority, despite speeches in defense of decarbonization.” Jaciara Borari is one of the indigenous activists from Engajamundo and is part of the delegation that organized this action. “We want the protest at COP28 to somehow express the urgency of this agenda reaching decision-makers, and for the process of oil exploration in the Amazon River Basin to be rethought and stopped. “We still have time to avoid a major disaster that has been announced!” warns the activist.

column6: ['CC: Criticism of institutions and authorities: Criticism of national governments', 'CC: Amplifying Climate Fears: Other']

column3:
Emirates oil company chairman to lead COP28

The head of the United Arab Emirates oil company was appointed on Thursday (12) as chairman of the annual UN climate conference, scheduled for the end of the year in the Gulf country, drawing criticism from environmentalists. The UAE's Industry Minister, chairman of oil giant ADNOC (Abu Dhabi National Oil Company) and special envoy for climate change, Sultan Ahmed al Jaber, is the "chairman-designate for the 28th Conference of the Parties (COP28)," the official WAM news agency said in a statement on Thursday. It will be the first time that a company chairman will lead the COP, which this year is being held in Dubai between November and December. "We will bring a pragmatic, realistic and solution-oriented approach," Sultan Ahmed al Jaber said after his appointment. "Climate action represents a major economic opportunity to invest in sustainable growth. Financing is key," he added. Sultan Ahmed al Jaber has headed the UAE's national oil company since 2016, as well as Masdar, the country's renewable energy company. His dual role has drawn criticism from environmentalists. “The appointment of Sultan Ahmed al Jaber to the COP28 presidency as the chairman of Abu Dhabi’s national oil company is an outrageous conflict of interest,” said Harjeet Singh of Climate Action Network International. “The constant threat of fossil fuel lobbyists at UN climate talks has always undermined the outcome of climate talks. This has now reached a dangerous and unprecedented level,” he added. Oil and gas lobbyists were plentiful at COP27 in Egypt last November, up 25% from the previous meeting in Glasgow, according to environmental groups. The largest contingent of lobbyists were from the Emirates, followed by the Russians. The United Arab Emirates, one of the world’s largest oil exporters, advocates phasing out hydrocarbons and has committed to achieving carbon neutrality by 2050. The country has seen rapid economic growth since the 1970s, driven by oil, but its economy has gradually diversified. "Limiting warming to 1.5°C [as set out in the 2015 Paris Agreement] will require significant emissions reductions, a pragmatic, practical and realistic approach to the energy transition and greater support for emerging economies," the statement released today said. Climate change is a sensitive issue in the Gulf countries, where temperatures often reach 50°C in summer.
column5: ['CC: Criticism of institutions and authorities']
column6: ['CC: Criticism of institutions and authorities: Criticism of international entities']

column3:
Austrian climate activists "Last Generation" end protests due to lack of results

The "Last Generation" movement has manifested itself in many different forms over the years, often in disruptive ways, in an attempt to gain media and public attention. Some of the most high-profile actions have included road closures, disruptions of motorsport and winter sports events, confrontations with politicians, disruptions of theatre performances, cementing cars, disrupting shareholder meetings of fossil fuel companies, disrupting marathons and, most recently, protests at airports. Now the group has announced an end to the protest actions, at least until it finds new ways to make its voice heard. "Last Generation" says that the government is not responding and that society itself has come out in favour of the use of fossil fuels. "The form of protest was absolutely necessary at the time we decided to do it. We also needed a certain amount of everyday disruption", says Anja Windl, activist with "Last Generation". “But, in the end, the problem of failure is more that few people dared, did not have the courage to really peacefully confront the government.” Activist Afra Porsche seems calm about facing the authorities’ investigations into the protests that the group has already carried out. She also believes that the protests will return, but in a different form. "We need to shake things up. Civil resistance is legitimate and democratic. There will be resistance again, but in a different form," says Afra Porsche. The group managed to attract attention

Communications expert Jakob-Moritz Eberl believes that the group has at least achieved its goal of attracting attention. "The goal was to generate attention and draw attention to the fact that the situation is unpleasant," says Jakob-Moritz Eberl. "There is scientific evidence that the importance of the climate crisis or climate change is much greater after these actions, even for a short period of time, but the issue becomes important for society." Meteorologist Michael Staudinger from the group "Scientists for the Future" argues that scientists also have an important role to play in raising awareness of these concerns. "Well, it was an attempt to convey a certain message. It wasn't very successful, but we understood that young people expressed their concerns in their own way," says Eberl. "Now we have to see what happens next. Science has to convey these issues in the right way." The scientist stresses that the situation is "very serious" and that the most affected are young people. "The next generation and the generation after that will be affected ten times more than ours," he concludes.

column6: ['CC: Criticism of institutions and authorities: Criticism of national governments', 'CC: Criticism of climate movement: Other', 'CC: Amplifying Climate Fears: Other']

column3:
Faced with wave of fires, Lula announces creation of Climate Authority

The creation of the new structure was a campaign promise made by Lula, when Marina Silva, current Minister of the Environment, joined his candidacy in 2022. — Our focus needs to be on adaptation and preparation to face these phenomena (extreme climate risks). To this end, we will establish a climate authority and a technical-scientific committee that supports and coordinates the implementation of the federal government's actions — said the president, during a meeting with mayors to announce measures to combat drought in the state, in an excerpt read from his speech. Lula added that the "objective is to establish the conditions to expand and accelerate public policies based on a national plan to face extreme climate risks". According to the proposal presented in the election, the National Authority for Climate Change would have the objective of monitoring the measures taken by the government to reduce the emission of gases that contribute to the greenhouse effect. After the victory, the proposal was put aside. One of the reasons given was budgetary constraints. Lula traveled to Amazonas accompanied by ministers Rui Costa (Chief of Staff), Marina Silva (Environment), José Múcio Monteiro (Defense), Nizia Trindade (Health), Wellington Dias (Social Development) and Silvio Costa Filho (Ports and Airports). The president announced an investment of 81.8 million euros in dredging interventions in the rivers of the state of Amazonas, to facilitate navigation in the midst of the drought. He also promised to pave a 20-kilometer stretch of the BR-319 highway, at a cost of 25.8 million euros. During his speech, Lula also criticized the administration of his predecessor Jair Bolsonaro (PL). "The previous plan for the environment was clear; it was to open the gate to let the cattle through. And we think that we can even raise cattle, but it is not necessary to destroy the forest and our planet in order to raise them. And that is why we are treating it with great decency." The Amazon has been recording below-average rainfall since July. In recent weeks, fires have left cities and even indigenous territories engulfed in smoke. On August 27, 1,516 fires were recorded in the Amazon, according to the monitoring panel of the National Institute for Space Research (INPE): 39% in Pará, 29% in Amazonas, 12% in Acre, 10% in Rondônia and 8% in Mato Grosso. In July, the Amazon experienced its worst July since the beginning of the historical series of fires, in 1998. In addition to deforestation, the biome is suffering from a severe drought for the second consecutive year.

column3:
World has record for hottest day for the second time in a row

The world once again had its hottest day on record, on Monday (22), surpassing Sunday (21), which had also broken a record, according to preliminary data from a European Union monitoring agency. With heat waves around the world and wildfires in parts of the Mediterranean, Russia and Canada, the global average surface air temperature rose to 17.15 degrees Celsius (°C) on Monday. That number was 0.06°C higher than Sunday's record, according to the European Union's Copernicus Climate Change Service, which has been tracking this data since 1940. This includes temperatures in the Southern Hemisphere, which is currently in winter, which reduces the world average. Scientists said it's possible Tuesday and Wednesday this week could surpass Monday's record again. Until then, the record hot day was recorded in July 2023, when the average daily peak was broken for four consecutive days – from July 3rd to 6th. Before that, the record was recorded in August 2016. El-niño

What makes this year's record unusual is that, unlike 2023 and 2016, in April the world exited the El Niño weather pattern, which typically raises global temperatures due to warmer-than-normal waters in the Eastern Pacific. Karsten Haustein, a climate scientist at the University of Leipzig in Germany, said it is remarkable that the record has been broken again now that the world is in the "neutral" phase of the El Niño-Southern Oscillation. This points to the greater influence than ever of climate change, driven by the burning of fossil fuels, on rising global temperatures. "Last Monday may have set a new world record for the hottest absolute global average temperature ever, that is, tens of thousands of years ago," Haustein said. China has issued a series of heat warnings this week, with dozens of weather stations in parts of the central and northwestern regions of the country recording temperatures exceeding 40°C. Extreme events

Taiwan braced for the impact of Typhoon Gaemi on Wednesday, with factories and financial markets closed amid forecasts of torrential rain. Scientists say climate change is making typhoons – tropical cyclones that gain energy by feeding on ocean heat – more intense, capable of reaching higher wind speeds and dumping more rain. Japan also suffers from record heat throughout the month of July. Heatstroke warnings were issued in 39 of the country's 47 prefectures on Monday, with temperatures exceeding 37°C. More than 40 million Americans were facing dangerous temperatures on Tuesday, mostly in the western United States, where gusty winds and dry conditions have fueled dozens of wildfires. Even the Arctic is experiencing a heat wave. Fairbanks, Alaska, is expected to reach 31°C on Wednesday, approaching previous records, while temperatures in parts of the Canadian, Russian and Norwegian Arctic were reaching temperatures more than 9°C above the 1979-2000 average for this time of year.

column3:
Weather and climate change affect sugar production in Mozambique

"We are registering drops in our sugar production due to some difficulties caused by the bad weather recorded in recent years in the country", Pascoal Macule, director of Tongaat Hulett, the group that owns the Mafambisse Sugar Company, told journalists on Thursday. The executive said that, of the 75 thousand tons produced annually by the firm, it fell to 40 thousand in the last two years, creating huge losses for the factory. Another factor that influenced the sharp drop in production was the loss of around 8,000 hectares of sugar cane, the raw material for sugar production, due to the effects of climate change: "This in Nhamatanda, due to the drought in our fields and to the El Niño phenomenon." Located in the administrative post of Mafambisse, in the district of Dondo, in Sofala, the sugar factory has an installed capacity to produce 92 thousand tons of sugar per year. Mozambique is considered one of the countries most severely affected by climate change in the world, cyclically facing floods and tropical cyclones during the rainy season, which takes place between October and April. The 2018/2019 rainy season was one of the most severe in memory: 714 people died, including 648 victims of cyclones Idai and Kenneth, two of the biggest ever to hit the country. The province of Sofala, in the centre of the country, has been one of the worst hit by storms. In the first quarter of last year, heavy rains and the passage of Cyclone Freddy caused 306 deaths, affected more than 1.3 million people in the country, destroyed 236,000 homes and 3,200 classrooms, according to official government figures. Tongaat Hulett recently announced an injection of 500 million rand (25 million euros) into the Mafambisse and Xinavane sugar mills, both in Mozambique and in which the South African group is the majority shareholder. The challenges the two sugar mills have faced in recent times include countering a continuing decline in sugar sales and obtaining support to prevent low-priced sugar imports from entering the domestic market and affecting domestic production. To turn the situation around, according to the director of Tongaat Hulett, Mafambisse Sugar Mill adopted several strategies, including seeking more financial partners to leverage the company. "We have recovered, although we have not met expectations. We are currently serving the markets of West Africa, the United States, Mauritius and Mozambique, and we are thinking of expanding the export market for our product to neighboring Malawi," concluded Pascoal Macule.

column3:
Climáximo protesters throw red paint at Navigator headquarters

Coletivo accuses the “cellulose industry” of being responsible for the fires and seven deaths this week. Protesters were arrested and the company will file a criminal complaint. Two members of the Climáximo collective threw red paint this Friday against the headquarters of Navigator, in Lisbon, accusing the paper manufacturing company of being responsible for the forest fires and the deaths that resulted from them. The two people then sat in front of the entrance, on Av. Fontes Pereira de Melo, and were subsequently detained by the PSP, as confirmed by a source from this police force to PÚBLICO, for committing a crime of damage. An official source from Navigator told PÚBLICO that it “vehemently repudiates this and all acts of vandalism” and that it “will file a criminal complaint against those responsible for this act of vandalism”. In a statement from Climáximo, protester Alice Gato, 22, declared that “the seven deaths this week” in the fires that ravaged the Center and North of Portugal “are the direct result of a coordinated offensive between the State, the cellulose industry and the fossil industry to transform the interior of our country into an incineration chamber

This is the second time this week that Climáximo has targeted Navigator facilities. On Tuesday, members of the group had pasted posters on the company's doors, accusing it of “increased responsibility for deaths” during the fires. “In the hottest summer on record, the current plans of Governments and companies like Navigator, to increase greenhouse gas emissions and continue selling the interior of our country to the paper industry, are a violent crime ”, argues the climate collective.

column3:
F-16s arrived in Ukraine. But they don't arrive

For more than two years, Ukrainian forces have been waiting for these reinforcements. But this is “insufficient”, warned President Volodymyr Zelenskyy. Ukraine has received its first Western F-16 fighter jets, expected for more than two years, President Volodymyr Zelenskyy announced today, showing them to journalists and emphasizing that their number is “insufficient”. “We held hundreds of meetings and negotiations” with allies to obtain these planes and reinforce the country’s air defense and “we often heard the words ‘it is impossible’ in response,” said Volodymyr Zelenskyy, during a ceremony at a secret location in Ukraine, according to AFP. “Now it is reality, reality in our heaven. The F-16s are in Ukraine,” he said. Since the start of the Russian invasion in February 2022, Kiev has been begging for the delivery of F-16s in hopes of ending Russian dominance in the air and better protecting its cities and military against incessant bombardment by Moscow's forces. Made in the United States, the planes are considered the crown jewel in the extensive list of military equipment that Ukraine has requested from its allies in an attempt to repel the advance of Russian forces on its soil. The president of Ukraine did not reveal the number of aircraft received by Kiev, limiting himself to saying that it is “insufficient”, as well as the number of Ukrainian pilots trained in the West to fly those aircraft. The delivery date and the country that supplied this first batch were also not revealed. “What is positive is that we expect more F-16s” and that “many of our men are being trained”, assured Zelenskyy. AFP journalists saw at least two F-16s flying over the site during the ceremony. Behind Volodymyr Zelenskyy, two other gray F-16-like aircraft were placed on the ground, partially covered by camouflage netting and with their tails emblazoned with the national coat of arms, the trident. In mid-May, President Zelenskyy stated in an interview with AFP that he needed 120 to 130 of these aircraft to achieve parity with Russian aviation.

column3:
The injustice of climate justice

The climate justice discourse is yet another nonsense in the debate led by groups on the watermelon left: green on the outside, red on the inside. The combination of the two ideas, justice and climate, is abhorrent. Opinions or policies with this level of absurdity must be denounced and rejected! Justice is a social concept. There is no justice without human beings in society. Climate, in turn, corresponds to a set of atmospheric conditions in a region over many years. And most importantly, climate does not depend on humans. Climate depends mainly on the Sun. Without the Sun, there would be no climate, no life on Earth, no human beings – watermelons or not. The watermelon left replaces family with climate in the formulation of national and global policies. In the name of climate justice, draconian environmental measures are taken. They drive industry out of Europe and make fuel prices unsustainable. Our tax burden on diesel is 44% and gasoline is 51%. We all know the consequences. More expensive transport and products. Fewer job opportunities. Fewer jobs. Less justice. And with everything getting more expensive, we still have to pay for a poorly designed energy transition. We are forced to bear environmental costs ignored by countries like China, which has almost 200 times more emissions than we do. In Portugal, the climate justice of the watermelon left makes the poorest and most vulnerable suffer. These Portuguese people are the ones most impacted in their daily lives by the increase in basic food prices. They are the ones who must survive in cold, unheated homes, forgotten by climate watchdogs.

column3:
Italy's Deputy Prime Minister Suggests Macron Wear Helmet and Go to Ukraine

Italy's Minister of Transport and Infrastructure Matteo Salvini has suggested that Emmanuel Macron go to Ukraine and take part in hostilities. "I will tell Macron: go to Ukraine to fight, put on a helmet and don't mess with the Italians," Salvini said at a campaign event for his League party's candidate for mayor of the city. The League leader has repeatedly criticized NATO and EU leaders for their stance on increasing military support for Kiev and their willingness to lift restrictions on Ukraine's strikes with Western weapons on the territory of the Russian Federation. EU foreign minister Josep Borrell Salvini has called the Demoman and NATO Secretary General Stoltenberg "Mr. Dangerous." Macron has previously said he does not rule out sending troops to Ukraine if Russia breaks through the front lines and Ukraine asks for it. According to him, "many countries" agreed with France's approach on the possible deployment of troops. According to the newspaper "Monde", Macron wants to create a European coalition to send military instructors to Ukraine. Russian President's spokesman Dmitry Peskov called the rhetoric from Paris and London on the possibility of sending troops to Ukraine dangerous. The Kremlin also said that it drew attention to Macron's words on the topic of sending military personnel to Ukraine in Europe, his position on inflicting a "strategic defeat" on Moscow is also well known. They noted that a number of countries maintain "a rather sober assessment of the potential dangers of such an action and the potential danger of directly getting involved in a hot conflict", this "is not at all in the interests of these countries, they should be aware of this."

column3:
The head of Chega in the European Elections is the former Ambassador who received 2 sailboats, went against the Ukrainian government and revealed a “State Secret”

António Tânger Corrêa, who was general secretary of the Centrist Youth (CDS) and assistant to the Minister of Foreign Affairs, Diogo Freitas do Amaral in the original AD government, was confirmed this weekend in the press as Head of the list for Chega in the next European Elections . The former ambassador is a protagonist in several controversies, with a long history of 30 years of taking risks, according to Jornal Público, where the “offer” of a sailboat stands out, of which there were two after all (you can read it on Facebook – here the full story). According to the same newspaper, “António Ranger’s” career is a catalog of “cases” that included breaking into a house and being suspended by the MNE with an unprecedented sentence in the profession — the first for an active ambassador serving abroad. António Tânger, who followed in his father's footsteps in his diplomatic career, was suspended in 2009 for 90 days due to several irregularities found in the management of the Portuguese embassy in the capital of Lithuania, Vilnius. But the controversies of No. 1 of the European Championships of June 2024 do not stop at situations while he was representing Portugal, more recently, and already as vice-president of André Ventura's party, he adopted a position contrary to the party leader, accusing the Government of President Zelensky of being responsible for the invasion of Ukraine, using a copied message. In February 2022, days before Russia's invasion of Ukraine began, António Tânger began making a wrong prognosis and criticizing “commentators who are sorry for their ignorance” because “will there ever be a war?”

After this comment he “copied” a text on Facebook that accuses the president of Ukraine and justifies Russia's position. This text was placed on your page without identifying the author, later identified after the person responsible contested the copy, and was later deleted from your page after also appearing in the news on Expresso. Months earlier, in September 2021, the vice-president of Chega revealed to the press a Conspiracy Theory that was later not confirmed, by announcing a “State Secret” before the elections, as according to the former ambassador a “state secret” had been created. working group between the secret police and the Judiciary Police to incriminate Chega” in an alleged connection to the denialists. In January 2023, on the second day of the V Chega Convention in Santarém, António Tânger Corrêa recalled the times when he was leader of the Centrist Youth to ask for greater presence and dynamism from the Chega Youth: 

I don't want Youth Chega to be like the others. I wanted to see Juventude Chega, call me nostalgic or whatever you want, fighting in the streets with clubs with the MRPP and the PCP. He was greatly applauded by the nostalgic fans, which made the former ambassador further state: “In my time it was cleaning”.

column3:
"Many armies are not ready to fight Russia." In NATO, there are those who fear that they will not resist an invasion beyond Ukraine

Donald Trump's entry into the US presidency could confuse everything and leave Europe vulnerable

“If anyone thinks this is just about Ukraine, they are sadly mistaken.” The warning was made by the President of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky, at the World Economic Forum in Davos. The Ukrainian president's objective is not new: the idea is to continue putting pressure on the West, namely the United States, for continued financial and military support for Kiev, at a time when Congress remains deadlocked in approving more aid. And if the situation is complicated with Joe Biden's administration, behind the scenes there are fears that a possible election of Donald Trump will only make everything worse. The former president and likely Republican Party candidate has said several times that he wants to leave NATO and stop helping Western allies militarily. If this extends to Ukraine, Kiev will hardly be able to resist Moscow's advances, and it is possible that, one year at a time, it will fall. This scenario leaves several European countries alarmed, and many of them afraid of not being able to resist a possible Russian move beyond Ukraine, especially if the United States is not available to provide support. “We always thought there was a threat like this,” said Major General Veiko-Vello Pal, commander of the Estonian army, speaking to The New York Times about a possible Russian invasion. But the problem is not just the possible lack of American aid. The official from Estonia, one of the countries of the former Soviet Union, which borders modern-day Russia, was merely echoing what the country has been saying for a long time. Because of its geographical location, Estonia is one of the most vulnerable countries. For this reason, it is also one of the countries that has contributed the most to NATO, having one of the largest armies in terms of size, but it will never be enough to defend the country from a power like Russia. The problem is, according to Veiko-Vello Pal, that many other countries do not have this capacity either. “In recent times, we have made it very, very clear that, as a military alliance, many NATO countries are not ready to conduct large-scale operations,” he said. “Simply speaking, many NATO armies are not ready to fight Russia,” he concluded, admitting great discomfort with the situation.

column3:
Ukrainian drone strike causes fire at Russian refinery

A drone strike launched by Ukraine overnight caused a fire at an oil refinery and killed one person in southern Russia, Russian and Ukrainian authorities said Monday (22). Kiev and Moscow have stepped up their cross-border attacks on each other, both with missiles and drones, in recent months, targeting mainly energy infrastructure. The Russian regional authorities of the Black Sea and the town of Tuapse, in the Krasnodar region (south), explained that the fall of drone debris caused a fire at a refinery, which required the mobilization of about a hundred firefighters. The governor of Belgorod, another southern Russian region, said that a person driving a tractor was killed after being hit by a Ukrainian drone, and that his wife was injured. A source in the Ukrainian defense sector said that drones related to military intelligence services were used and that the damaged refinery is operated by the Russian state giant Rosneft. "The extent of the damage to the military-industrial complex of the aggressor state is being verified," the source said in a written statement. According to the Russian Defense Ministry, 75 Ukrainian drones were shot down overnight, 47 of them in the southern Rostov region, another in Belgorod, two more in Voronezh and Smolensk, and eight in the skies of Krasnodar. Another 17 drones were shot down while flying over the Black Sea and the Sea of ​​Azov, according to the ministry. Russia announces, almost daily, that it has shot down Ukrainian drones on its territory. According to Kiev, these attacks are a response to Russian bombings as part of the invasion of the country, launched by Moscow in February 2022. Ukraine said that its forces shot down 16 drones overnight.

column3:
Around 20 countries call for tripling global nuclear power by 2050

The announcement was made by John Kerry, the United States' climate envoy, during the 28th United Nations Climate Change Conference (COP28) which runs until December 12 in Dubai. China and Russia, the world's largest builders of nuclear power plants, are not among the signatories. In addition to the United States, France and the United Arab Emirates, the declaration was signed by Bulgaria, Canada, the Czech Republic, Finland, Ghana, Hungary, Japan, Moldova, Mongolia, Morocco, the Netherlands, Poland, Romania, Slovakia, Slovenia, Sweden, Ukraine, South Korea and the United Kingdom. "The declaration recognises the key role of nuclear energy in achieving carbon neutrality by 2050 and in maintaining the goal of (limiting global warming to) 1.5°C," the text states. "We know from the science, the facts and the evidence that we cannot achieve carbon neutrality by 2050 without nuclear power," said John Kerry. Romanian President Clausus Johannites explained that nuclear power represents for the European country "a stable energy source that contributes to energy security and decarbonisation". The signatory countries also call on international financial institutions, such as the World Bank, to include nuclear power in approved financing. "There are statutory provisions, sometimes in certain international credit institutions, that exclude nuclear energy. I think that is completely obsolete," Rafael Grossi, director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), told Agence France-Presse. Proponents of nuclear energy say it is flexible, emits virtually no greenhouse gases and is an unparalleled means of producing clean and abundant electricity. On the other hand, some environmentalists point to negative aspects, such as the risk of accidents and the high cost of this energy.

column3:
Southeast Europe records unusually hot summer: Greece records hottest July ever

July 2024 went down in history as the hottest month ever recorded in Greece, according to preliminary data analyzed by the scientific team at meteo.gr and the National Observatory of Athens. This heat record not only exceeded the average July temperatures from the period 1991-2020 by 2.9°C, but also exceeded the previous record from July 2012 by 0.3°C. July 2024: a month of historic records in Greece and the world

Analysis of climate data revealed that July 2024 was marked by long periods of exceptionally high temperatures, significantly exceeding seasonal normals across the country. This pattern of extreme heat is in line with a worrying trend observed in recent decades: since 1960, the average July temperature in Greece has increased by 2.5°C. Furthermore, over the past four years, three of the four hottest Julys in the last 80 years have been recorded in Greece, highlighting a growing trend of extreme temperatures attributed to climate change. Additionally, the persistent heat of July 2024 was compounded by one of the longest heat wave periods since 1980. This heat wave occurred between July 8 and 23. But anyone who thinks that this trend was limited only to Greece is mistaken. In fact, globally, July 21, 2024 was considered the hottest day ever, with a global average temperature of 17.1°C, as reported by the European Union's Copernicus Climate Change Service. This record was surpassed again the following day, July 22, with the global average temperature reaching 17.2 °C. Adaptation and mitigation measures: Greece's response to extreme heat

One cannot, in fact, neglect the inherent concerns. Greek authorities have been taking measures to adapt and mitigate the impacts of extreme temperatures. During heat peaks, several cities opened air-conditioned centers to help the vulnerable population. Additionally, there has been an increase in preparedness and response to wildfires, which are a greater threat during periods of extreme heat. Note, for example, the concern that civil protection elements have had, closing the most visited monument in Greece, the Acropolis, in Athens, during the heat, between 12pm and 5pm. Data from July 2024 reinforces the urgency of concrete measures to adapt to climate change. The record temperatures, not just in Greece but globally, are a clear sign of the intensification of extreme weather phenomena, which have expanded into the month of August. Note, in fact, the days with very high temperatures that continue at the beginning of this month across Europe and in Greece, in particular, and that will last for at least the next few weeks.

column3:
Fundo Brasil supports projects for traditional communities

The Traditional Communities Fighting for Climate Justice call has been open since Monday (27) and interested parties may submit projects until January 31, 2024. Applications must be submitted on the organization's website. Proposals may involve topics such as land rights, productive alternatives, training activities, among others. Traditional communities will be considered to be culturally distinct groups, which are characterized by their own forms of social organization and which relate to their territories and natural resources as a fundamental condition for their cultural, social, economic and spiritual reproduction. This includes indigenous people, andirobeiras, everlasting plant gatherers, caatingueiros, mangaba gatherers, quilombolas, extractivists, riverside dwellers, caiçaras, gypsies, terreiro peoples, cipozeiros, chestnut tree growers, faxinalenses, fundo and fecha de pasto, geraizeiros, islhéus, isqueiros, morroquianos, pantaneiros, artisanal fishermen, piassava growers, pomerans, babassu coconut breakers, retireros, rubber tappers, vazanteiros and veredeiros. The Fund indicates that these communities have been greatly affected by the advance of the exploitation of biomes observed in Brazil in recent years, with the growth of illegal occupations and agrarian conflicts. Furthermore, it notes that they are also impacted due to their vulnerability to the consequences of climate change, such as drought or excessive rainfall depending on the region and time of year. "Supporting the ways of life of traditional communities also means ensuring sustainable practices, preserving biodiversity and promoting the resilience of ecosystems, in a broad strategy for climate and environmental justice covered by this notice," the organization maintains. New calls for proposals

According to the Fundo Brasil de Direitos Humanos, the call for proposals is the first to be launched by Raízes - Fundo de Justiça Climática para Povos e Comunidades Tradicionais, a support line that should allocate at least R$6 million over the next 3 years to strengthen grassroots groups, communities and organizations that work to defend their rights and protect territories and natural resources. New calls for proposals should be announced later.

column3:
Water shortage in Espírito Santo: drought can no longer take anyone by surprise

From 2015 to 2017, the water crisis in Espírito Santo required tough measures, such as the prohibition of irrigation of plantations during the day in municipalities in critical situations, with economic impacts on the agricultural sector. Industries also committed to reducing consumption. The population had to commit to a culture of rationing. The state government then began a program to build multipurpose dams. The Reis Magos supply system, in Serra, was also inaugurated in 2017, in this context, reducing the overload on the Santa Maria da Vitória System. And, in 2018, the construction of the Jucu River dam between Domingos Martins and Viana was announced, with the capacity to store 23 billion liters of water: accumulating the resource in the wet season for use in the dry season, as the little ant teaches in the fable. This important project, which is progressing slowly, is included in the PAC. Its urgency is undeniable. In this atypical month of November, with no rain, in which Espírito Santo is one of the states affected by the heat wave, the alert for a new water supply crisis is sounding. In the Metropolitan Area, the Jucu and Santa Maria rivers are approaching the critical level, as reported by Leonel Ximenes in his column. Cesan also reported that the rivers from which the company draws water to supply the population have had their water levels reduced due to the recent drought and warned that the situation affects the 53 municipalities served by the company. In Pinheiros, in the north of the state, the water supply has been compromised in the district of São João Sobrado for 15 days, requiring the use of tanker trucks. Neighborhoods in Marataízes, on the South Coast, have also been suffering from a lack of water since last week. As previously stated, this is still only a warning, which already requires the government to prepare contingency actions. No government has the ability to control when it rains or shines, but experience in previous critical scenarios should teach what needs to be done to avoid or face future supply crises. Without standing idly by. Periods of drought, like those of rain, are cyclical and unpredictable, but will become increasingly common with climate change. Governor Renato Casagrande chairs the Consórcio Brasil Verde, created in 2021 to develop coordinated actions between federative entities, obtaining external financial resources and seeking good practices to mitigate climate effects in the country. Investments are needed not only in large-scale projects, but also in smaller rainwater harvesting projects, as well as industrial water reuse projects and the conservation and recovery of riparian forests, which are responsible for the health of rivers. Amid warnings of global climate change, we need to prepare for what lies ahead, with planning that integrates the municipal, state and federal spheres. We already have enough experience to learn how to deal with extreme weather events and reduce damage. It is a path of no return.

column3:
COP28: Brazil resumes central role in climate negotiations, but Congress approves absurd coal subsidy

Brazil is an environmental powerhouse. Period. It is large, has a voice, has the largest tropical forest on the planet, and has an efficient diplomacy that has already found several solutions to real problems. This year, the country returns to the table at COP28, after four tragic years of denialism, with data on emissions and deforestation reductions. Brazil at COP28: Lula and Marina with ideas and solutions

Environment and health: Approval of the 'Poison Bill' goes against new trends and happens at the worst time

I spoke this morning with Minister Marina Silva, who is already in Dubai for the conference, and she told me that Brazil will present the new financing mechanism for forest countries tomorrow. This is a new path, in addition to those that already exist and that could prosper in the negotiations over the next few days, such as the 91.4 billion euros per year for mitigation and adaptation, which, in COP jargon, means that rich countries with older industrialization will finance policies to reduce the impacts of climate change and also to adapt to irreversible changes in developing nations. There is another path, which is the agreement on losses and damages. Speaking from there today, the minister stated that the agreement is being reached to make compensation for vulnerable countries concrete. COP28: Research shows that workers would like to contribute to sustainability, but are unaware of company strategies

The problem is that here in Brazil, Congress gives a signal that is completely contrary to the agenda presented by Brazil at COP28. By approving a coal subsidy, what Congress is doing is subverting the meaning of the green agenda, corrupting the meaning of the wind energy law to serve the lobbies and transferring the cost of this contradiction to you, reader. Subsidizing coal also means sending this cost, estimated at R$4.6 billion per year, to the electricity bill. There is also a contradiction in Dubai, of course. There is an expectation of progress on the climate change agenda at COP28 despite it being held in the United Arab Emirates, the heart of oil, which is the largest emitter of greenhouse gases, therefore a large part of the problem. Minister Marina Silva told me that the big victory would be to leave the conference with a commitment to reducing the use of fossil fuels, which will be challenging as the president of COP28, Sultan al-Jaber, also heads the local oil company. Contradictions: On his way to the COP, Lula goes to the birthplace of oil and tyranny in the Middle East

At this meeting, it is expected that the first assessment will be made of the commitments, national targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions established in the Paris Agreement. But it will be in Brazil, at COP30, ten years after the agreement signed in the French capital, that the great adjustment and the reestablishment of goals will be made. Now, one detail: at COP28, everyone is looking towards COP30 in Belém. But where will COP29 be? There is a stalemate. It has to be in a European country, but Russia's war against Ukraine has confused that choice.

column3:
Lula's message on fossil fuels after OPEC+ invitation

President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva said this Friday, the 1st, that world economies need to address the debate on fossil fuels and reduce their use. The president's speech was given at COP 28, in the United Arab Emirates, one day after Brazil received an invitation from the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and Allies (OPEC+) to join the group. “The world is already convinced of the potential of renewable energy. It is time to address the debate on the slow pace of decarbonization of the planet and work towards an economy less dependent on fossil fuels,” he said. In his opening speech, Lula drew attention to the increase in global temperatures and extreme global events, such as the historic drought in the Amazon and cyclones in the southern region of Brazil. “The bill has come early,” said the president, stating that the planet is “fed up” with climate agreements that are made and not fulfilled, and reiterated that Brazil is willing to lead “by example.” The day before, Brazil received an invitation to join OPEC+, the organization that controls oil prices through a cartel of major producers such as Saudi Arabia, Iran, Iraq, the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela and other allied countries, such as Mexico and Russia. The organization, which uses the increase in fuel production to control the value of the commodity on the international market, has a different view from that defended by Lula in his speech at the COP, which is that fossil fuels should continue to be used. This Friday, Petrobras CEO Jean Paul Prates told Reuters that Brazil should join the OPEC+ group of oil producers. According to him, the country should play a cooperative role and monitor decisions, but without participating in the production quota system. “They call on other countries that do not have the right to vote and are not subject to quotas. We would never participate in an entity that established a quota for Brazil, especially with the support of Petrobras, which is a publicly traded company and cannot have a quota,” the executive stated. In addition to defending the use of renewable energy and the obvious awkward situation that the country is putting itself in by accepting to join OPEC+, Lula said in his speech that spending on weapons and wars should be used to combat hunger and climate change. “How many tons of carbon are emitted by missiles that cross the sky and fall on innocent civilians, especially children and women?” The president also said that “the world has naturalized unacceptable disparities in income, gender and race and that it is not possible to tackle climate change without tackling inequality.” In his speech, Lula also criticized the UN’s stance on its inability to maintain peace, “simply because some of its members profit from war.” The United Nations has Russia, Ukraine and Israel as member countries, for example. “Governments cannot be exempted from their responsibilities. No country will solve its problems alone. We are all obliged to act together, beyond our borders. Brazil is willing to lead by example. We have adjusted our goals, which are now more ambitious than those of many developed countries,” he said.

column3: United Kingdom: The country has been invaded by a new species of jumping spider! Scientists have recently discovered a new species of spider in the south of England. It is believed that its migration has been facilitated by climate change. Researchers assure that this species is not poisonous to humans. However, it is attracting a lot of attention. But what is happening? Several cities in the United States have recently been on alert for invasions of giant exotic spiders. It is enough to send people into panic. Now it is the turn of Europe, more specifically, the southern regions of the United Kingdom. During a biological census carried out by the British Arachnological Society in Penryn, west Cornwall (England), in 2023, researchers identified for the first time a species of spider native to the Caribbean. Far from the giant exotic spider invading the United States, this species is tiny, measuring no more than 3 to 4 mm in length. Scientifically called Anasaitis milesae, this species of jumping spider is completely harmless. Like most spiders, this one is not poisonous, but like all animals, it defends itself by biting when it feels threatened. Given its size, its bite seems insignificant. But how did it get from the Caribbean to England? According to scientists, it traveled thanks to international trade. Due to its tiny size, it could easily fit into suitcases or be transported in international shipping containers. And it clearly enjoyed the Anglo-Saxon climate. It is not the only animal and insect to travel this way; the Asian hornet was also introduced this way. As a result of climate change, insect invasions are becoming more frequent. The milder climate of the UK's port areas is favouring the establishment of these new specimens. Anasaitis milesae is not the only species to have recently arrived in the European country. Experts have also observed a Mediterranean spider called Zoropsis spinimana, or 'false wolf spider', in London. Another species identified in the south of the UK is Segestria florentina. This spider has the distinctive feature of having green fangs. Unlike the Caribbean species, these two species are imposing in size and have a painful bite. And like Anasaitis milesae, they are not dangerous to humans.

column3:
"The fight against climate change is not on the voting table." Jovem do Climáximo interrupts debate between party leaders

The debate between the eight party leaders with parliamentary seats had started four minutes ago when it was interrupted by a young man from the Climáximo activist movement. “The fight against climate change is not on the voting table, it is in the hands of the people”, shouted the protester, who invaded the studio that RTP set up at the Nova SBE university, in Carcavelos, and placed himself in front of the moderator, the journalist Carlos Daniel. The young man was immediately removed by a member of the production, at the moment when Pedro Nuno Santos, leader of the PS, was explaining the scenarios he defends for governance for the country after the legislative elections on March 10th. Shortly afterwards, when the president of the PSD, Luís Montenegro, was being questioned, more background voices from protesters were heard due to the atmosphere, which led Carlos Daniel to mention that some protests were continuing “by some people who understood that this was the moment to bring your message to the public space.” “It is no longer new in the country, but we will keep the debate within what was planned”, he added. Climáximo protesters also painted the windows behind the candidates with red paint. In a statement seen by Observador, the group states that the protest “aimed to interrupt the normality of electoral debates that ignore the climate crisis and whose plans” lead “to climate collapse: water shortages for people, losses in agriculture and food production, deaths due to unbearable heat waves, displacements due to deadly fires”. António Assunção, spokesperson for Climáximo, says that “in these elections, not only is stopping the climate crisis not the main issue, but no party — with or without parliamentary seats — presents a plan compatible with the limits of nature”. “Failing to implement” cuts of “at least” 75% of emissions by 2030 is “guaranteeing climate and civilizational collapse”, he considers. “We cannot allow them to continue taking us to climate hell. All parties deliberately reiterate their declaration of war against people. Society must resist and fight to stop the climate crisis”, adds the spokesperson, who reiterates that the group believes that an “alternative” to stop the climate crisis is “on the streets, not at the ballot box”. In the statement released this Friday, Climáximo recalls that over the last week it has been altering the billboards of several parties, placing the phrase “with your vote we guarantee climate collapse”. Observador awaits a response from RTP to the questions posed. Authorities are already on site, about an hour after the incident. The PSP of Carcavelos, in a previous telephone contact, said it was unable to provide information about the possible arrest of the protesters.

column3:
EU withdraws meeting of Hungarian foreign ministers over country's position on war in Ukraine

The European Union's top diplomat, Josep Borrell, withdrew from Hungary this Monday a meeting of EU foreign ministers, which was to take place in Budapest, in a reaction by the bloc to the country's rapprochement with Russia over the war in Ukraine. Borrel said the late August meeting would now take place in Brussels, after Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán visited Moscow and Beijing without EU support, and said his government defined European policy as "pro-war". "We have to send a signal, albeit a symbolic one," Borrell told reporters in Brussels at the last meeting of foreign ministers before the summer holidays. Orbán began the trip, which also included a visit to the Republican candidate for President of the United States, Donald Trump, just days after Hungary assumed the rotating Presidency of the EU, on July 1st. At Monday's meeting, several foreign ministers expressed strong condemnation of the Hungarian minister, Peter Szijjarto, according to officials. "This was done very clearly and repeatedly so as to leave no room for doubt," said Portuguese Foreign Minister Paulo Rangel. Several European countries consider Hungary to be too close to Moscow, sabotaging EU efforts to isolate Russia politically and diplomatically over its invasion of Ukraine. Hungary says it seeks to bring peace to Ukraine as quickly as possible.

column3:
The new bonfires of the Inquisition

1. The rector of the University of Coimbra thinks he can fire the director of the Center for Russian Studies at that University with the same arbitrariness with which any boss of a stairwell company fires a young man on a trial period. There is no disciplinary process, there are no facts to justify it. There is the fact that the fired director is Russian and there is the accusation made by two Ukrainians that the director recommends books by Russian authors and has an opinion on the war in Ukraine that does not coincide with that of the informants. In all the news that came out about this dismissal, which was carried out outside any legal process, which is serious in a public institution, there are no other facts that justify it other than the nationality of the author and the statement regarding his opinions. . It is clear that we are facing a gross violation of article 13 of the Constitution of the Portuguese Republic, according to which no one can be harmed or deprived of any right due to their language, territory of origin, religion, political or ideological convictions. That Ukrainian whistleblowers ignore the Portuguese Constitution and the democratic rights it enshrines does not surprise me, but that the rector of a University should promote the summary dismissal of a professor based on his nationality and for a crime of opinion, is something that bothers me. It amazes me, it outrages me, and I consider it to be a disservice to a University whose prestige should be defended. Were we not living in the climate of witch hunt that has been imposed on this western corner of the world and the news of a rector who, in an act of total arrogance, summarily dismisses a professor, violating his fundamental rights with the same degree of carelessness with which he prohibits beef in canteens would be the cause of a national and international scandal. 2. Manuel Pires da Rocha is a prestigious Portuguese musician and music teacher. He is publicly known for being the violinist of Brigada Victor Jara, but he has a past and present of enormous prestige in music teaching, namely as professor and director of the Coimbra Conservatory. He studied in Moscow, where he obtained a degree in violin and, unlike others, he respects the country where he studied and the people who welcomed him. Last week, Manuel Pires da Rocha was the target of a snitch who identified himself as a “Jew of Ukrainian origin”, who sent an email to the Conservatory teachers denouncing his presence at the Victory Day celebrations over Nazi-fascism in Lisbon . The response to this ignominy was given by Manuel Rocha himself with the intellectual brilliance for which he is recognized and whose reading I highly recommend. 3. These two episodes are in addition to that of the Setúbal Chamber, where Russian citizens were vilified and even accused of being spies for the simple fact of being Russian and willing to support Ukrainian refugees in Portugal, in addition to demonstrations by Ukrainian citizens in Portugal displaying flags of Nazi organizations and defending the illegalization of the PCP, add to a drift of political and cultural intolerance that is very dangerous for democracy. The thing is, as Manuel Rocha wrote in his text, citing the vampires sung by José Afonso who are back out there, if someone is fooled by their serious appearance and opens the doors to them upon arrival, they eat everything and leave nothing behind.

column3:
Russia is giving up on Kharkiv after ‘failure’

Russia is now “throwing everything it has” at the eastern front, Zelenskyy says. Kremlin denies: “Operation is ongoing”. Just months after Moscow launched the operation, Kharkiv is preparing to see the Russians leave after the “failure” of the offensive with more troops in northeastern Ukraine, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said. According to Zelenskyy’s recent interview, Russia is now “throwing everything it has” at the eastern front, where it has intensified fighting near the city of Pokrovsk. “Its main focus is no longer the entire east, although Sloviansk [a city in northern Donetsk that borders the Kharkiv region] is not excluded,” the Ukrainian leader added. In June, Zelenskyy had already described the failure of the operation. “I spoke with the commander-in-chief about the general situation. “A very significant result is that the Russian army failed in its operation in Kharkiv. Now we are holding them back as much as possible and destroying Russian units that enter our territory and terrorize the Kharkiv region,” the Ukrainian president said. Russia, however, has already denied giving up the territory, according to The Moscow Times. “This operation is ongoing and will continue until it is successfully completed,” Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said on July 17. In a July 24 update, Ukrainian forces near the city described the fighting as “tense and difficult.” Ukraine’s second-largest city, Kharkiv, was overrun by some 30,000 Russian troops, who entered several villages and reopened the northeastern front of the war. The city lacked the necessary defenses that should have been in place by now, experts and commanders in the war that has dragged on since 2022 said.
